5.text:
CHAPTER 1
On the morning the radar reported something

9.text:
odd out in space, Lockley awoke at about twenty
minutes to eight. That was usual. He'd slept

15.text:
in a sleeping bag on a mountain-flank with
other mountains all around. That was not unprecedented.

22.text:
He was there to make a base line measurement
for a detailed map of the Boulder Lake National

27.text:
Park, whose facilities were now being built.
Measuring a base line, even with the newest

33.text:
of electronic apparatus, was more or less
a commonplace job for Lockley.

39.text:
This morning, though, he woke and realized
gloomily that he'd dreamed about Jill Holmes

44.text:
again, which was becoming a habit he ought
to break. He'd only met her four times and

50.text:
she was going to marry somebody else. He had
to stop.

55.text:
He stirred, preparatory to getting up. At
the same moment, certain things were happening

61.text:
in places far away from him. As yet, no unusual
object in space had been observed. That would

69.text:
come later. But far away up at the Alaskan
radar complex a man on duty watch was relieved

75.text:
by another. The relief man took over the monitoring
of the giant, football-field-sized radar antenna

83.text:
that recorded its detections on magnetic tape.
It happened that on this particular morning

89.text:
only one other radar watched the skies along
a long stretch of the Pacific Coast There

95.text:
was the Alaskan installation, and the other
was in Oregon. It was extremely unusual for

101.text:
only those two to be operating. The people
who knew about it, or most of them, thought

106.text:
that official orders had somehow gone astray.
Where the orders were issued, nothing out

112.text:
of the ordinary appeared. All was normal,
for example, in the Military Information Center

118.text:
in Denver. The Survey saw nothing unusual
in Lockley's being at his post, and other

124.text:
men at places corresponding to his in the
area which was to become Boulder Lake National

129.text:
Park. It also seemed perfectly natural that
there should be bulldozer operators, surveyors,

137.text:
steelworkers, concrete men and so on, all
comfortably at breakfast in the construction

143.text:
camp for the project. Everything seemed normal
everywhere.

148.text:
Up to the time the Alaskan installation reported
something strange in space, the state of things

154.text:
generally was neither alarming nor consoling.
But at 8:02 A.M. Pacific time, the situation

162.text:
changed. At that time Alaska reported an unscheduled
celestial object of considerable size, high

169.text:
out of atmosphere and moving with surprising
slowness for a body in space. Its course was

177.text:
parabolic and it would probably land somewhere
in South Dakota. It might be a bolide--a large,

184.text:
slow-moving meteorite. It wasn't likely, but
the entire report was improbable.

191.text:
The message reached the Military Information
Center in Denver at 8:05 A.M. By 8:06 it had

197.text:
been relayed to Washington and every plane
on the Pacific Coast was ordered aloft. The

204.text:
Oregon radar unit reported the same object
at 8:07 A.M. It said the object was seven

210.text:
hundred fifty miles high, four hundred miles
out at sea, and was headed toward the Oregon

216.text:
coastline, moving northwest to southeast.
There was no major city in its line of travel.

224.text:
The impact point computed by the Oregon station
was nowhere near South Dakota. As other computations

232.text:
followed other observations, a second place
of fall was calculated, then a third. Then

239.text:
the Oregon radar unbelievably reported that
the object was decelerating. Allowing for

245.text:
deceleration, three successive predictions
of its landing point agreed. The object, said

252.text:
these calculations, would come to earth somewhere
near Boulder Lake, Colorado, in what was to

258.text:
become a national park. Impact time should
be approximately 8:14 A.M.

266.text:
These events followed Lockley's awakening
in the wilds, but he knew nothing of any of

271.text:
them. He himself wasn't near the lake, which
was to be the center of a vacation facility

277.text:
for people who liked the outdoors. The lake
was almost circular and was a deep, rich blue.

285.text:
It occupied what had been the crater of a
volcano millions of years ago. Already bulldozers

292.text:
had ploughed out roads to it through the forest.
Men worked with graders and concrete mixers

298.text:
on highways and on bridges across small rushing
streams. There was a camp for them. A lakeside

304.text:
hotel had been designed and stakes were driven
in the ground where its foundation would eventually

310.text:
be poured. There were infant big-mouthed bass
in the lake and fingerling trout in many of

317.text:
the streams. A huge Wild Life Control trailer-truck
went grumbling about such trails as were practical,

324.text:
attending to these matters. Yesterday Lockley
had seen it gleaming in bright sunshine as

330.text:
it moved toward Boulder Lake on the highway
nearest to his station.

337.text:
But that was yesterday. This morning he awoke
under a pale gray sky. There was complete

343.text:
cloud cover overhead. He smelled conifers
and woods-mould and mountain stone in the

349.text:
morning. He heard the faint sound of tree
branches moving in the wind. He noted the

355.text:
cloud cover. The clouds were high, though.
The air at ground level was perfectly transparent.

363.text:
He turned his head and saw a prospect that
made being in the wilderness seem entirely

368.text:
reasonable and satisfying.
Mountains reared up in every direction. A

374.text:
valley lay some thousands of feet below him,
and beyond it other valleys, and somewhere

380.text:
a stream rushed white water to an unknown
destination. Not many wake to such a scene.

388.text:
Lockley regarded it, but without full attention.
He was preoccupied with thoughts of Jill Holmes,

394.text:
and unfortunately she was engaged to marry
Vale, who was also working in the park some

400.text:
thirty miles to the northeast, near Boulder
Lake itself. Lockley didn't know him well

406.text:
since he was new in the Survey. He was up
there to the northeast with an electronic

411.text:
survey instrument like Lockley's and on the
same job. Jill had an assignment from some

418.text:
magazine or other to write an article on how
national parks are born, and she was staying

423.text:
at the construction camp to gather material.
She'd learned something from Vale and much

428.text:
from the engineers while Lockley had tried
to think of interesting facts himself. He'd

434.text:
failed. When he thought about her, he thought
about the fact that she was engaged to Vale.

440.text:
That was an unhappy thought. Then he tried
to stop thinking about her altogether. But

447.text:
his mind somehow lingered on the subject.
At ten minutes to eight Lockley began to dress,

455.text:
wilderness fashion. He began by putting on
his hat. It had lain on the pile of garments

460.text:
by his bed. Then he donned the rest of his
garments in the exact reverse of the order

465.text:
in which he'd removed them.
At 8:00 he had a small fire going. He had

472.text:
no premonition that anything out of the ordinary
was going to happen that day. This was still

478.text:
before the first Alaskan report. At 8:10 he
had bacon sizzling and a small coffeepot almost

485.text:
enveloped by the flames. Events occurred and
he knew nothing at all about them. For example,

493.text:
the Military Information Center had been warned
of what was later privately called Operation

498.text:
Terror while Lockley was still tranquilly
cooking breakfast and thinking--frowning a

504.text:
little--about Jill.
Naturally he knew nothing of emergency orders

509.text:
sending all planes aloft. He wasn't informed
about something reported in space and apparently

515.text:
headed for an impact point at Boulder Lake.
As the computed impact time arrived, Lockley

523.text:
obliviously dumped coffee into his tin coffeepot
and put it back on the flames.

529.text:
At 8:13 instead of 8:14--this information
is from the tape records--there was an extremely

535.text:
small earth shock recorded by the Berkeley,
California, seismograph. It was a very minor

542.text:
shock, about the intensity of the explosion
of a hundred tons of high explosive a very

548.text:
long distance away and barely strong enough
to record its location, which was Boulder

553.text:
Lake. The cause of that explosion or shock
was not observed visually. There'd been no

560.text:
time to alert observers, and in any case the
object should have been out of atmosphere

565.text:
until the last few seconds of its fall, and
where it was reported to fall the cloud cover

571.text:
was unbroken. So nobody reported seeing it.
Not at once, anyhow, and then only one man.

580.text:
Lockley did not feel the impact. He was drinking
a cup of coffee and thinking about his own

586.text:
problems. But a delicately balanced rock a
hundred yards below his camp site toppled

591.text:
over and slid downhill. It started a miniature
avalanche of stones and rocks. The loose stuff

598.text:
did not travel far, but the original balanced
rock bounced and rolled for some distance

604.text:
before it came to rest.
Echoes rolled between the hillsides, but they

610.text:
were not very loud and they soon ended. Lockley
guessed automatically at half a dozen possible

617.text:
causes for the small rock-slide, but he did
not think at all of an unperceived temblor

622.text:
from a shock like high explosives going off
thirty miles away.

627.text:
Eight minutes later he heard a deep-toned
roaring noise to the northeast. It was unbelievably

634.text:
low-pitched. It rolled and reverberated beyond
the horizon. The detonation of a hundred tons

641.text:
of high explosives or an equivalent impact
can be heard for thirty miles, but at that

647.text:
distance it doesn't sound much like an explosion.
He finished his breakfast without enjoyment.

654.text:
By that time well over three-quarters of the
Air Force on the Pacific Coast was airborne

659.text:
and more planes shot skyward instant after
instant. Inevitably the multiplied air traffic

666.text:
was noted by civilians. Reporters began to
telephone airbases to ask whether a practice

672.text:
alert was on, or something more serious.
Such questions were natural, these days. All

680.text:
the world had the jitters. To the ordinary
observer, the prospects looked bad for everything

686.text:
but disaster. There was a crisis in the United
Nations, which had been reorganized once and

692.text:
might need to be shuffled again. There was
a dispute between the United States and Russia

697.text:
over satellites recently placed in orbit.
They were suspected of carrying fusion bombs

703.text:
ready to dive at selected targets on signal.
The Russians accused the Americans, and the

709.text:
Americans accused the Russians, and both may
have been right.

714.text:
The world had been so edgy for so long that
there were fallout shelters from Chillicothe,

720.text:
Ohio, to Singapore, Malaya, and back again.
There were permanent trouble spots at various

726.text:
places where practically anything was likely
to happen at any instant. The people of every

732.text:
nation were jumpy. There was constant pressure
on governments and on political parties so

737.text:
that all governments looked shaky and all
parties helpless. Nobody could look forward

742.text:
to a peaceful old age, and most hardly hoped
to reach middle age. The arrival of an object

749.text:
from outer space was nicely calculated to
blow the emotional fuses of whole populations.

757.text:
But Lockley ate his breakfast without premonitions.
Breezes blew and from every airbase along

764.text:
the coast fighting planes shot into the air
and into formations designed to intercept

769.text:
anything that flew on wings or to launch atom-headed
rockets at anything their radars could detect

776.text:
that didn't.
At eight-twenty, Lockley went to the electronic

780.text:
base line instrument which he was to use this
morning. It was a modification of the devices

786.text:
used to clock artificial satellites in their
orbits and measure their distance within inches

791.text:
from hundreds of miles away. The purpose was
to make a really accurate map of the park.

798.text:
There were other instruments in other line-of-sight
positions, very far away. Lockley's schedule

804.text:
called for them to measure their distances
from each other some time this morning. Two

810.text:
were carefully placed on bench marks of the
continental grid. In twenty minutes or so

815.text:
of cooperation, the distances of six such
instruments could be measured with astonishing

820.text:
precision and tied in to the bench marks already
scattered over the continent. Presently photographing

827.text:
planes would fly overhead, taking overlapping
pictures from thirty thousand feet. They would

833.text:
show the survey points and the measurements
between them would be exact, the photos could

838.text:
be used as stereo-pairs to take off contour
lines, and in a few days there would be a

844.text:
map--a veritable cartographer's dream for
accuracy and detail.

850.text:
That was the intention. But though Lockley
hadn't heard of it yet, something was reported

855.text:
to have landed from space, and a shock like
an impact was recorded, and all conditions

861.text:
would shortly be changed. It would be noted
from the beginning, however, that an impact

868.text:
equal to a hundred-ton explosion was a very
small shock for the landing of a bolide. It

874.text:
would add to the plausibility of reported
deceleration, though, and would arouse acute

880.text:
suspicion. Justly so.
At 8:20, Lockley called Sattell who was southeast

886.text:
of him. The measuring instruments used microwaves
and gave readings of distance by counting

892.text:
cycles and reading phase differences. As a
matter of convenience the microwaves could

899.text:
be modulated by a microphone, so the same
instrument could be used for communication

905.text:
while measurements went on. But the microwaves
were directed in a very tight beam. The device

912.text:
had to be aimed exactly right and a suitable
reception instrument had to be at the target

917.text:
if it was to be used at all. Also, there was
no signal to call a man to listen. He had

924.text:
to be listening beforehand, and with his instrument
aimed right, too.

929.text:
So Lockley flipped the modulator switch and
turned on the instrument. He said patiently,

936.text:
"Calling Sattell. Calling Sattell. Lockley
calling Sattell."

942.text:
He repeated it some dozens of times. He was
about to give it up and call Vale instead

948.text:
when Sattell answered. He'd slept a little
later than Lockley. It was now close to nine

953.text:
o'clock. But Sattell had expected the call.
They checked the functioning of their instruments

959.text:
against each other.
"Right!" said Lockley at last. "I'll check

965.text:
with Vale and on out of the park, and then
we'll put it all together and wrap it up and

970.text:
take it home."
Sattell agreed. Lockley, rather absurdly,

976.text:
felt uncomfortable because he was going to
have to talk to Vale. He had nothing against

981.text:
the man, but Vale was, in a way, his rival
although Jill didn't know of his folly and

987.text:
Vale could hardly guess it.
He signed off to Sattell and swung the base

993.text:
line instrument to make a similar check with
Vale. It was now ten minutes after nine. He

999.text:
aligned the instrument accurately, flipped
the switch, and began to say as patiently

1004.text:
as before, "Calling Vale. Calling Vale. Lockley
calling Vale. Over."

1011.text:
He turned the control for reception. Vale's
voice came instantly, scratchy and hoarse

1016.text:
and frantic.
"Lockley! Listen to me! There's no time to

1021.text:
tell me anything. I've got to tell you. Something
came down out of the sky here nearly an hour

1026.text:
ago. It landed in Boulder Lake, and at the
last instant there was a terrific explosion

1032.text:
and a monstrous wave swept up the shores of
the lake. The thing that came down vanished

1037.text:
under water. I saw it, Lockley!"
Lockley blinked. "Wha-a-at?"

1043.text:
"A thing came down out of the sky!" panted
Vale. "It landed in the lake with a terrific

1049.text:
explosion. It went under. Then it came up
to the surface minutes later. It floated.

1055.text:
It stuck things up and out of itself, pipes
or wires. Then it moved around the lake and

1062.text:
came in to the shore. A thing like a hatch
opened and ... creatures got out of it. Not

1075.text:
"Dammit, listen!" said Vale shrilly, "I'm
telling you what I've seen. Things out of

1082.text:
the sky. Creatures that aren't men. They landed
and set up something on the shore. I don't

1090.text:
know what it is. Do you understand? The thing
is down there in the lake now. Floating. I

1096.text:
can see it!"
Lockley swallowed. He couldn't believe this

1101.text:
immediately. He knew nothing of radar reports
or the seismograph record. He'd seen a barely

1107.text:
balanced rock roll down the mountainside below
him, and he'd heard a growling bass rumble

1113.text:
behind the horizon, but things like that didn't
add up to a conclusion like this! His first

1119.text:
conviction was that Vale was out of his head.
"Listen," said Lockley carefully. "There's

1127.text:
a short wave set over at the construction
camp. They use it all the time for orders

1132.text:
and reports and so on. You go there and report
officially what you've seen. To the Park Service

1139.text:
first, and then try to get a connection through
to the Army."

1144.text:
Vale's voice came through again, at once raging
and despairing, "They won't believe me. They'll

1150.text:
think I'm a crackpot. You get the news to
somebody who'll investigate. I see the thing,

1156.text:
Lockley. I can see it now. At this instant.
And Jill's over at the construction camp--"

1164.text:
Lockley was unreasonably relieved. If Jill
was at the camp, at least she wasn't alone

1169.text:
with a man gone out of his mind. The reaction
was normal. Lockley had seen nothing out of

1175.text:
the ordinary, so Vale's report seemed insane.
"Listen here!" panted Vale again. "The thing

1183.text:
came down. There was a terrific explosion.
It vanished. Nothing happened for a while.

1191.text:
Then it came up and found a place where it
could come to shore. Things came out of it.

1197.text:
I can't describe them. They're motes even
in my binoculars. But they aren't human! A

1205.text:
lot of them came out. They began to land things.
Equipment. They set it up. I don't know what

1211.text:
it is. Some of them went exploring. I saw
a puff of steam where something moved. Lockley?"

1217.text:
"I'm listening," said Lockley. "Go on!"
"Report this!" ordered Vale feverishly. "Get

1226.text:
it to Military Information in Denver, or somewhere!
The party of creatures that went off exploring

1232.text:
hasn't come back. I'm watching. I'll report
whatever I see. Get this to the government.

1238.text:
This is real. I can't believe it, but I see
it. Report it, quick!"

1245.text:
His voice stopped. Lockley painfully realigned
the instrument again for Sattell, thirty miles

1250.text:
to the southeast.
Sattell surprisingly answered the first call.

1256.text:
He said in an astonished voice, "Hello! I
just got a call from Survey. It seems that

1263.text:
the Army knew there was a Survey team in here,
and they called to say that radars had spotted

1268.text:
something coming down from space, right after
eight o'clock. They wanted to know if any

1274.text:
of us supposedly sane observers noticed anything
peculiar about that time."

1280.text:
Lockley's scalp crawled suddenly. Vale's report
had disturbed him, but more for the man's

1286.text:
sanity than anything else. But it could be
true! And instantly he remembered that Jill

1293.text:
was very near the place where frighteningly
impossible things were happening.

1298.text:
"Vale just told me," said Lockley, his voice
unsteady, "that he saw something come down.

1306.text:
His story was so wild I didn't believe it.
But you pass it on and say that Vale's watching

1311.text:
it. He's waiting for instructions. He'll report
everything he sees. I'm thirty miles from

1318.text:
him, but he can see the thing that came down.
Maybe the creatures in it can see him. Listen!"

1325.text:
He repeated just what Vale had told him. Somehow,
telling it to someone else, it seemed at once

1332.text:
even less real but more horrifying as a possible
danger to Jill. It didn't strike him forcibly

1339.text:
that other people were endangered, too.
When Sattell signed off to forward the report,

1346.text:
Lockley found himself sweating a little. Something
had come down out of space. The fact seemed

1353.text:
to him dangerous and appalling. His mind revolted
at the idea of non-human creatures who could

1360.text:
build ships and travel through space, but
radars had reported the arrival of a ship,

1367.text:
and there were official inquiries that nearly
matched Vale's account, which was therefore

1373.text:
not a mere crackpot claim to have seen the
incredible. Something had happened and more

1380.text:
was likely to, and Jill was in the middle
of it.

1384.text:
He swung the instrument back to Vale's position.
His hands shook, though a part of his mind

1390.text:
insisted obstinately that alarms were commonplace
these days, and in common sense one had to

1396.text:
treat them as false cries of "Wolf!" But one
knew that some day the wolf might really come.

1404.text:
Perhaps it had....
Lockley found it difficult to align the carrier

1409.text:
beam to Vale's exact location. He assured
himself that he was a fool to be afraid; that

1416.text:
if disaster were to come it would be by the
imbecilities of men rather than through creatures

1422.text:
from beyond the stars. And therefore....
But there were other men at other places who

1429.text:
felt less skepticism. The report from Vale
went to the Military Information Center and

1436.text:
thence to the Pentagon. Meanwhile the Information
Center ordered a photo-reconnaissance plane

1443.text:
to photograph Boulder Lake from aloft. In
the Pentagon, hastily alerted staff officers

1449.text:
began to draft orders to be issued if the
report of two radars and one eye-witness should

1455.text:
be further substantiated. There were such-and-such
trucks available here, and such-and-such troops

1463.text:
available there. Complicated paper work was
involved in the organization of any movement

1468.text:
of troops, but especially to carry out a plan
not at all usual in the United States.

1474.text:
Everything, though, depended on what the reconnaissance
plane photographs might show.

1480.text:
Lockley did not see the plane nor consciously
hear it. There was the faintest of murmuring

1486.text:
noises in the sky. It moved swiftly toward
the north, tending eastward. The plane that

1493.text:
made the noise was invisible. It flew above
the cloud cover which still blotted out nearly

1498.text:
all the blue overhead. It went on and on and
presently died out beyond the mountains toward

1505.text:
Boulder Lake.
Lockley tried to get Vale back, to tell him

1510.text:
that radars had verified his report and that
it would be acted on by the military. But

1515.text:
though he called and called, there was no
answer.

1519.text:
An agonizingly long time later the faint and
disregarded sound of the plane swept back

1525.text:
across the heavens. Lockley still did not
notice it. He was too busy with his attempts

1532.text:
to reach Vale again, and with grisly imaginings
of what might be done by aliens from another

1538.text:
world when they found the workmen near the
lake--and Jill among them. He pictured alien

1545.text:
monsters committing atrocities in what they
might consider scientific examination of terrestrial

1552.text:
fauna. But somehow even that was less horrible
than the images that followed an assumption

1559.text:
that the occupants of the spaceship might
be men.

1564.text:
"Calling Vale ... Vale, come in!" He fiercely
repeated the call into the instrument's microphone.

1571.text:
"Lockley calling Vale! Come in, man! Come
in!"

1575.text:
He flipped the switch and listened. And Vale's
voice came.

1579.text:
"I'm here." The voice shook. "I've been trying
to find where that exploring party went."

1587.text:
Lockley threw the speech switch and said sharply,
"The Army asked Survey if any of us had seen

1592.text:
anything come down from the sky. I gave Sattell
your report to be forwarded. It's gone to

1598.text:
the Pentagon now. Two radars reported tracking
the thing down to a landing near you. Now

1604.text:
listen! You go to the construction camp. Most
likely they'll get orders to clear out, by

1609.text:
short wave. But you go there! Make sure Jill's
all right. See her to safety."

1615.text:
The switch once more. Vale's voice was desperate.
"A ... while ago a party of the creatures

1623.text:
started away from the lake. An exploring party,
I think. Once I saw a puff of steam as if

1631.text:
they'd used a weapon. I'm afraid they may
find the construction camp, and Jill...."

1637.text:
Lockley ground his teeth. Vale said unsteadily,
"I ... can't find where they went.... A little

1645.text:
while ago their ship backed out into the lake
and sank. Deliberately! I don't know why.

1652.text:
But there's a party of those ... creatures
out exploring! I don't know what they'll do...."

1660.text:
Lockley said savagely, "Get to the camp and
look after Jill! The workmen may have panicked.

1667.text:
The Army'll know by this time what's happened.
They'll send copters to get you out. They'll

1672.text:
send help of some sort, somehow. But you look
after Jill!"

1677.text:
Vale's voice changed.
"Wait. I heard something. Wait!"

1683.text:
Silence. Around Lockley there were the usual
sounds of the wilderness. Insects made chirping

1690.text:
noises. Birds called. There were those small
whispering and rustling and high-pitched sounds

1696.text:
which in the wild constitute stillness.
A scraping sound from the speaker. Vale's

1703.text:
voice, frantic.
"That ... exploring party. It's here! They

1708.text:
must have picked up our beams. They're looking
for me. They've sighted me! They're coming...."

1714.text:
There was a crashing sound as if Vale had
dropped the communicator. There were pantings,

1720.text:
and the sound of blows, and gasped profanity--horror-filled
profanity--in Vale's voice. Then something

1729.text:
roared.
Lockley listened, his hands clenched in fury

1733.text:
at his own helplessness. He thought he heard
movements. Once he was sure he heard a sound

1739.text:
like the unshod hoof of an animal on bare

1755.text:
querulous. Then something pounded the communicator

1764.text:
Almost calmly Lockley swung his instrument

1770.text:
He called in a steady voice until Sattell
answered. He reported with meticulous care

1776.text:
just what Vale had said, and what he'd heard

1784.text:
the sound of blows and gasps, then the squeakings

1790.text:
for the measurement of base lines for an accurate

1795.text:
Sattell grew agitated. At Lockley's insistence,
he wrote down every word. Then he said nervously

1803.text:
that orders had come from Survey. The Army

1810.text:
Vale was to have been ordered out. The workmen
were ordered out. Lockley was to get out of

1816.text:
the area as soon as possible.
When Sattell signed off, Lockley switched

1821.text:
off the communicator. He put it where it would
be relatively safe from the weather. He abandoned

1827.text:
his camping equipment. A mile downhill and
four miles west there was a highway leading

1833.text:
to Boulder Lake. When the Park was opened
to the public it would be well used, but the

1839.text:
last traffic he'd seen was the big trailer-truck
of the Wild Life Control service. That huge

1845.text:
vehicle had gone up to Boulder Lake the day
before.

1850.text:
He made his way to the highway, following
a footpath to the spot where he'd left his

1854.text:
own car parked. He got into it and started
the motor. He moved with a certain dogged

1861.text:
deliberation. He knew, of course, that what
he was going to do was useless. It was hopeless.

1868.text:
It was possibly suicidal. But he went ahead.
He headed northward, pushing the little car

1876.text:
to its top speed. This was not following his
instructions. He wasn't leaving the Park area.

1884.text:
He was heading for Boulder Lake. Jill was
there and he would feel ashamed for all time

1891.text:
if he acted like a sensible man and got to
safety as he was ordered.

1897.text:
Miles along the highway, something occurred
to him. The base line instrument had to be

1902.text:
aimed exactly right for Vale or Sattell to
pick up his voice as carried by its beam.

1910.text:
Vale's or Sattell's instruments had to be
aimed as accurately to convey their voices

1915.text:
to him. Yet after the struggle he'd overheard,
and after Vale had been either subdued or

1922.text:
killed, someone or something seemed to have
picked up the communicator, and Lockley had

1929.text:
heard squeakings, and then he had heard the
instrument smashed.

1936.text:
It was not easy to understand how the beam
had been kept perfectly aligned while it was

1942.text:
picked up and squeaked at. Still less was
it understandable that it remained aimed just

1948.text:
right so he could hear when it was flung down
and crushed.

1953.text:
But somehow this oddity did not change his
feelings. Jill could be in danger from creatures

1961.text:
Vale said were not human. Lockley didn't wholly
accept that non-human angle, but something

1968.text:
was happening there and Jill was in the middle
of it. So he went to see about it for the

1975.text:
sake of his self-respect. And Jill. It was
not reasonable behavior. It was emotional.

1984.text:
He didn't stop to question what was believable
and what wasn't. Lockley didn't even give

1990.text:
any attention to the problem of how a microwave
beam could stay pointed exactly right while

1996.text:
the instrument that sent it was picked up,
and squeaked at, and smashed. He gave that

2002.text:
particular matter no thought at all.
He jammed down the accelerator of the car

2008.text:
and headed for Boulder Lake.

2014.text:
The car was ordinary enough; it was one of
those scaled-down vehicles which burn less

2020.text:
fuel and offer less comfort than the so-called
standard models. For fuel economy too, its

2026.text:
speed had been lowered. But Lockley sent it
up the brand-new highway as fast as it would

2031.text:
go.
Now the highway followed a broad valley with

2035.text:
a meadow-like floor. Now it seemed to pick
its way between cliffs, and on occasion it

2041.text:
ran over a concrete bridge spanning some swiftly
flowing stream. At least once it went through

2048.text:
a cut which might as well have been a tunnel,
and the crackling noise of its motor echoed

2054.text:
back from stony walls on either side.
He did not see another vehicle for a long

2059.text:
way. Deer, he saw twice. Over and over again
coveys of small birds rocketed up from beside

2067.text:
the road and dived to cover after he had passed.
Once he saw movement out of the corner of

2073.text:
his eye and looked automatically to see what
it was, but saw nothing. Which meant that

2079.text:
it was probably a mountain lion, blending
perfectly with its background as it watched

2084.text:
the car. At the end of five miles he saw a
motor truck, empty, trundling away from Boulder

2091.text:
Lake and the construction camp toward the
outer world.

2095.text:
The two vehicles passed, combining to make
a momentary roaring noise at their nearest.

2101.text:
The truck was not in a hurry. It simply lumbered
along with loose objects in its cargo space

2106.text:
rattling and bumping loudly. Its driver and
his helper plainly knew nothing of untoward

2112.text:
events behind them. They'd probably stopped
somewhere to have a leisurely morning snack,

2118.text:
with the truck waiting for them at the roadside.

2124.text:
the distances added by curves in the road.
He tended to fume when his underpowered car

2130.text:
noticeably slowed up on grades, and especially
the long ones. He saw a bear halfway up a

2137.text:
hillside pause in its exploitation of a berry
patch to watch the car go by below it. He

2144.text:
saw more deer. Once a smaller animal, probably
a coyote, dived into a patch of brushwood

2150.text:
and stayed hidden as long as the car remained
in sight.

2155.text:
More miles of empty highway. And then a long,
straight stretch of road, and he suddenly

2160.text:
saw vehicles coming around the curve at the
end of it. They were not in line, singlelane,

2165.text:
as traffic usually is on a curve. Both lanes
were filled. The road was blocked by motor-driven

2172.text:
traffic heading away from the lake, and not
at a steady pace, but in headlong flight.

2179.text:
It roared on toward Lockley. Big trucks and
little ones; passenger cars in between them;

2185.text:
a few motorcyclists catching up from the rear
by riding on the road's shoulders. They were

2191.text:
closely packed, as if by some freak the lead
had been taken by great trucks incapable of

2197.text:
the road speed of those behind them, yet with
the frantic rearmost cars unable to pass.

2204.text:
There was a humming and roaring of motors
that filled the air. They plunged toward Lockley's

2210.text:
miniature roadster. Truck horns blared.
Lockley got off the highway and onto the right-hand

2216.text:
shoulder. He stopped. The crowded mass of
rushing vehicles roared up to him and went

2222.text:
past. They were more remarkable than he'd
believed. There were dirt mover trucks. There

2229.text:
were truck-and-trailer combinations. There
were sedans and dump trucks and even a convertible

2234.text:
or two, and then more trucks--even tank trucks--and
more sedans and half-tonners--a complete and

2242.text:
motley collection of every kind of gasoline-driven
vehicle that could be driven on a highway

2248.text:
and used on a construction project.
And every one was crowded with men. Trailer-trucks

2255.text:
had their body doors open, and they were packed
with the workmen of the construction camp

2260.text:
near Boulder Lake. The sedans were jammed
with passengers. Dirt mover trucks had men

2266.text:
holding fast to handholds, and there were
men in the backs of the dump trucks. The racing

2272.text:
traffic filled the highway from edge to edge.
It rushed past, giving off a deafening roar

2278.text:
and clouds of gasoline fumes.
They were gone, the solid mass of them at

2283.text:
any rate. But now there came older cars, no
less crowded, and then more spacious cars,

2290.text:
not crowded so much and less frantically pushing
at those ahead. But even these cars passed

2297.text:
each other recklessly. There seemed to be
an almost hysterical fear of being last.

2304.text:
One car swung off to its left. There were
five men in it. It braked and stopped on the

2309.text:
shoulder close to Lockley's car. The driver
shouted above the din of passing motors, "You

2315.text:
don't want to go up there. Everybody's ordered
out. Everybody get away from Boulder Lake!

2321.text:
When you get the chance, turn around and get
the hell away."

2325.text:
He watched for a chance to get back on the
road, having delivered his warning. Lockley

2329.text:
got out of his car and went over, "You're
talking about the thing that came down from

2335.text:
the sky," he said grimly. "There was a girl
up at the camp. Jill Holmes. Writing a piece

2342.text:
about building a national park. Getting information
about the job. Did anybody get her away?"

2349.text:
The man who'd warned him continued to watch
for a reasonable gap in the flood of racing

2355.text:
cars. They weren't crowded now as they had
been, but it was still impossible to start

2359.text:
in low and get back in the stream of vehicles
without an almost certain crash. Then he turned

2365.text:
his head back, staring at Lockley.
"Hell! Somebody told me to check on her. I

2372.text:
was routing men out and loading 'em on whatever
came by. I forgot!"

2378.text:
A man in the back of the sedan said, "She
hadn't left when we did. I saw her. But I

2383.text:
thought she had a ride all set."
The man at the wheel said furiously, "She

2388.text:
hasn't passed us! Unless she's in one of these...."
Lockley set his teeth. He watched each oncoming

2396.text:
car intently. A girl among these fugitives
would have been put with the driver in the

2401.text:
cab of a truck, and he'd have seen a woman
in any of the private cars.

2406.text:
"If I don't see her go by," he said grimly,
"I'll go up to the camp and see if she's still

2413.text:
there."
The man in the driver's seat looked relieved.

2417.text:
"If she's left behind, it's her fault. If
you hunt for her, make it fast and be plenty

2424.text:
careful. Keep to the camp and stay away from
the lake. There was a hell of an explosion

2429.text:
over there this morning. Three men went to
see what'd happened. They didn't come back.

2435.text:
Two more went after 'em, and something hit
them on the way. They smelled something worse

2441.text:
than skunk. Then they were paralyzed, like
they had hold of a high-tension line. They

2447.text:
saw crazy colors and heard crazy sounds and
they couldn't move a finger. Their car ditched.

2455.text:
In a while they came out of it and they came
back--fast! They'd just got back when we got

2461.text:
short wave orders for everybody to get out.
If you look for that girl, be careful. If

2467.text:
she's still there, you get her out quick!"
Then he said sharply, "Here's a chance for

2473.text:
us to get going. Move out of the way!"
There was a gap in the now diminishing spate

2478.text:
of cars. The driver of the stopped car drove
furiously onto the highway. He shifted gears

2484.text:
and accelerated at the top of his car's power.
Another car behind him braked and barely avoided

2490.text:
a crash while blowing its horn furiously.
Then the traffic went on. But it was lessening

2498.text:
now. It was mostly private cars, owned by
the workmen.

2503.text:
Suddenly there were no cars coming down the
long straight stretch of road. Lockley got

2508.text:
back on the highway and resumed his rush toward
the spot the others fled from. He heard behind

2513.text:
him the diminishing rumble and roar of the
fugitive motors. He jammed his own accelerator

2519.text:
down to the floor and plunged on.
There'd been an explosion by the lake, the

2524.text:
man who'd warned him said. That checked. Three
men went to see what had happened. That was

2531.text:
reasonable. They didn't come back. Considering
what Vale had reported, it was almost inevitable.

2538.text:
Then two other men went to find out what happened
to the first three and--that was news! A smell

2545.text:
that was worse than skunk. Paralysis in a
moving car, which ditched. Remaining paralyzed

2552.text:
while seeing crazy colors and hearing crazy
sounds.... Lockley could not even guess at

2559.text:
an explanation. But the men had remained paralyzed
for some time, and then the sensations lifted.

2567.text:
They had fled back to the construction camp,
evidently fearing that the paralysis might

2572.text:
return. Their narrative must have been hair-raising,
because when orders had come for the evacuation

2578.text:
of the camp, they had been obeyed with a promptitude
suggesting panic. But apparently nothing else

2585.text:
had happened.
The first three men were still missing--or

2589.text:
at least there'd been no mention of their
return. They'd either been killed or taken

2594.text:
captive, judging by Vale's account and obvious
experience. He was either killed or captured,

2600.text:
too, but it still seemed strange that Lockley
had heard so much of that struggle via a tight

2607.text:
beam microwave transmitter that needed to
be accurately aimed. Vale had been captured

2613.text:
or killed. The three other men missing probably
had undergone the same fate. The two others

2620.text:
had been made helpless but not murdered or
taken prisoner. They'd simply been held until

2626.text:
when they were released they'd flee.
The car went over a bridge and rounded a curve.

2632.text:
Here a deep cut had been made and the road
ran through it. It came out upon undulating

2638.text:
ground where many curves were necessary.
Another car came, plunging after the others.

2645.text:
In the next ten miles there were, perhaps
a dozen more. They'd been hard to start, perhaps,

2651.text:
and so left later than the rest. Jill wasn't
in any of them. There was one car traveling

2657.text:
slowly, making thumping noises. Its driver
made the best time he could, following the

2663.text:
others.
Sober common sense pointed out that Vale's

2667.text:
account was fully verified. There'd been a
landing of non-human creatures in a ship from

2673.text:
outer space. The killing or capture of the
first three men to investigate a gigantic

2679.text:
explosion was natural enough--the alien occupants
of a space ship would want to study the inhabitants

2685.text:
of the world they'd landed on. The mere paralysis
and release of two others could be explained

2691.text:
on the theory that the creatures who'd come
to earth were satisfied with three specimens

2696.text:
of the local intelligent race to study. They
had Vale, too. They weren't trying to conceal

2702.text:
their arrival, though it would have been impossible
anyhow. But it was plausible enough that they'd

2708.text:
take measures to become informed about the
world they'd landed on, and when they considered

2713.text:
that they knew enough, they'd take the action
they felt was desirable.

2718.text:
All of which was perfectly rational, but there
was another possibility. The other possible

2723.text:
explanation was--considering everything--more
probable. And it seemed to offer even more

2730.text:
appalling prospects.
He drove on. Jill Holmes. He'd seen her four

2736.text:
times; she was engaged to Vale. It seemed
extremely likely that she hadn't left the

2742.text:
camp with the workmen. If Lockley hadn't been
obsessed with her, he'd have tried to make

2747.text:
sure she was left behind before he tried to
find her. If she was still at the camp, she

2753.text:
was in a dangerous situation.
There'd been no other car from the camp for

2758.text:
a long way now. But there came a sharp curve
ahead. Lockley drove into it. There was a

2765.text:
roar, and a car came from the opposite direction,
veering away from the road's edge. It sideswiped

2771.text:
the little car Lockley drove. The smaller
car bucked violently and spun crazily around.

2778.text:
It went crashing into a clump of saplings
and came to a stop with a smashed windshield

2783.text:
and crumpled fenders, but the motor was still
running. Lockley had braked by instinct.

2789.text:
The other car raced away without pausing.
Lockley sat still for a moment, stunned by

2795.text:
the suddenness of the mishap. Then he raged.
He got out of the car. Because of its small

2803.text:
size, he thought he might be able to get it
back on the road with saplings for levers.

2808.text:
But the job would take hours, and he was irrationally
convinced that Jill had been left behind in

2813.text:
the construction camp.
He was perhaps five miles from Boulder Lake

2818.text:
itself and about the same distance from the
camp. It would take less time to go to the

2823.text:
camp on foot than to try to get the car on
the road. Time was of the essence, and whoever

2830.text:
or whatever the occupants of the landed ship
might be, they'd know what a road was for.

2835.text:
They'd sight an intruder in a car on a road
long before they'd detect a man on foot who

2841.text:
was not on a highway and was taking some pains
to pass unseen.

2846.text:
He started out, unarmed and on foot. He was
headed for the near neighborhood of the thing

2851.text:
Vale had described as coming from the sky.
He was driven by fear for Jill. It seemed

2855.text:
to him that his best pace was only a crawl
and he desperately needed all the speed he

2861.text:
could muster.
He headed directly across country for the

2865.text:
camp. All the world seemed unaware that anything
out of the ordinary was in progress. Birds

2871.text:
sang and insects chirruped and breezes blew
and foliage waved languidly. Now and again

2879.text:
a rabbit popped out of sight of the moving
figure of the man. But there were no sounds,

2884.text:
or sights or indications of anything untoward
where Lockley moved. He reflected that he

2890.text:
was on his way to search for a girl he barely
knew, and whom he couldn't be sure needed

2896.text:
his help anyway.
Outside in the world, there were places where

2900.text:
things were not so tranquil. By this time
there were already troops in motion in long

2906.text:
trains of personnel-carrying trucks. There
were mobile guided missile detachments moving

2911.text:
at top speed across state lines and along
the express highway systems. Every military

2918.text:
plane in the coastal area was aloft, kept
fueled by tanker planes to be ready for any

2924.text:
sort of offensive or defensive action that
might be called for. The short wave instructions

2930.text:
to the construction camp had become known,
and all the world knew that Boulder Lake National

2936.text:
Park had been evacuated to avoid contact with
non-human aliens. The aliens were reported

2944.text:
to have hunted men down and killed them for
sport. They were reported to have paralysis

2950.text:
beams, death beams and poison gas. They were
described as indescribable, and described

2958.text:
in "artist's conceptions" on television and
in the newspapers. They appeared--according

2965.text:
to circumstances--to resemble lizards or slugs.
They were portrayed as carnivorous birds and

2970.text:
octopods. The artists took full advantage
of their temporarily greater importance than

2976.text:
cameramen. They pictured these diverse aliens
in their one known aggressive action of trailing

2983.text:
Vale down and carrying him away. This was
said to be for vivisection. None of the artists'

2990.text:
ideas were even faintly plausible, biologically.

2996.text:
heat rays upon humans, who dramatically burst
into steam as the beams struck them. Obviously,

3004.text:
there were also artist's conceptions of women
being seized by the creatures from outer space.

3009.text:
There was only one woman known to be in the
construction camp, but that inconvenient fact

3014.text:
didn't bother the artists.
The United States went into a mild panic.

3020.text:
But most people stayed on their jobs, and
followed their normal routine, and the trains

3025.text:
ran on time.

3029.text:
used to newspaper and broadcast scares. They
were unconsciously relegated to the same category

3035.text:
as horror movies, which some day might come
true, but not yet. This particular news story

3043.text:
seemed more frightening than most, but still
it was taken more or less as shuddery entertainment.

3050.text:
So most of the United States shivered with
a certain amount of relish as ever new and

3057.text:
ever more imaginative accounts appeared describing
the landing of intelligent monsters, and waited

3063.text:
to see if it was really true. The truth was
that most of America didn't actually believe

3069.text:
it. It was like a Russian threat. It could
happen and it might happen, but it hadn't

3077.text:
happened so far to the United States.
An official announcement helped to guide public

3083.text:
opinion in this safe channel. The Defense
Department released a bulletin: An object

3089.text:
had fallen from space into Boulder Lake, Colorado.
It was apparently a large meteorite. When

3096.text:
reported by radar before its landing, defense
authorities had seized the opportunity to

3101.text:
use it for a test of emergency response to
a grave alarm. They had used it to trigger

3107.text:
a training program and test of defensive measures
made ready against other possible enemies.

3115.text:
