were continued as a more complete test of

3120.text:
the nation's fighting forces' responsive ability.
The object and its landing, however, were

3126.text:
being investigated.
Lockley tramped up hillsides and scrambled

3131.text:
down steep slopes with many boulders scattered
here and there. He moved through a landscape

3136.text:
in which nothing seemed to depart from the
normal. The sun shone. The cloud cover, broken

3142.text:
some time since, was dissipating and now a
good two-thirds of the sky was wholly clear.

3149.text:
The sounds of the wilderness went on all around
him.

3153.text:
But presently he came to a partly-graded new
road, cutting across his way. A bulldozer

3159.text:
stood abandoned on it, brand-new and in perfect
order, with the smell of gasoline and oil

3165.text:
about it. He followed the gash in the forest
it had begun. It led toward the camp. He came

3173.text:
to a place where blasting had been in progress.
The equipment for blasting remained. But there

3179.text:
was nobody in sight.
Half a mile from this spot, Lockley looked

3183.text:
down upon the camp. There were Quonset huts
and prefabricated structures. There were streets

3189.text:
of clay and wires from one building to another.
There was a long, low, open shed with long

3196.text:
tables under its roof. A mess shed. Next to
it metal pipes pierced another roof, and wavering

3203.text:
columns of heated air rose from those pipes.
There was a building which would be a commissary.

3209.text:
There was every kind of structure needed for
a small city, though all were temporary. And

3216.text:
there was no movement, no sound, no sign of
life except the hot air rising from the mess

3222.text:
kitchen stovepipes.
Lockley went down into the camp. All was silence.

3229.text:
All was lifeless. He looked unhappily about
him. There would be no point, of course, in

3235.text:
looking into the dormitories, but he made
his way to the mess shed. Some heavy earthenware

3240.text:
plates and coffee cups, soiled, remained on
the table. There were a few flies. Not many.

3248.text:
In the mess kitchen there was grayish smoke
and the reek of scorched and ruined food.

3254.text:
The stoves still burned. Lockley saw the blue
flame of bottled gas. He went on. The door

3262.text:
of the commissary was open. Everything men
might want to buy in such a place waited for

3267.text:
purchasers, but there was no one to buy or
sell.

3271.text:
The stillness and desolation of the place
resulted from less than an hour's abandonment.

3277.text:
But somehow it was impossible to call out
loudly for Jill. Lockley was appalled by the

3282.text:
feeling of emptiness in such bright sunshine.
It was shocking. Men hadn't moved out of the

3289.text:
camp. They'd simply left it, with every article
of use dropped and abandoned; nothing at all

3296.text:
had been removed. And there was no sign of
Jill. It occurred to Lockley that she'd have

3302.text:
waited for Vale at the camp, because assuredly
his first thought should have been for her

3307.text:
safety. Yes. She'd have waited for Vale to
rescue her. But Vale was either dead or a

3314.text:
captive of the creatures that had been in
the object from the sky. He wouldn't be looking

3319.text:
after Jill.
Lockley found himself straining his eyes at

3323.text:
the mountain from whose flank Vale had been
prepared to measure the base line between

3327.text:
his post and Lockley's. That vantage point
could not be seen from here, but Lockley looked

3334.text:
for a small figure that might be Jill, climbing
valiantly to warn Vale of the events he'd

3340.text:
known before anybody else.
Then Lockley heard a very small sound. It

3348.text:
was faint, with an irregular rhythm in it.
It had the cadence of speech. His pulse leaped

3355.text:
suddenly. There was the mast for the short
wave set by which the camp had kept in touch

3360.text:
with the outer world. Lockley sprinted for
the building under it. His footsteps sounded

3366.text:
loudly in the silent camp, and they drowned
out the sound he was heading for.

3371.text:
He stopped at the open door. He heard Jill's
voice saying anxiously, "But I'm sure he'd

3378.text:
have come to make certain I was safe!" A pause.
"There's no one else left, and I want...."

3386.text:
Another pause. "But he was up on the mountainside!
At least a helicopter could--"

3393.text:
Lockley called, "Jill!"
He heard a gasp. Then she said unsteadily,

3399.text:
"Someone just called. Wait a moment."
She came to the door. At sight of Lockley

3405.text:
her face fell.
"I came to make sure you were all right,"

3410.text:
he said awkwardly. "Are you talking to outside?"
"Yes. Do you know anything about--"

3417.text:
"I'm afraid I do," said Lockley. "Right now
the important thing is to get you out of here.

3425.text:
I'll tell them we're starting. All right?"
She stood aside. He went up to the short wave

3431.text:
set which looked much like an ordinary telephone,
but was connected to a box with dials and

3437.text:
switches. There was a miniature pocket radio--a
transistor radio--on top of the short wave

3443.text:
cabinet. Lockley picked up the short wave
microphone. He identified himself. He said

3450.text:
he'd come to make sure of Jill's safety, and
that he'd been passed by the rushing mass

3455.text:
of cars and trucks that had evacuated everybody
else. Then he said, "I've got a car about

3462.text:
four miles away. It's in a ditch, but I can
probably get it out. It'll be a lot safer

3468.text:
for Miss Holmes if you send a helicopter there
to pick her up."

3472.text:
The reply was somehow military in tone. It
sounded like a civilian being authoritative

3479.text:
about something he knew nothing about. Lockley
said, "Over" in a dry tone and put down the

3486.text:
microphone. He picked up the pocket radio
and put it in his pocket. It might be useful.

3493.text:
"They say to try to make it out in my car,"
he told Jill wryly. "As civilians, I suppose

3500.text:
they haven't any helicopters they can give
orders to. But it probably makes sense. If

3507.text:
there are some queer creatures around, there's
no point in stirring them up with a flying

3511.text:
contraption banging around near their landing
place. Not before we're ready to take real

3517.text:
action. Come along. I've got to get you away
from here."

3521.text:
"But I'm waiting...." She looked distressed.
"He wanted me to leave yesterday. We almost

3528.text:
quarrelled about it. He'll surely come to
make sure I'm safe...."

3532.text:
"I'm afraid I have bad news," said Lockley.
Then he described, as gently as he could,

3541.text:
his last talk with Vale. It was the one which
ended with squeaks and strugglings transmitted

3547.text:
by the communicator, and then the smashing
of the communicator itself. He didn't mention

3553.text:
the puzzling fact that the communicator had
stayed perfectly aimed while it was picked

3559.text:
up and squeaked at and destroyed. He had no
explanation for it. What he did have to tell

3565.text:
was bad enough. She went deathly pale, searching
his face as he told her.

3572.text:
"But--but--" She swallowed. "He might have
been hurt and--not killed. He might be alive

3580.text:
and in need of help. If there are creatures
from somewhere else, they might not realize

3586.text:
that he could be unconscious and not dead!
He'd make sure about me! I--I'll go up and

3593.text:
make sure about him...."
Lockley hesitated. "It's not likely," he said

3600.text:
carefully, "that he was left there injured.
But if you feel that somebody has to make

3605.text:
sure, I'll do it. For one thing, I can climb
faster. My car is ditched back yonder. You

3613.text:
go and wait by it. At least it's farther from
the lake and you should be safer there. I'll

3618.text:
make sure about Vale."
He explained in detail how she could find

3623.text:
the car. Up this hillside to a slash through
the forest for a highway. Due south from an

3629.text:
abandoned bulldozer. Keep out of sight. Never
show against a skyline.

3635.text:
She swallowed again. Then she said, "If he
needs help, you could--do more than I can.

3644.text:
But I'll wait there where the woods begin.
I can hide if I need to, and I--might be of

3650.text:
some use."
He realized that she deluded herself with

3654.text:
the hope that he, Lockley, might bring an
injured Vale down the mountainside and that

3660.text:
she could be useful then. He let her. He went
through the camp with her to put her on the

3665.text:
right track. He gave her the pocket radio,
so she could listen for news. When she went

3671.text:
on out of sight in brushwood, he turned back
toward the mountain on which Vale had occupied

3676.text:
an observation post. It was actually a million-year-old
crater wall that he climbed presently. And

3683.text:
he took a considerable chance. As he climbed,
for some time he moved in plain view. If the

3690.text:
crew of the ship in Boulder Lake were watching,
they'd see him rather than Jill. If they took

3696.text:
action, it would be against him and not Jill.
Somehow he felt better equipped to defend

3703.text:
himself than Jill would be.
He climbed. Again the world was completely

3710.text:
normal, commonplace. There were mountain peaks
on every hand. Some had been volcanoes originally,

3717.text:
some had not. With each five hundred feet
of climbing, he could see still more mountains.

3724.text:
The sky was cloudless now. He climbed a thousand
feet. Two. Three. He could see between peaks

3731.text:
for a full thirty miles to the spot where
he'd been at daybreak. But he was making his

3736.text:
ascent on the back flank of this particular
mountain. He could not see Boulder Lake from

3742.text:
there. On the other hand, no creature at Boulder
Lake should be able to see him. Only an exploring

3749.text:
party which might otherwise sight Jill would
be apt to detect him, a slowly moving speck

3755.text:
against a mountainside.
He reached the level at which Vale's post

3759.text:
had been assigned. He moved carefully and
cautiously around intervening masses of stone.

3766.text:
The wind blew past him, making humming noises
in his ears. Once he dislodged a small stone

3773.text:
and it went bouncing and clattering down the
slope he'd climbed.

3777.text:
He saw where Vale could have been as he watched
something come down from the sky. He found

3782.text:
Vale's sleeping bag, and the ashes of his
campfire. Here too was the communicator. It

3789.text:
had been smashed by a huge stone lifted and
dropped upon it, but before that it had been

3796.text:
moved. It was not in place on the bench mark
from which it could measure inches in a distance

3801.text:
of scores of miles.
There was no other sign of what had apparently

3805.text:
happened here. The ashes of the fire were
undisturbed. Vale's sleeping bag looked as

3811.text:
if it had not been slept in, as if it had
only been spread out for the night before.

3818.text:
Lockley went over the rock shelf inch by inch.
No red stains which might be blood. Nothing....

3824.text:
No. In a patch of soft earth between two stones
there was a hoofprint. It was not a footprint.

3833.text:
A hoof had made it, but not a horse's hoof,
nor a burro's. It wasn't a mountain sheep

3840.text:
track. It was not the track of any animal
known on earth. But it was here. Lockley found

3847.text:
himself wondering absurdly if the creature
that had made it would squeak, or if it would

3854.text:
roar. They seemed equally unlikely.
He looked cautiously down at the lake which

3861.text:
was almost half a mile below him. The water
was utterly blue. It reflected only the crater

3868.text:
wall and the landscape beyond the area where
the volcanic cliffs had fallen. Nothing moved.

3875.text:
There was no visible apparatus set up on the
shore, as Vale had said. But something had

3881.text:
happened down in the lake. Trees by the water's
edge were bent and broken. Masses of brushwood

3888.text:
had been crushed and torn away. Limbs were
broken down tens of yards from the water,

3894.text:
and there were gullies to be seen wherever
there was soft earth. An enormous wave had

3899.text:
flung itself against the nearly circular boundary
of the lake. It had struck like a tidal wave

3905.text:
dozens of feet high in an inland body of water.
It was extremely convincing evidence that

3911.text:
something huge and heavy had hurtled down
from the sky.

3917.text:
But Lockley saw no movement nor any other
novelty in this wilderness. He heard nothing

3923.text:
that was not an entirely normal sound.
But then he smelled something.

3930.text:
It was a horrible, somehow reptilian odor.
It was the stench of jungle, dead and rotting.

3938.text:
It was much, much worse than the smell of
a skunk.

3942.text:
He moved to fling himself into flight. Then
light blinded him. Closing his eyelids did

3949.text:
not shut it out. There were all colors, intolerably
vivid, and they flashed in revolving combinations

3956.text:
and forms which succeeded each other in fractions
of seconds. He could see nothing but this

3963.text:
light. Then there came sound. It was raucous.
It was cacophonic. It was an utterly unorganized

3971.text:
tumult in which musical notes and discords
and bellowings and shriekings were combined

3976.text:
so as to be unbearable. And then came pure
horror as he found that he could not move.

3983.text:
Every inch of his body had turned rigid as
it became filled with anguish. He felt, all

3991.text:
over, as if he were holding a charged wire.
He knew that he fell stiffly where he stood.

3998.text:
He was blinded by light and deafened by sound
and his nostrils were filled with the nauseating

4005.text:
fetor of jungle and decay. These sensations
lasted for what seemed years.

4012.text:
Then all the sensations ended abruptly. But
he still could not see; his eyes were still

4019.text:
dazzled by the lights that closing his eyelids
had not changed. He still could not hear.

4025.text:
He'd been deafened by the sounds that had
dazed and numbed him. He moved, and he knew

4030.text:
it, but he could not feel anything. His hands
and body felt numb.

4036.text:
Then he sensed that the positions of his arms
and legs were changed. He struggled, blind

4042.text:
and deaf and without feeling anywhere. He
knew that he was confined. His arms were fastened

4048.text:
somehow so that he could not move them.
And then gradually--very gradually--his senses

4055.text:
returned. He heard squeakings. At first they
were faint as the exhausted nerve ends in

4061.text:
his ears only began to regain their function.
He began to regain the sense of touch, though

4068.text:
he felt only furriness everywhere.
He was raised up. It seemed to him that claws

4075.text:
rather than fingers grasped him. He stood
erect, swaying. His sense of balance had been

4082.text:
lost without his realizing it. It came back,
very slowly. But he saw nothing. Clawlike

4089.text:
hands--or handlike claws--pulled at him. He
felt himself turned and pushed. He staggered.

4097.text:
He took steps out of the need to stay erect.
The pushings and pullings continued. He found

4103.text:
himself urged somewhere. He realized that
his arms were useless because they were wrapped

4109.text:
with something like cord or rope.
Stumbling, he responded to the urging. There

4115.text:
was nothing else to do. He found himself descending.
He was being led somewhere which could only

4121.text:
be downward. He was guided, not gently, but
not brutally either.

4127.text:
He waited for sight to return to him. It did
not come.

4131.text:
It was then he realized that he could not
see because he was blindfolded.

4137.text:
There were whistling squeaks very near him.
He began helplessly to descend the mountain,

4143.text:
surrounded and guided and sometimes pulled
by unseen creatures.

4150.text:
CHAPTER 3
It was a long descent, made longer by the

4155.text:
blindfold and clumsier by his inability to
move his arms. More than once Lockley stumbled.

4162.text:
Twice he fell. The clawlike hands or handlike
claws lifted him and thrust him on the way

4168.text:
that was being chosen for him. There were
whistling squeaks. Presently he realized that

4174.text:
some of them were directed at him. A squeak
or whistle in a warning tone told him that

4181.text:
he must be especially careful just here.
He came to accept the warnings. It occurred

4187.text:
to him that the squeaks sounded very much
like those button-shaped hollow whistles that

4192.text:
children put in their mouths to make strident
sounds of varying pitch. Gradually, all his

4198.text:
senses returned to normal. Even his eyes under
the blindfold ceased to report only glare

4204.text:
blindness, and he saw those peculiar, dissolving
grayish patterns that human eyes transmit

4211.text:
from darkness.
More squeakings. A long time later he moved

4216.text:
over nearly level grassy ground. He was led
for possibly half a mile. He had not tried

4223.text:
to speak during all his descent. It would
have been useless. If he was to be killed,

4229.text:
he would be killed. But trouble had been taken
to bring him down alive from a remaining bit

4236.text:
of crumbling crater wall. His captors had
evidently some use for him in mind.

4242.text:
They abruptly held him still for a long time--perhaps
as much as an hour. It seemed that either

4249.text:
instructions were hard to come by, or some
preparation was being made. Then the sound

4255.text:
of something or someone approaching. Squeaks.
He was led another long distance. Then claws

4263.text:
or hands lifted him. Metal clanked. Those
who held him dropped him. He fell three or

4270.text:
four feet onto soft sand. There was a clanging
of metal above his head.

4276.text:
Then a human voice said sardonically, "Welcome
to our city! Where'd they catch you?"

4284.text:
Lockley said, "Up on a mountainside, trying
to see what they were doing. Will you get

4289.text:
me loose, please?"
Hands worked on the cord that bound his arms

4293.text:
close to his body. They loosened. He removed
the blindfold.

4298.text:
He was in a metal-walled and metal-ceilinged
vault, perhaps eight feet wide and the same

4304.text:
in height, and perhaps twelve feet long. It
had a floor of sand. Some small amount of

4310.text:
light came in through the circular hole he'd
been dropped through, despite a cover on it.

4316.text:
There were three men already in confinement
here. They wore clothing appropriate to workmen

4322.text:
from the construction camp. There was a tall
lean man, and a broad man with a moustache,

4327.text:
and a chunky man. The chunky man had spoken.
"Did you see any of 'em?" he demanded now.

4335.text:
Lockley shook his head. The three looked at
each other and nodded. Lockley saw that they

4340.text:
hadn't been imprisoned long. The sand floor
was marked but not wholly formed into footprints,

4347.text:
as it would have been had they moved restlessly
about. Mostly, it appeared, they'd simply

4352.text:
sat on the sand floor.
"We didn't see 'em either," said the chunky

4357.text:
man. "There was a hell of a explosion over
at the lake this mornin'. We piled in a car--my

4363.text:
car--and came over to see what'd happened.
Then something hit us. All of us. Lights.

4369.text:
Noise. A godawful stink. A feeling all over
like an electric shock that paralyzed us.

4376.text:
We came to blindfolded and tied. They brought
us here. That's our story so far. What's happened

4384.text:
to you--and what really happened to us?"
"I'm not sure," said Lockley.

4390.text:
He hesitated. Then he told them about Vale,
and what he'd reported. They'd had no explanation

4397.text:
at all of what had happened to them. They
seemed relieved to be informed, though the

4401.text:
information was hardly heartening.
"Critters from Mars, eh?" said the moustached

4407.text:
man. "I guess we'd act the same way if we
was to get to Mars. They got to figure out

4413.text:
some way to talk to who lives here. I guess
that makes us it--unless we can figure out

4419.text:
something better."
Lockley, by temperament, tended to anticipate

4424.text:
worse things in the future than had come in
the past. The suggestion that the occupants

4430.text:
of the spaceship had captured men to learn
how to communicate with them seemed highly

4435.text:
optimistic. He realized that he didn't believe
it. It seemed extremely unlikely that the

4442.text:
invaders from space were entirely ignorant
of humanity. The choice of Boulder Lake as

4448.text:
a landing place, for example, could not have
been made from space. If there was need for

4453.text:
deep water to land in--which seemed highly
probable--then it would have been simple good

4458.text:
sense to descend in the ocean. The ship could
submerge, and it could move about in the lake.

4465.text:
Vale had said so. Such a ship would almost
inevitably choose deep water in the ocean

4471.text:
for a landing place. To land in a crater lake--one
of possibly two or three on an entire continent

4479.text:
suitable for their use--indicated that they
had information in advance. Detailed information.

4486.text:
It practically shouted of a knowledge of at
least one human language, by which information

4492.text:
about Crater Lake could have been obtained.
Whoever or whatever made use of the lake was

4498.text:
no stranger to earth!
Yes.... They'd needed a deep-water landing

4504.text:
and they knew that Boulder Lake would do.
They probably knew very much more. But if

4510.text:
they didn't know that Jill waited for him
where the trail toward his ditched car began,

4515.text:
then there was no reason to let them overhear
the information.

4519.text:
"I was part of a team making some base line
measurements," said Lockley, "when this business

4526.text:
started. I began to check my instruments with
a man named Vale."

4530.text:
He told exactly, for the second time, what
Vale said about the thing from the sky and

4536.text:
the creatures who came out of it. Then he
told what he'd done. But he omitted all reference

4542.text:
to Jill. His coming to the lake he ascribed
to incredulity. Also, he did not mention meeting

4549.text:
the fleeing population of the construction
camp. When his story was finished he sounded

4555.text:
like a man who'd done a very foolhardy thing,
but he didn't sound like a man with a girl

4560.text:
on his mind.
The broad man with the moustache asked a question

4565.text:
or two. The tall man asked others. Lockley
asked many.

4570.text:
The answers were frustrating. They hadn't
seen their captors at all. They'd heard squeaks

4576.text:
when they were being brought to this place,
and the squeaks were obviously language, but

4581.text:
no human one. They'd been bound as well as
blindfolded. They hadn't been offered food

4587.text:
since their capture, nor water. It seemed
as if they'd been seized and put into this

4592.text:
metal compartment to wait for some use of
them by their captors.

4597.text:
"Maybe they want to teach us to talk," said
the moustached man, "or maybe they're goin'

4603.text:
to carve us up to see what makes us tick.
Or maybe," he grimaced, "maybe they want to

4610.text:
know if we're good to eat."
The chunky man said, "Why'd they blindfold

4615.text:
us?"
Lockley had begun to have a very grim suspicion

4621.text:
about this. It came out of the realization
of how remarkable it was that a ship designed

4626.text:
to be navigable in deep water should have
landed in a deep crater lake. He said, "Vale

4633.text:
said at first that they weren't human, though
they were only specks in his binoculars. Later,

4640.text:
when he saw them close, he didn't say what
they look like."

4643.text:
"Must be pretty weird," said the tall man.
"Maybe," said the man with the moustache,

4650.text:
attempting humor, "maybe they didn't want
us to see them because we'd be scared. Or

4655.text:
maybe they didn't mean to blindfold us, but
just to cover us up. Maybe they wouldn't mind

4662.text:
us seeing them, but it hurts for them to look
at us!"

4667.text:
Lockley said abruptly, "This box we're in.
It's made by humans."

4672.text:
The moustached man said quickly, "We figured
that. It's the shell of a compost pit for

4678.text:
the hotel that's goin' to be built around
here. They'll sink it in the ground and dump

4683.text:
garbage in it, and it'll rot, and then it'll
be fertilizer. These critters from space are

4689.text:
just using it to hold us. But what are they
gonna do with us?"

4695.text:
There were faint squeakings. The cover to
the round opening lifted. Three rabbits dropped

4701.text:
down. The cover closed with a clang. The rabbits
shivered and crouched, terrified, in one corner.

4708.text:
"Is this how they're gonna feed us?" demanded
the chunky man.

4713.text:
"Hell, no!" said the tall man, in evident
disgust. "They're dumped in here like we were.

4720.text:
They're animals. So are we. This is a temporary
cage. It's got a sand floor that we can bury

4727.text:
things in. It won't be any trouble to clean
out. The rabbits and us, we stay caged until

4734.text:
they're ready to do whatever they're goin'
to do with us."

4737.text:
"Which is what?" demanded the chunky man.
There was no answer. They would either be

4744.text:
killed, or they would not. There was nothing
to be done. Meanwhile Lockley evaluated his

4752.text:
three fellow captives as probably rather good
men to have on one's side, and bad ones to

4758.text:
have against one. But there was no action
which was practical now. A single guard outside,

4764.text:
able to paralyze them by whatever means it
was accomplished, made any idea of escape

4770.text:
in daylight foolish.
"What kind of critters are they?" demanded

4775.text:
the chunky man. "Maybe we could figure out
what they'll do if we know what kind of thing

4780.text:
they are!"
"They've got eyes like ours," said Lockley.

4786.text:
The three men looked at him.
"They landed by daylight," said Lockley. "Early

4792.text:
daylight. They could certainly have picked
the time for their landing. They picked early

4797.text:
morning so they could have a good long period
of daylight in which to get settled before

4802.text:
night. If they'd been night moving creatures,
they'd have landed in the dark."

4807.text:
The tall man said, "Sounds reasonable. I didn't
think of that."

4813.text:
"They saw me at a distance," said Lockley,
"and I didn't see them. They've got good eyes.

4820.text:
They beat me up to the top of the mountain
and hid to see what I'd do. When they saw

4826.text:
me looking the lake over after checking up
on Vale, they paralyzed me and brought me

4831.text:
here. So they've got eyes like ours."
"This guy Vale," said the chunky man. "What

4839.text:
happened to him?"
Lockley said, "Probably what'll happen to

4844.text:
us."
"Which is what?" asked the chunky man.

4849.text:
Lockley did not answer. He thought of Jill,
waiting anxiously at the edge of the woods

4854.text:
not far from the camp. She'd surely have watched
him climbing. She might have followed his

4860.text:
climb all the way to where he went around
to Vale's post. But she wouldn't have seen

4865.text:
his capture and she might be waiting for him
now. It wasn't likely, though, that she'd

4871.text:
climb into the trap that had taken Vale and
then himself. She must realize that that spot

4877.text:
was one to be avoided.
She'd probably try to make her way to his

4882.text:
ditched car. She'd heard him ask on short
wave for a helicopter to come to that place

4887.text:
to pick her up. It hadn't been promised; in
fact it had been refused. But if she remained

4894.text:
missing, surely someone would risk a low-level
flight to find out if she were waiting desperately

4899.text:
for rescue. A light plane could land on the
highway if a helicopter wasn't to be risked.

4906.text:
Somehow Jill must find a way to safety. She
was in danger because she'd waited loyally

4911.text:
for Vale to come to her at the camp. Now....
Time passed. Hot sunshine on their prison

4920.text:
heated the metal. It became unbearably hot
inside. There came squeakings. The cover of

4927.text:
the compost pit shell lifted. Half a dozen
wild birds were thrust into the opening. The

4933.text:
cover closed again. Lockley listened closely.
It was latched from the outside. There would

4941.text:
naturally be a fastening on the cover of a
compost pit to keep bears from getting at

4946.text:
the garbage it was built to contain.
The heat grew savage. Thirst was a problem.

4953.text:
Once and only once they heard a noise from
the world beyond their prison. It was a droning

4959.text:
hum which, even through a metal wall, could
be nothing but the sound of a helicopter.

4965.text:
It droned and droned, very gradually becoming
louder. Then, abruptly, it cut off. That was

4973.text:
all. And that was all that the four in the
metal tank knew about events outside of their

4978.text:
own experience.
But much was happening outside. Troop-carrying

4984.text:
trucks had reached the edge of Boulder Lake
National Park, a very few hours after the

4989.text:
workmen from the camp had gotten out of it.
They had a story to tell, and if it lacked

4993.text:
detail it did not lack imagination. The three
missing men had their fate described in various

5000.text:
versions, all of which were dramatic and terrifying.
The two men who had been paralyzed by some

5007.text:
unknown agency described their sensations
after their release. Their stories were immediately

5013.text:
relayed to all the news media. It now appeared
that dozens of men had seen the thing descend

5019.text:
from the sky. They had not compared notes,
however, and their descriptions varied from

5025.text:
a black pear-shaped globe which had hovered
for minutes before descending behind the mountains

5030.text:
into the lake, to detailed word pictures of
a silvery, torpedo-shaped vessel of space

5038.text:
with portholes and flaming rockets and an
unknown flag displayed from a flagstaff.

5045.text:
Of course, none of those accounts could be
right. The velocity of the falling object,

5050.text:
as reported from two radar installations,
checked against a seismograph record of the

5055.text:
time of the impact in the lake and allowed
no leeway of time for it to hover in mid-air

5060.text:
to be admired.
But there were enough detailed and first-hand

5065.text:
accounts of alarming events to make a second
statement by the Defense Department necessary.

5070.text:
It was an over-correction of the first soothing
one. It was intended to be more soothing still.

5078.text:
It said blandly that a bolide--a slow-moving,
large meteoric object--had been observed by

5085.text:
radar to be descending to earth. It had been
tracked throughout its descent. It had landed

5091.text:
in Boulder Lake. Air photos taken since its
landing showed that an enormous disturbance

5096.text:
of the water of the lake had taken place.
It had seemed wise to remove workmen from

5101.text:
the neighborhood of the meteoric fall, and
the whole occurrence had been made the occasion

5106.text:
of a full-scale practice emergency response
by air and other defense forces. Investigation

5112.text:
of the possible bolide itself was under way.
The writer of the bulletin was obviously sitting

5120.text:
on Vale's report and that of the workmen so
as to tell as little as possible and that

5126.text:
slanted to prevent alarm. The bulletin went
on to say that there was no justification

5131.text:
for the alarming reports now spreading through
the country. This happening was not--repeat,

5138.text:
was not--in any way associated with the cold
war of such long standing. It was simply a

5144.text:
very large meteor arriving from space and
very fortunately falling in a national park

5151.text:
area, and even more fortunately into a deep
crater lake so that there was no damage even

5157.text:
to the forests of the park.
The bulletin had no effect, of course. It

5162.text:
was too late. It was released at just about
the time the temperature in the metal prison--which

5168.text:
seemed likely to become a metal coffin--had
begun to fall. The moving sun had gone behind

5174.text:
a mountain and the compost pit shell was in
shadow once more.

5180.text:
Again the cover of that giant box was opened.
A porcupine was dropped inside. The cover

5186.text:
went on again. This was, at a guess, about
five o'clock in the afternoon. The chunky

5192.text:
man said drearily, "If this is supposed to
be the way they'll feed us, they coulda picked

5198.text:
something easier to eat than a porcupine!"
The box now held four men, three rabbits--panting

5204.text:
in terror in one corner--half a dozen game
birds and the just-arrived porcupine. All

5211.text:
the wild creatures shrank away from the men.
At any sudden movement the birds tended to

5217.text:
fly hysterically about in the dimness, dashing
themselves against the metal wall.

5222.text:
"I'd say," observed Lockley, "that his guess,"
he nodded at the tall man, "is the most likely

5230.text:
one. Rabbits and birds and porcupines would
be considered specimens of the local living

5237.text:
creatures. We could be considered specimens
too. Maybe we are. Maybe we're simply being

5244.text:
held caged until there's time for a scientific
examination of us. Let's hope they don't happen

5251.text:
to drop a bear down here to wait with us!"
The tall man said, "Or rattlers! I wonder

5258.text:
what time it is. I'll feel better when dark
comes. They're not so likely to find rattlers

5264.text:
in the dark."
Lockley said nothing. But if Boulder Lake

5269.text:
had been chosen for a landing place on the
basis of previously acquired information,

5274.text:
it wasn't likely that either bears or rattlesnakes
would be put in confinement with the men.

5280.text:
The men would have been killed immediately,
unless there was a practical use to be made

5284.text:
of them. He began to make guesses. He could
make a great many, but none of them added

5290.text:
up exactly right.
Only one seemed promising, and that assumed

5295.text:
a lot of items Lockley couldn't be sure of.
He did know, though, that he'd been lifted

5301.text:
up before he was dropped into the round opening
of this tank-like metal shell. The top of

5307.text:
the box was well above ground. It was not
sunk in place as it would eventually be. Evidently

5314.text:
it was not yet in its permanent position.
The light inside was dim enough, but he could

5320.text:
see the other men and the animals and the
birds. He could make out the riveted plates

5325.text:
which formed the box's sides and top.
Inconspicuously, he worked his hand down through

5332.text:
the sand bottom of the prison. Four inches
down the sand ended and there was earth. He

5338.text:
felt around. He found grass stems. The box,
then, rested on top of the ground, which was

5345.text:
perfectly natural for a compost pit shell
not yet placed where it would finally belong.

5351.text:
The sand.... He explored further.
He waited. The other three stayed quiet. The

5359.text:
faint brightness around the cover hole faded
away. The interior of the tank-like box became

5365.text:
abysmally black.
"Can anybody guess the time?" he asked, after

5371.text:
aeons seemed to have passed.
"It feels like next Thursday," said the voice

5377.text:
of the moustached man, "but it's probably
ten or eleven o'clock. Looks like we're just

5383.text:
going to be left here till they get around
to us."

5387.text:
"I think we'd better not wait," said Lockley.
"We've been pretty quiet. They probably think

5394.text:
we're well-behaved specimens of this planet's
wild life. They won't expect us to try anything

5400.text:
this late. Suppose we get out."
"How?" demanded the chunky man.

5407.text:
Lockley said carefully, "This box is resting
on top of the ground. I've dug down through

5414.text:
the sand and found the bottom edge of the
metal sidewall. If it's resting only on dirt,

5420.text:
not stone, we ought to be able to dig out
with our hands. I'll start now. You listen."

5427.text:
He began to dig with his hands, first clearing
away the sand for a reasonable space. He felt

5433.text:
a certain sardonic interest in what might
happen. He strongly suspected that nothing

5439.text:
undesirable would take place.
It was at least quaint that aliens from outer

5444.text:
space should accept a bottomless metal shell
as a suitable prison for animals. It was quaint

5451.text:
that they'd put in a sandy floor. How would
they know that such a thing meant a cage,

5457.text:
on earth?
Of course the whole event might have been

5461.text:
a test of animal intelligence. Almost any
animal would have tried to burrow out.

5468.text:
Lockley dug. The earth was hard, and its upper
part was filled with tenacious grass roots.

5475.text:
Lockley pulled them away. Once he'd gotten
under them, the digging went faster. Presently

5481.text:
he was under the metal side wall. He dug upward.
His hand reached open air.

5487.text:
"One of you can spell me now," he reported
in a low tone. "It looks like we'll get away.

5494.text:
But we've got to make our plans first. We
don't want to be talking outside the tank,

5499.text:
or even when the hole's fair-sized. For instance,
will we want to keep together when we get

5505.text:
outside?"
"Nix!" said the chunky man. "We wanna tell

5509.text:
everybody about these characters. We scatter.
If they catch one they don't catch any more.

5516.text:
We couldn't fight any better for bein' together.
We better scatter. I call that settled. I'm

5522.text:
scatterin'!"
He crawled to Lockley in the darkness.

5525.text:
"Where you diggin'? OK. I got it. Move aside
an' give me room."

5530.text:
"Everybody agrees on that?" asked Lockley.
They did. Lockley was relieved. The chunky

5538.text:
man dug busily. There was only the sound of
breathing, and the occasional fall of thrown-out

5544.text:
earth against the metal of the thing that
confined them. The chunky man said briskly,

5549.text:
"This dirt digs all right. We just got to
make the hole bigger."

5553.text:
In a little while the chunky man stopped,
panting. The tall man said, "I'll take a shot

5559.text:
at it."
There was a breakthrough to the air outside.

5564.text:
The atmosphere in the tank improved. The smell
of fresh-dug dirt and cool night air was refreshing.

5572.text:
The moustached man took his turn at digging.
Lockley went at it again. Soon he whispered,

5578.text:
"I think it's OK. I'll go ahead. No talking
outside!"

5583.text:
He shook hands all around, whispered "Good
luck!" and squirmed through the opening to

5589.text:
the night. Innumerable stars glittered in
the sky. They were reflected on the water

5595.text:
of the lake, here very close. Lockley moved
silently. In the blackness just behind him,

5603.text:
his eyes had become adjusted to almost complete
darkness. He headed away from the shining

5609.text:
water. He got brushwood between himself and
his former companions. He stood very, very

5615.text:
still.
He heard them murmuring together. They were

5620.text:
outside. But they had proposed entirely separate
efforts at escape. He went on, relieved. It

5627.text:
happened that the next time he'd see them,
circumstances would be entirely different.

5633.text:
But he believed they were competent men.
Guided by the Big Dipper, he moved directly

5638.text:
toward the place where Jill should be waiting
for him. By the angle of the Dipper's handle

5643.text:
he knew that it was almost midnight. Jill
would surely have known that nearly the worst

5649.text:
had happened. He'd have to find her....
It was two o'clock when he reached the place

5655.text:
where Jill had intended to wait. He showed
himself openly. He called quietly. There was

5661.text:
no answer. He called again, and again.
He saw something white. It was a scrap of

5668.text:
paper speared on a brushwood branch which
had been stripped of leaves to make the paper

5672.text:
show clearly. Lockley retrieved it and saw
markings on it which the starlight could not

5678.text:
help him to read. He went deep into the woods,
found a hollow, and bent low, risking the

5684.text:
light of his cigarette lighter for a swift
look at the message.

5688.text:
"I saw creatures moving around in the camp.
They weren't men. I was afraid they might

5695.text:
be hunting me. I've gone to wait by the car
if I can find it."

5700.text:
She'd written in English, in full confidence
that creatures from space would not be able

5705.text:
to read it. Lockley was not so sure, but the
message hadn't been removed. If it had been

5712.text:
read, there'd have been an ambush waiting
for him when he found it. So it appeared.

5717.text:
He headed through the night toward the ditched
small car.

5722.text:
It seemed a very long way, though he did stop
and drink his fill from a little mountain

5727.text:
stream over which a highway bridge had almost
been completed. In the night, though, and

5732.text:
with hard going, it was not easy to estimate
how far he'd gone. In fact, he was anxiously

5739.text:
debating if he mightn't have passed the abandoned
bulldozer when he came upon the place where

5744.text:
blasting had been going on. Still, it was
a very long way to be negotiated over still-remaining

5750.text:
tree stumps and the unfilled holes from which
others had been pulled.

5755.text:
He reached the bulldozer and turned south,
and at long last reached the highway. His

5761.text:
car should be no more than a quarter-mile
away. He moved toward it, close to the road's

5767.text:
edge. He heard music. It was faint, but vivid
because it was the last sound that anybody

5774.text:
would expect to hear in the hours before dawn
in a wilderness deserted by mankind. He scraped

5781.text:
his foot on the roadway. The music stopped
instantly. He said, "Jill?"

5787.text:
He heard her gasp.
"I found where Vale had been," he said steadily.

5792.text:
"There was no blood there. There's no sign
that he's been killed. Then I was caught myself.

5799.text:
I was put with three other men who were believed
killed but who are still alive. We escaped.

5805.text:
It is within reason to hope that Vale is unharmed
and that he may escape or somehow be rescued."

5813.text:
What he said was partly to make her sure that
it was he who appeared in the darkness. But

5818.text:
it was technically true, too. It was within
reason to hope for Vale's ultimate safety.

5825.text:
One can always hope, whatever the odds against
the thing hoped for. But Lockley thought that

5831.text:
the odds against Vale's living through the
events now in progress were very great indeed.

5837.text:
Jill stepped out into the starlight.
"I wasn't--sure it was you," she said with

5843.text:
difficulty. "I saw the things, you know, at
a distance. At first I thought they were men.

5850.text:
So when I first saw you--dimly--I was afraid."
"I'm sorry I haven't better news," said Lockley.

5858.text:
"It's good news! It's very good news," she
insisted as he drew near. "If they've captured

5865.text:
him, he'll make them understand that he's
a man, and that men are intelligent and not

5870.text:
just animals, and that they should be our
friends and we theirs."

5875.text:
The girl's voice was resolute. Lockley could
imagine that all the time she'd been waiting,

5882.text:
she'd been preparing to deny that even the
worst news was final, until she looked on

5887.text:
Vale's dead body itself.
"Do you want to tell me exactly what you found

5892.text:
out?" she asked.
"I'll tell you while I work on the car," said

5897.text:
Lockley. "We want to get moving away from
here before daybreak."

5902.text:
He went down to the little car, wedged in
the saplings it had splintered and broken.

5907.text:
He began to clear it so he could lever it
back on to the highway. He used a broken sapling,

5912.text:
and as he worked he told what had happened,
including the three men in the compost pit

5918.text:
shell and the dumping of assorted small wild
life specimens into it with them.

5924.text:
"But they didn't kill you," said Jill insistently,
"and they didn't kill those three, and there

5932.text:
were the two others you say got over the paralysis
and went back to the camp. Counting you, that's

5938.text:
six men they had at their mercy that we know
weren't harmed. So why should they have harmed

5944.text:
a seventh man?"
Lockley did not answer at once. None of the

5949.text:
spared six, he thought, had put up a fight.
Only Vale had exchanged blows with the crew

5954.text:
of the spaceship. Nobody else had seen them.
"That's right, about Vale," he said after

5962.text:
a moment in which he had been busy. "But this
doesn't look good!"

5967.text:
He felt under the car. He squeezed himself
beneath its front end. There was a small,

5973.text:
fugitive flicker of flame. It went out and
he was silent.

5978.text:
Presently he got to his feet and said evenly,
"We're in a fix. One of the front wheels is

5983.text:
turned almost at a right angle to the other.
A king pin is broken. The car couldn't be

5989.text:
driven even if I managed to get it up on the
road. We've got to walk. There ought to be

5994.text:
soldiers on the way up to the lake today.
If we meet them we'll be all right. But this

5999.text:
is bad luck!"
It happened that he was mistaken on both counts.

6005.text:
There were no soldiers moving into the park,
and it was not bad luck that his car couldn't

6010.text:
be driven. If he'd been able to get it on
the road and trundling down the highway, the

6015.text:
car would have been wrecked and they could
very well have been killed. But this was for

6020.text:
the future to disclose.
They took nothing from the car because they

6025.text:
could not see beyond the present. They started
out doggedly to follow the highway that soldiers

6031.text:
would be likely to follow on the way to the
lake. It was not the shortest way to the world

6036.text:
outside the Park. It was considerably longer
than a footpath would have been. But Lockley

6042.text:
expected tanks, at least, against which eccentric
unearthly weapons would be useless. So they

6048.text:
headed down the main highway. Lockley was
unarmed. They had no food. He hadn't eaten

6055.text:
since the morning before.
When day came--gray and still--and presently

6061.text:
the dew upon grass and tree leaves glittered
reflections of the sky, he moved aside into

6067.text:
the woods and found a broken-off branch, out
of which by very great effort he made a club.

6074.text:
When he came back, Jill was listening attentively
to the little pocket radio. She turned it

6080.text:
off.
"I was hoping for news," she explained determinedly.

6085.text:
"The government knows that there are creatures
in the spaceship, and he--" that would be

6090.text:
Vale "--will be trying to make them understand
what kind of beings we are. So there could

6095.text:
be friendly communication almost any time.
But there aren't any news broadcasts on the

6100.text:
air. I suppose it's too early."
He agreed, with reservations. They made their

6108.text:
way along the dew-wetted surface of the highway.
As the light grew stronger, Lockley glanced

6113.text:
again and again at Jill's face. She looked
very tired. He reflected sadly that she was

6120.text:
thinking of Vale. She'd never thought twice
about Lockley. Even now, or especially now,

6127.text:
all her thoughts were for Vale.
When sunlight appeared on the peaks around

6132.text:
them, he said detachedly, "You've had no rest
for twenty-four hours and I doubt that you've

6138.text:
had anything to eat. Neither have I. If troops
come up this highway we'll hear the engines.

6145.text:
I think we'd better get off the highway and
try to rest. And I may be able to find something

6151.text:
for us to eat."
There are few wildernesses so desolate as

6155.text:
to offer no food at all for one who knows
what to look for. There is usually some sort

6160.text:
of berry available. One kind of acorn is not
bad to eat. Shoots of bracken are not unlike

6167.text:
asparagus. There are some spiny wild plants
whose leaves, if plucked young enough, will

6174.text:
yield some nourishment and of course there
are mushrooms. Even on stone one can find

6180.text:
liverish rock-tripe which is edible if one
dries it to complete dessication before soaking

6187.text:
it again to make a soup or broth.
Before he searched for food, though, Lockley

6193.text:
said abruptly, "You said you saw the creatures
and they weren't men. What did they look like?"

6199.text:
"They were a long way away," Jill told him.
"I didn't see them clearly. They're about

6206.text:
the size of men but they just aren't men.
Far away as they were, I could tell that!"

6214.text:
Lockley considered. He shrugged and said,
"Rest. I'll be back."

6219.text:
He moved away. He was hungry and he kept his
eyes in motion, looking for something to take

6225.text:
back to Jill. But his mind struggled to form
a picture of a creature who'd be the size

6231.text:
of a man but would be known not to be a man
even at a distance; whose difference from

6238.text:
mankind couldn't be described because seen
at such great distance. Presently he shook

6244.text:
his head impatiently and gave all his attention
to the search for food.

6250.text:
He found a patch of berries on a hillside
where there was enough earth for berry bushes,

6254.text:
but not for trees. Bears had been at them,
but there were many left.

6259.text:
He filled his hat with them and made his way
back to Jill. She had the pocket radio on

6264.text:
again, but at the lowest possible volume.
He put the berry-filled hat down beside her.

6270.text:
She held up a warning hand. Speckles of sunshine
trickled down through the foliage and the

6276.text:
tree trunks were spotted with yellow light.
They ate the berries as they heard the news.

6282.text:
A new official news release was out. And now,
twelve hours after the last, wholly reassuring

6290.text:
bulletin, there was no longer any pretense
that the thing in Boulder Lake was merely

6294.text:
a meteorite.
The pretext that it was a natural object,

6299.text:
said the news broadcaster, resuming, had been
abandoned. But reassurance continued. Photographic

6307.text:
planes had been attempting to get a picture
of the alien ship as it floated in the lake.

6312.text:
So far no satisfactory image had been secured,
but pictures of wreckage caused by an enormous

6318.text:
wave generated in the lake by the alien spaceship's
arrival were sharp and clear. Troops have

6326.text:
been posted in a cordon about the Boulder
Lake Park area to prevent unauthorized persons

6331.text:
from swarming in to see earth's visitors from
space. Details of its landing continue to

6337.text:
be learned. Workmen from the construction
camp have been questioned, and the two men

6342.text:
who were paralyzed and then released have
told their story. So far four human beings

6348.text:
are known to have been seized by the occupants
of the spaceship. One is Vale, an eye-witness

6354.text:
to the ship's descent and landing. The three
others went to investigate the gigantic explosion

6360.text:
accompanying the landing in the lake. They
have not been seen since. This, however, does

6366.text:
not imply that they are dead. Quite possibly
the invaders--aliens--guests--who have landed

6372.text:
on American soil are trying to learn how to
communicate with the American people who are

6377.text:
their hosts.
Lockley watched Jill's face. As she heard

6383.text:
the references to Vale, she went white, but
she saw Lockley looking at her and said fiercely,

6389.text:
"They don't know that the visitors didn't
kill you and let you and the other three men

6394.text:
escape. Someone ought to tell these broadcasters...."
Lockley did not answer. In his own mind, though,

6402.text:
there was the fact that of the two workmen
who'd been paralyzed and released, the three

6407.text:
men in the compost pit shell, and himself,
none had seen their captors. But Vale had.

6414.text:
The broadcaster went on with a fine air of
confidence, reporting that yesterday afternoon

6421.text:
a helicopter had flown into the mountains
to examine the landing site in detail since

6427.text:
it could not be examined from a high-flying
plane.

6431.text:
Lockley remembered the droning he and the
others had heard through the metal plates

6435.text:
of their prison.
The helicopter had suddenly ceased to communicate.

6440.text:
It is believed to have had engine trouble.
However, later on a fast jet had attempted

6446.text:
a flight below the extreme altitude of the
photographic planes. Its pilot reported that

6452.text:
at fifteen thousand feet he'd suddenly smelled
an appalling odor. Then he was blinded, deafened,

6460.text:
and his muscles knotted in spasms. He was
paralyzed. The experience lasted for seconds

6466.text:
only. It was as if he'd flown into a searchlight
beam which produced those sensations and then

6473.text:
had flown out of it. He'd instinctively used
evasive maneuvers and got away, but twice

6479.text:
before he passed the horizon there were instantaneous
flashes of the paralysis and the pain. Scientists

6486.text:
determined that the report of the men who'd
been paralyzed and released agreed with the

6491.text:
report of the pilot. It was assumed that whatever
or whoever had landed in Boulder Lake possessed

6498.text:
a beam--it might as well be called a terror
beam because of the effects it had--of some

6504.text:
sort of radiation which produced the paralysis
and the agony. Unless the three men missing

6510.text:
from the construction camp had died of it,
however, it was not to be considered a death

6514.text:
ray.
The news went on with every appearance of

6518.text:
frankness and confidence. It was natural for
strangers on a strange planet to take precautions

6524.text:
against possibly hostile inhabitants of the
newly-found world. But every effort would

6530.text:
be exerted to make friendly contact and establish
peaceful communications with the beings from

6536.text:
space. Their weapon appeared to be of limited
range and so far not lethal to human beings.

6544.text:
Occasional flashes of its effects had been
noted by the troops now forming a cordon about

6549.text:
the Park, but it only produced discomfort,
not paralysis. Nevertheless the troops in

6555.text:
question have been moved back. Meanwhile rocket
missiles are being moved to areas where they

6561.text:
can deliver atom bombs on the alien ship if
it should prove necessary. But the government

6568.text:
is extremely anxious to make this contact
with extra-terrestrials a friendly one, because

6574.text:
contact with a race more advanced than ourselves
could be of inestimable value to us. Therefore

6581.text:
atom bombs will be used only as a last resort.
An atom bomb would destroy aliens and their

6588.text:
ship together--and we want the ship. The public
is urged to be calm. If the ship should appear

6596.text:
dangerous, it can and will be smashed.
The news broadcast ended.

6603.text:
Jill said, obviously speaking of Vale, "He'll
make them realize that men aren't like porcupines

6609.text:
and rabbits! When they realize that we humans
are intelligent people, everything will be

6615.text:
all right!"
Lockley said reluctantly, "There's one thing

6621.text:
to remember, though, Jill. They didn't blindfold
the rabbits or the porcupine. They only blindfolded

6630.text:
"One of the men in the pit with me," said
Lockley, "thought they didn't want us to see

6636.text:
them because they were monsters. That's not
likely." He paused. "Maybe they blindfolded

6643.text:
us to keep us from finding out they aren't."
CHAPTER 4

6651.text:
"The evidence," said Lockley as Jill looked
at him ashen-faced, "the evidence is all for

8279.text:
them, by accident. Or it could have been weakened....
It was very puzzling.

8285.text:
CHAPTER 5
When darkness fell, Lockley and Jill were

8290.text:
many miles away from the clearing where he
had made the S.O.S. They were under a dense

8296.text:
screen of leaves from a monster tree whose
roots rose above ground at the foot of its

8301.text:
enormous trunk. They formed a shelter of sorts
against observation from a distance. Lockley

8309.text:
had spotted a fallen tree far gone with wood-rot.
He broke pieces of the punky stuff with his

8315.text:
fingers. Then he realized that without a pot
the bracken shoots he'd gathered could not

8321.text:
be cooked. They had to be boiled or not cooked
at all.

8326.text:
"We'll call it a salad," he told Jill, "minus
vinegar and oil and garlic, and eat what we

8334.text:
can."
She'd been pale with exhaustion before the

8337.text:
sun sank, but he hadn't dared let her rest
more than was absolutely necessary. Once he'd

8343.text:
offered to carry her for a while, but she'd
refused. Now she sat drearily in the shelter

8349.text:
of the roots, resting.
"We might try for news," he suggested.

8356.text:
She made an exhausted gesture of assent. He
turned on the tiny radio and tuned it in.

8363.text:
There was no scarcity of news, now. A few
days past, news went on the air on schedule,

8370.text:
mostly limited to five-minute periods in which
to cover all the noteworthy events of the

8376.text:
world. Part of that five minutes, too, was
taken up by advertising matter from a sponsor.

8382.text:
Now music was rare. There were occasional
melodies, but most were interrupted for new

8388.text:
interpretations of the threat to earth at
Boulder Lake. Every sort of prominent person

8394.text:
was invited to air his views about the thing
from the sky and the creatures it brought.

8400.text:
Most had no views but only an urge to talk
to a large audience. Something, though, had

8406.text:
to be put on the air between commercials.
The actual news was specific. Small towns

8413.text:
around the fringe of the Park area were being
evacuated of all their inhabitants. Foreign

8418.text:
scientists had been flown to the United States
and were at the temporary area command post

8424.text:
not far from Boulder Lake. Rocket missiles
were aimed and ready to blast the lake and

8429.text:
the mountains around it should the need arise.
A drone plane had been flown to the lake with

8435.text:
a television camera transmitting back everything
its lens saw. It arrived at the lake and its

8441.text:
camera relayed back exactly nothing that had
not been photographed and recorded before.

8447.text:
But suddenly there was a crash of static and
the drone went out of control and crashed.

8453.text:
Its camera faithfully transmitted the landscape
spinning around until its destruction. Military

8460.text:
transmitters were beaming signals on every
conceivable frequency to what was now universally

8466.text:
called the alien spaceship. They had received
no replies. The foreign scientists had agreed

8473.text:
that the terror beam--paralysis beam--death
beam--was electronic in nature.

8480.text:
Lockley had thought Jill asleep from pure
weariness, but her voice came out of the darkness

8485.text:
beside the big tree trunk.
"You found that out!" she said. "About its

8491.text:
being electronic!"
"I had a sample stationary beam to check on,"

8497.text:
said Lockley. "They haven't. Which may be
a bad thing. Nobody's going to make useful

8503.text:
observations of something that makes him blind
and deaf and paralyzed while he's in the act.

8510.text:
There are some things that puzzle me about
that. Why haven't they killed anybody yet?

8516.text:
They've got the public about as scared as
it can get without some killing. And why didn't

8521.text:
we get the full force of the beam after the
plane had been driven away? They could have

8526.text:
given us the full treatment if they'd wanted
to. Why didn't they?"

8531.text:
"If people run away from the towns," said
Jill's voice, very tired and sleepy, "maybe

8539.text:
they think that's enough. They can take the
towns...."

8544.text:
Lockley did not answer, and Jill said no more.
Her breathing became deep and regular. She

8550.text:
was so weary that even hunger could not keep
her awake.

8556.text:
Lockley tried to think. There was the matter
of food. Bracken shoots were common enough

8562.text:
but unsubstantial. It would need more careful
observation to note all the likely spots for

8569.text:
mushrooms. Perhaps they were far enough from
the lake to take more time hunting food. They

8575.text:
were almost exactly in the situation of Australian
bushmen who live exclusively by foraging,

8582.text:
with some not-too-efficient hunting. But Australian
savages were not as finicky as Jill and himself.

8589.text:
They ate grubs and insects. For this sort
of situation, prejudices were a handicap.

8597.text:
He considered the idea with sardonic appreciation.
Two days of inadequate food and such ideas

8605.text:
came! But he and Jill wouldn't be the only
ones to think such things if matters continued

8611.text:
as they were going. The towns around Boulder
Lake were being evacuated. The cordon about

8617.text:
it had been made to retreat. There was panic
not only in America, but everywhere. In Europe

8624.text:
there were wild rumors of other landings of
other ships of space. The stock markets would

8630.text:
undoubtedly close tomorrow, if they hadn't
closed today. There'd be the beginning of

8635.text:
a mass exodus from the larger cities, starting
quietly but building up to frenzy as those

8642.text:
who tried to leave jammed all the routes by
which they could get away. If the creatures

8648.text:
of the spaceship wanted more than the flight
of all humans from about their landing place,

8653.text:
there would be genuine trouble. Let them move
aggressively and there would be panic and

8659.text:
disorder and pure catastrophe, with self-exiled
city dwellers desperate from hunger because

8666.text:
they were away from market centers. It looked
as if a dozen or two monsters could wreck

8672.text:
a civilization without the need to kill one
single human being directly.

8679.text:
He heard a sound. He turned off the radio,
gripping the clumsy club which was probably

8684.text:
useless against anything really threatening.
The sound continued. There were rustlings

8690.text:
of leaves, and then faint rattling, almost
clicking noises. Whatever the creature was,

8698.text:
it was not large. It seemed to amble tranquilly
through the forest and the night, neither

8705.text:
alarmed nor considering itself alarming.
The clickings again. And suddenly Lockley

8712.text:
knew what it was. Of course! He'd heard it
in the compost pit shell, when he was a prisoner

8718.text:
of the invaders from space. He rose and moved
toward the noise. The creature did not run

8724.text:
away. It went about its own affairs with the
same peaceful indifference as before. Lockley

8731.text:
ran into a tree. He stumbled over a fallen
branch on the ground. He came to the place

8737.text:
where the creature should be. There was silence.
He flicked the flint of his pocket lighter

8743.text:
and in the flash of brightness he saw his
prey. It had heard his approach. It was a

8749.text:
porcupine, prudently curled up into a spiky
ball and placidly defying all carnivores,

8756.text:
including men. A porcupine is normally the
one wild creature without an enemy. Even men

8763.text:
customarily spare it because so often it has
saved the lives of lost hunters and half-starved

8770.text:
travelers. It accomplishes this by its bland
refusal to run away from anybody.

8778.text:
Lockley classed himself as a half-starved
traveler. He struck with the club after a

8784.text:
second spark from his lighter-flint.
Presently he had a small, barely smouldering

8790.text:
fire of rotted wood. He cooked over it, and
the smell of cooking roused Jill from her

8799.text:
"We're having a late supper," said Lockley
gravely. "A midnight snack. Take this stick.

8806.text:
There's a loin of porcupine on it. Be careful!
It's hot!"

8811.text:
Jill said, "Oh-h-h-h!" Then, "Is there more
for you?"

8816.text:
"Plenty!" he assured her. "I hunted it down
with my trusty club, and only got stuck a

8822.text:
half-dozen times while I was skinning and
cleaning it."

8826.text:
She ate avidly, and when she'd finished he
offered more, which she refused until he'd

8832.text:
had a share.
They did not quite finish the whole porcupine,

8836.text:
but it was an odd and companionable meal,
there in the darkness with the barely-glowing

8842.text:
coals well-hidden from sight. Lockley said,
"I'm sort of a news addict. Shall we see what

8849.text:
the wild radio waves are saying?"
"Of course," said Jill. She added awkwardly:

8856.text:
"Maybe it's the sudden food, but--I hope you'll
remain my friend after this is all over. I

8864.text:
don't know anyone else I'd say that to."
"Consider," said Lockley, "that I've made

8869.text:
an eloquent and grateful reply."
But his expression in the darkness was not

8876.text:
happy. He'd fallen in love with Jill after
meeting her only twice, and both times she

8883.text:
had been with Vale. She intended to marry
Vale. But on the evidence at hand Vale was

8889.text:
either dead or a prisoner of the invaders;
if the last, his chances of living to marry

8895.text:
Jill did not look good, and if the first,
this was surely no time to revive his memory.

8903.text:
He found a news broadcast. He suspected that
most radio stations would stay on the air

8908.text:
all night, now that it was officially admitted
that the object in Boulder Lake was a spaceship

8914.text:
bringing invaders to earth. The government
releases spoke of them as "visitors," in a

8920.text:
belated use of the term, but the public was
suspicious of reassurances now. At the beginning

8927.text:
the landing had seemed like another exaggerated
horror tale of the kind that kept up newspaper

8933.text:
circulations. Now the public was beginning
to believe it, and people might stop going

8939.text:
to their offices and the trains might cease
to ran on time. When that happened, disaster

8945.text:
would be at hand.
The news came in a resonant voice which revealed

8950.text:
these facts:
Four more small towns had been ordered evacuated

8956.text:
because of their proximity to Boulder Lake.
The radiation weapon of the aliens had pushed

8961.text:
back the military cordon by as much as five
miles. But the big news was that the aliens

8967.text:
had broken radio silence. Apparently they'd
examined and repaired the short wave communicator

8974.text:
from the helicopter they'd knocked down.
Shortly after sundown, said the news report,

8980.text:
a call had come through on a military short
wave frequency. It was a human voice, first

8986.text:
muttering bewilderedly and then speaking with
confusion and uneasiness. The message had

8992.text:
been taped and now was released to the public.
"What the hell's this ...? Oh.... What do

8999.text:
you characters want me to do? This feels like
the short wave set from the 'copter.... Hmm....

9005.text:
You got it turned on.... What'll I do with
it, Broadcast? I don't know whether you want

9011.text:
me to talk to you or to back home, wherever
that is.... Maybe you want me to say I'm havin'

9016.text:
a fine time an' wish you was here.... I'm
not. I wish I was there.... If this is goin'

9023.text:
on the air I'm Joe Blake, radio man on the
'copter two 'leven. We were headin' in to

9029.text:
Boulder Lake when I smelled a stink. Next
second there were lights in my eyes. They

9034.text:
blinded me. Then I heard a racket like all
hell was loose. Then I felt like I had hold

9039.text:
of a power transmission line. I couldn't wiggle
a finger. I stayed that way till the 'copter

9046.text:
crashed. When I come to, I was blindfolded
like I am now. I don't know what happened

9051.text:
to the other guys. I haven't seen 'em. I haven't
seen anything! But they just put me in front

9057.text:
of what I think is the 'copter's short wave
set an' squeaked at me--"

9060.text:
The recorded voice ended abruptly. The news
announcer's voice came back. He said that

9068.text:
the member of the 'copter crew had given some
other information before he was arbitrarily

9072.text:
cut off.
"I'll bet," said Lockley when the newscast

9077.text:
ended, "I'll bet the other information was
that the invaders have managed to tell him

9082.text:
that earth must surrender to them!"
"Why?"

9086.text:
"What else would they want to say? To come
and play patty-cake, when they can push the

9091.text:
Army around at will and have managed to keep
planes from flying anywhere near them? They

9097.text:
may not know we've got atom bombs, but I'll
bet they do! Part of that extra information

9103.text:
could have been a warning not to try to use
them. It would be logical to bluff even on

9108.text:
that, though they couldn't make good."
Jill said very carefully, "You hinted once

9116.text:
that they might be men, pretending to be monsters.
But that would mean that somebody I care about

9122.text:
would probably be killed because he'd seen
them and knew they weren't creatures from

9128.text:
beyond the stars."
"I think you can forget that idea," said Lockley.

9133.text:
"They don't act like men. Chasing away the
plane that was going to land for us, and not

9139.text:
using the beam on the fugitives it was plainly
going to land for--that's not like men preparing

9145.text:
to take over a continent! And nudging the
Army back to make the cordoned space larger--that's

9152.text:
not like our most likely human enemy, either.
They'd wipe out the cordon by stepping up

9157.text:
the terror beam to death ray intensity."
"Suppose they couldn't?"

9162.text:
"They wouldn't have landed with a weapon that
couldn't kill anybody," said Lockley. "It's

9168.text:
much more likely that they're monsters. But
they don't act like monsters, either."

9174.text:
Jill was silent for a moment.
"Not even monsters who wanted to make friends?"

9181.text:
"They," said Lockley drily, "would hardly
make a surprise landing. They'd have parked

9187.text:
on the moon and squeaked at us until we got
curious, and then they'd arrange to land,

9193.text:
or to meet men in orbit, or something. But
they didn't. They made a surprise landing,

9198.text:
and cleared a big space of humans, keeping
themselves to themselves. But if they do think

9204.text:
we're animals, like rabbits, they'd kill people
instead of stinging them up a bit, or paralyzing

9210.text:
them for a while and then letting them go.
That's not like any monster I can imagine!"

9216.text:
"Then--"
"You'd better go to sleep," said Lockley.

9220.text:
"We've got a long day's hike before us tomorrow."
"Yes-s-s," agreed Jill reluctantly. "Good-night."

9229.text:
"'Night," said Lockley curtly.
He stayed awake. It was amusing that he was

9235.text:
uneasy about wild animals. There were predators
in the Park, and he had only an improvised

9241.text:
club for a weapon. But he knew well enough
that most animals avoid man because of a bewildering

9248.text:
sudden development of instinct.
Grizzly bears, before the white man came,

9253.text:
were so scornful of man that they could be
considered the dominant species in North America.

9259.text:
They'd been known to raid a camp of Indians
to carry away a man for food. Indian spears

9265.text:
and arrows were simply ineffective against
them. When Stonewall Jackson was a lieutenant

9271.text:
in the United States Army, stationed in the
West to protect the white settlers, he and

9276.text:
a detachment of mounted troopers were attacked
without provocation by a grizzly who was wholly

9282.text:
contemptuous of them. The then Lieutenant
Jackson rode a horse which was blind in one

9288.text:
eye, and he maneuvered to get the bear on
the horse's blind side so he could charge

9292.text:
it. With his cavalry sabre he split the grizzly's
skull down to its chin. It was the only time

9299.text:
in history that a grizzly bear was ever killed
by a man with a sword. But no grizzly nowadays

9306.text:
would attack a man unless cornered. Even cubs
with no possible experience of humankind are

9313.text:
terrified by the scent of men.
All that was true enough. In addition, preparations

9320.text:
for the Park included much activity by the
Wild Life Control unit, which persuaded bears

9326.text:
to congregate in one area by putting out food
for them, and took various other measures

9331.text:
for deer and other animals. It had seeded
trout streams with fingerlings and the lake

9336.text:
itself with baby big-mouthed bass. The huge
trailer truck of Wild Life Control was familiar

9344.text:
enough. Lockley had seen it headed up to the
lake the day before the landing. Now he found

9350.text:
himself wondering sardonically to what degree
the Wild Life Control men determined where

9355.text:
mountain lions should hunt.
He'd slept in the open innumerable times without

9360.text:
thinking of mountain lions. With Jill to look
after, though, he worried. But he was horribly

9367.text:
weary, and he knew somehow that in the back
of his mind there was something unpleasant

9372.text:
that was trying to move into his conscious
thoughts. It was a sort of hunch. Wearily

9379.text:
and half asleep, he tried to put his mind
on it. He failed.

9384.text:
He awoke suddenly. There were rustlings among
the trees. Something moved slowly and intermittently

9391.text:
toward him. It could be anything, even a creature
from Boulder Lake. He heard other sounds.

9398.text:
Another creature. The first drew near, not
moving in a straight line. The second creature

9404.text:
followed it, drawing closer to the first.
Lockley's scalp crawled. Creatures from space

9412.text:
might have some of the highly-developed senses
which men had lost while growing civilized--full

9419.text:
keenness of scent, for example.
Such a creature might be able to find Lockley

9424.text:
and Jill in the darkness after trailing them
for miles. And so primitive a talent, in a

9430.text:
creature farther advanced than men, was somehow
more horrifying than anything else Lockley

9436.text:
had thought of about them. He gripped his
club desperately, wholly aware that a star

9442.text:
creature should be able to paralyze him with
the terror beam....

9447.text:
There were whistling, squealing noises. They
were very much like the squeaks his captors

9452.text:
had directed at each other and at him when
he was blindfolded and being led downhill

9458.text:
to imprisonment in the compost pit shell.
Very much like, but not identical. Nevertheless,

9466.text:
Lockley's hair seemed to stand up on end and
he raised his club in desperation.

9472.text:
The whistling squeals grew shriller. Then
there was an indescribable sound and one of

9478.text:
the two creatures rushed frantically away.
It traveled in great leaps through the blackness

9484.text:
under the trees.
And then there was a sudden whiff of a long-familiar

9489.text:
odor, smelled a hundred times before. It was
the reek of a skunk, stalked by a carnivore

9497.text:
and defending itself as skunks do. But a skunk
was nothing like a terror beam. Its effluvium

9504.text:
offended only one sense, affected only one
set of sensation nerves. The terror beam....

9513.text:
Lockley opened his mouth to laugh, but did
not. The thing at the back of his mind had

9518.text:
come forward. He was appalled.
Jill said shakily, "What's the matter? What's

9525.text:
happened? That smell--"
"It's only a skunk," said Lockley evenly.

9531.text:
"He just told me some very bad news. I know
how the terror beam works now. And there's

9538.text:
not a thing that can be done about it. Not
a thing. It can't be!"

9543.text:
He raged suddenly, there in the darkness,
because he saw the utter hopelessness of combatting

9549.text:
the creatures who'd taken over Boulder Lake.
There was nothing to keep them from taking

9554.text:
over the whole earth, no matter what sort
of monsters or not-monsters they might be.

9563.text:
CHAPTER 6
It was nine o'clock at night when Lockley

9567.text:
killed the porcupine, and ten by the time
Jill had gone back to sleep huddled between

9572.text:
the projecting roots of a giant tree. Shortly
after midnight Lockley had been awakened when

9578.text:
a skunk defeated a hungry predator within
a hundred yards of their bivouac. But some

9584.text:
time in between, there was another happening
of much greater importance elsewhere.

9592.text:
Something came out of Boulder Lake National
Park. All humans had supposedly fled from

9598.text:
it. It was abandoned to the creatures of the
thing from the sky. But something came out

9604.text:
of it.
Nobody saw the thing, of course. Nobody could

9608.text:
approach it, which was the point immediately
demonstrated. No human being could endure

9614.text:
being within seven miles of whatever it was.
It was evidently a vehicle of some sort, however,

9622.text:
because it swung terror beams before it, and
terror beams on either side, and when it was

9627.text:
clear of the Park it played terror beams behind
it, too. Men who suffered the lightest touch

9633.text:
of those sweeping beams of terror and anguish
moved frantically to avoid having the experience

9639.text:
again. So when something moved out of the
Park and sent wavering terror beams before

9645.text:
it, men moved to one side or the other and
gave it room.

9650.text:
On a large-scale map in the military area
command post, its progress could be watched

9655.text:
as it was reported. The reports described
a development of unbearable beam strength

9661.text:
which showed up as a bulge in the cordon's
roughly circular line. That bulge, which was

9667.text:
the cordon itself moving back, moved outward
and became a half-circle some miles across.

9674.text:
It continued to move outward, and on the map
it appeared like a pseudopod extruded by an

9680.text:
enormous amoeba. It was the area of effectiveness
of a weapon previously unknown on earth--the

9687.text:
area where humans could not stay.
Deliberately, the unseen moving thing severed

9695.text:
itself from the similar and larger weapon
field which was its birthplace and its home.

9701.text:
It moved with great deliberation toward the
small town of Maplewood, twenty miles from

9706.text:
the border of the Park.
Jeeps and motorcycles scurried ahead of it,

9711.text:
just out of reach of its beams. They made
sure that houses and farms and all inhabited

9717.text:
places were emptied of people before the moving
terror beams could engulf them. They went

9723.text:
into the town of Maplewood itself and frantically
made sure that nothing alive remained in it.

9728.text:
They went on to clear the countryside beyond.
The unseen thing from the Park moved onward.

9736.text:
High overhead there was a dull muttering like
faraway thunder, but it was planes with filled

9742.text:
bomb racks circling above the starlit land.
There were men in those planes who ached to

9748.text:
dive down and destroy this separated fraction
of an invasion. But there were firm orders

9754.text:
from the Pentagon. So long as the invaders
killed nobody, they were not to be attacked.

9761.text:
There was reason for the order in the desire
of the government to be on friendly terms

9766.text:
with a race which could travel between the
