stars. But there was an even more urgent reason.

9772.text:
The aliens had not yet begun to murder, but
it was suspected that they had a horrifying

9778.text:
power to kill. So it was firmly commanded
that no bomb or missile or bullet was to be

9785.text:
used unless the invaders invited hostilities
by killing humans. Their captives--the crew

9792.text:
of a helicopter--might be freed if aliens
and men achieved friendship. So for now--no

9800.text:
provocation!
The thing which nobody saw moved comfortably

9804.text:
over the ground between the park and Maplewood.
In the center of the weapon field there was

9810.text:
a something which generated the terror beam
and probably carried passengers. Whatever

9816.text:
it was, it moved onward and into Maplewood
and for seven miles in every direction troops

9823.text:
watched for it to move out again. Artillerymen
had guns ready to fire upon it if they ever

9828.text:
got firing coordinates and permission to go
into action. Planes were ready to drop bombs

9834.text:
if they ever got leave to do so. And a few
miles away there were rockets ready to prove

9840.text:
their accuracy and devastating capacity if
only given a launching command. But nothing

9846.text:
happened. Not even a flare was permitted to
be dropped by the planes far up in the sky.

9852.text:
A flare might be taken for hostility.
The thing from the Park stayed in Maplewood

9859.text:
for two hours. At the end of that time it
moved deliberately back toward the Park. It

9865.text:
left the town untouched save for certain curious
burglaries of hardware stores and radio shops

9872.text:
and a garage or two. It looked as if intensely
curious not-human beings had moved from their

9880.text:
redoubt--Boulder Lake--to find out what civilization
human beings had attained. They could guess

9887.text:
at it by the buildings and the homes, but
most notably in the technical shops of the

9892.text:
inhabitants.
It went slowly and deliberately back into

9897.text:
the Park. Humans moved cautiously back into
the area that had been emptied. Not many,

9904.text:
but enough to be sure that the thing had really
returned to the place from which it had come.

9910.text:
Soldiers were tentatively entering the again-abandoned
town of Maplewood when the unseen thing changed

9916.text:
the range of its weapon bearing on that little
city. It was then presumably not less than

9922.text:
seven miles on its way back to Boulder Lake.
The military had congratulated themselves

9928.text:
on what they'd learned. The beam projectors
at the lake had a range of much more than

9933.text:
seven miles, but this movable, unidentifiable
thing carried a lesser armament. From it,

9941.text:
men and animals seven miles away were safe.
This was notable news.

9947.text:
Then the unseen object did something. The
terror beam that flicked back and forth doubled

9953.text:
in intensity. The soldiers just reentering
Maplewood smelled foulness and saw bright

9960.text:
lights. Bellowings deafened them. They fell
with every muscle rigid in spasm. Beyond them

9966.text:
other men were paralyzed. For five minutes
the invaders' mobile weapon paralyzed all

9972.text:
living things for a distance of fifteen miles.
Then for thirty seconds it paralyzed living

9979.text:
things for a distance of thirty miles. For
a bare instant it convulsed men and animals

9985.text:
for a greater distance yet. And all these
victims of the terror beam knew, thereafter,

9991.text:
an invincible horror of the beam.
The thing from the Park which nobody had seen

9998.text:
went back into the Park. And then men were
permitted to return to exactly the same places

10003.text:
they'd been allowed to occupy before the thing
began its excursion.

10010.text:
It seemed that nothing was changed, but everything
was changed. If there were mobile carriers

10016.text:
of the invasion weapon, then victory could
not be had by a single atom bomb fired into

10022.text:
Boulder Lake. There might be a dozen separate
mobile terror beam generators scattered through

10029.text:
the Park. Any atomic attack would need to
be multiplied in its violence to be certain

10034.text:
of results. Instead of one bomb there might
be a need for fifty. They would have to destroy

10041.text:
the Park utterly, even its mountains. And
the fallout from so many atom bombs simply

10047.text:
could not be risked. The invaders were effectively
invulnerable.

10053.text:
While this undesirable situation was being
demonstrated, Jill slept heavily between two

10058.text:
roots of a very large tree, and Lockley dozed
against a nearby tree trunk. He believed that

10065.text:
he guarded Jill most vigilantly.
He awoke at dawn with the din of bird song

10070.text:
in his ears. Jill opened her eyes at almost
the same instant. She smiled at him and tried

10076.text:
to get up. She was stiff and sore from the
hardness of the ground on which she'd slept.

10082.text:
But it was a new day, and there was breakfast.
It was porcupine cooked the night before.

10089.text:
"Somehow," said Jill as she nibbled at a bone,
"somehow I feel more cheerful than I did."

10098.text:
"That's a mistake," Lockley told her. "Start
out with a few premonitions and the day improves

10104.text:
as they turn out wrong. But if you start out
hoping, the day ends miserably with most of

10109.text:
your hopes denied."
"You've got premonitions?" she asked.

10115.text:
"Definitely," he said.
It was true. As yet he knew nothing of last

10121.text:
night's temporary occupation of a human town,
but he believed he knew how the terror beam

10127.text:
worked even if he couldn't figure out a way
to generate it. He could imagine no defense

10132.text:
against it. But if Jill had awakened feeling
cheerful, there was no reason to depress her.

10138.text:
She'd have reason enough to be dejected later,
beginning with proof of Vale's death and going

10144.text:
on from there.
"We might listen to the news," she suggested.

10150.text:
"A premonition or two might be ruled out right
away!"

10153.text:
Silently, he turned on the little radio. Automatically,
he set it for the lowest volume they could

10160.text:
hear distinctly.
The main item in the news was a baldly factual

10165.text:
but toned-down report of the thing from the
lake which had left the park and examined

10170.text:
a small human town in detail and then had
returned to the Park. There were reports of

10177.text:
peculiar hoofprints found where the invaders
had been. They were not the hoofprints of

10183.text:
any earthly animal. There was an optimistic
report from the scientists at work on the

10189.text:
problem of the beam. Someone had come up with
an idea and some calculations which seemed

10195.text:
to promise that the beam would presently be
duplicated. Once it was duplicated, of course

10201.text:
a way to neutralize it could be found.
Lockley grunted. The broadcast was enthusiastic

10207.text:
in its comments on the scientists. It talked
gobbledegook which sounded as if it meant

10213.text:
something but was actually nonsense. It barely
touched on the fact that human beings were

10219.text:
now ordered out of a much larger space than
had been evacuated before. There was a statement

10226.text:
from an important official that panic buying
of food was both unnecessary and unwise. Lockley

10233.text:
grunted again when the newscast ended.
"The idea that anything that can be duplicated

10239.text:
can be canceled," he announced gloomily, "is
unfortunately rot. We can duplicate sounds,

10246.text:
but there's no way to make them cancel out!
Not accurately!"

10251.text:
Jill had eaten a substantial part of the porcupine
while the newscast was on. It was not a satisfying

10258.text:
breakfast, but it cheered her immensely after
two days of near-starvation.

10262.text:
"But," she observed, "maybe that won't apply
to this business when you report what you

10270.text:
know. It's not likely that anybody else has
stood just outside a beam and made tests of

10276.text:
what it's like and how it's aimed and so on."
They started off. For journeying in the Park,

10284.text:
Lockley had the advantage that as part of
the preparation for making a new map, he'd

10288.text:
familiarized himself with all mapping done
to date. He knew very nearly where he was.

10295.text:
He knew within a close margin just where the
terror beam stretched. He'd smashed his watch,

10301.text:
which during sunshine substituted admirably
for a compass, but he could maintain a reasonably

10307.text:
straight line toward that part of the Park's
border the terror beam would cross.

10313.text:
They moved doggedly over mountain-flanks and
up valleys, and once they followed a winding

10319.text:
hollow for a long way because it led toward
their destination without demanding that they

10324.text:
climb. It was in this area that, pushing through
brushwood beside a running stream, they came

10331.text:
abruptly upon a big brown bear. He was no
more than a hundred feet away. He stared at

10337.text:
them inquisitively, raising his nose to sniff
for their scent.

10342.text:
Lockley bent and picked up a stone. He threw
it. It clattered on rocks on the ground. The

10348.text:
bear made a whuffing sound and moved aggrievedly
away.

10353.text:
"I'd have been afraid to do that," said Jill.
"It was a he-bear," said Lockley. "I wouldn't

10360.text:
have tried it on a she-bear with cubs."
They went on and on. At mid-morning Lockley

10366.text:
found some mushrooms. They were insipid and
only acute hunger would make them edible raw,

10373.text:
but he filled his pockets. A little later
there were berries, and as they gathered and

10378.text:
ate them he lectured learnedly on edible wild
plants to be found in the wilderness. Jill

10384.text:
listened with apparent interest. When they
left the berry patch they swung to the left

10389.text:
to avoid a steep climb directly in their way.
And suddenly Lockley stopped short. At the

10395.text:
same instant Jill caught at his arm. She'd
turned white.

10400.text:
They turned and ran.
A hundred yards back, Lockley slackened his

10405.text:
speed. They stopped. After a moment he managed
to grin mirthlessly.

10411.text:
"A conditioned reflex," he said wryly. "We
smell something and we run. But I think it's

10419.text:
the old familiar terror beam that crosses
highways to stop men from using them. If it

10424.text:
were a portable beam projector with somebody
aiming it, we wouldn't be talking about it."

10430.text:
Jill panted, partly with relief.
"I've thought of something I want to try,"

10435.text:
said Lockley. "I should have tried it yesterday
when I first smashed my watch."

10441.text:
He retraced his steps to the spot where they'd
caught the first whiff of that disgusting

10445.text:
reptilian-jungle-decay odor which had bombarded
their nostrils. Jill called anxiously, "Be

10454.text:
careful!"
He nodded. He got the coiled bronze watchspring

10458.text:
out of his pocket. He went very cautiously
to the spot where the smell became noticeable.

10464.text:
Standing well back from it, he tossed one
end of the spring into it. He drew it back.

10470.text:
He repeated the operation. He moved to one
side. Again he swung the gold-colored ribbon.

10478.text:
He dangled it back and forth. Then he drew
back yet again and wrapped his left hand and

10484.text:
wrists with many turns of the thin bronze
spring, carefully spacing the turns. He moved

10491.text:
forward once more.
He came back, his expression showing no elation

10497.text:
at all.
"No good," he said unhappily. "In a way, it

10503.text:
works. The spring acts as an aerial and picks
up more of the beam than my hand. But I tried

10509.text:
to make a Faraday cage. That will stop most
electromagnetic radiation, but not this stuff!

10516.text:
It goes right through, like electrons through
a radio tube grid."

10522.text:
He put the spring back in his pocket.
"Well," he grimaced. "Let's go on again. I

10528.text:
had a little bit of hope, but some smarter
men than I am haven't got the right gimmick

10532.text:
yet."
They started off once more. And this time

10537.text:
they did not choose a path for easier travel,
but went up a steep slope that rose for hundreds

10543.text:
of feet to arrive at a crest with another
steep slope going downhill. At the top Lockley

10549.text:
said sourly, "I did discover one thing, if
it means anything. The beam leaks at its edges,

10557.text:
but it's only leakage. It doesn't diffuse.
It's tight. It's more like a searchlight beam

10563.text:
than anything else in that way. You can see
a light beam at night because dust motes scatter

10569.text:
some part of it. But most of the light goes
straight on. This stuff does the same. It's

10576.text:
hard to imagine a limit to its range."
He trudged on downhill. Jill followed him.

10583.text:
Presently, when they'd covered two miles or
more with no lightening of his expression,

10588.text:
she said, "You said you understand how it
works. Radio and radar beams don't have effects

10595.text:
like this. How does this have them?"
"It makes high frequency currents on the surface

10601.text:
of anything it hits. High frequency doesn't
go into flesh or metal. It travels on the

10607.text:
surface only. So when this beam hits a man
it generates high frequency on his skin. That

10615.text:
induces counter currents underneath, and they
stimulate all the sensory nerves we've got--of

10621.text:
our eyes and ears and noses as well as our
skin. Every nerve reports its own kind of

10627.text:
sensation. Run current over your tongue, and
you taste. Induce a current in your eyes,

10634.text:
and you see flashes of light. So the beam
makes all our senses report everything they're

10639.text:
capable of reporting, true or not, and we're
blinded and deafened. Then the nerves to our

10646.text:
muscles report to them that they're to contract,
and they do. So we're paralyzed."

10653.text:
"And," said Jill, "if there's a way to generate
high frequency on a man's skin there's nothing

10660.text:
that can be done?"
"Nothing," said Lockley dourly.

10664.text:
"Maybe," said Jill, "you can figure out a
way to prevent that high frequency generation."

10670.text:
He shrugged. Jill frowned as she followed
him. She hadn't forgotten Vale, but she owed

10678.text:
some gratitude to Lockley. Womanlike, she
tried to pay part of it by urging him to do

10684.text:
something he considered impossible.
"At least," she suggested, "it can't be a

10691.text:
death ray!"
Lockley looked at her.

10694.text:
"You're wrong there," he said coldly. "It
can."

10700.text:
Jill frowned again. Not because of his statement,
but because she hadn't succeeded in diverting

10706.text:
his mind from gloomy things. She had reason
enough for sadness, herself. If she spoke

10713.text:
of it, Lockley would try to encourage her.
But he was concerned with more than his own

10719.text:
emotions. Without really knowing it, Jill
had come to feel a great confidence in Lockley.

10725.text:
It had been reassuring that he could find
food, and perhaps more reassuring that he

10731.text:
could chase away a bear. Such talents were
not logical reasons for being confident that

10737.text:
he could solve the alien's seemingly invincible
weapon, but she was inclined to feel so. And

10745.text:
if she could encourage him to cope with the
monsters--why--it would be even a form of

10750.text:
loyalty to Vale. So she believed.
In the late afternoon Lockley said, "Another

10758.text:
four or five miles and we ought to be out
of the Park and on another highway we'll hope

10763.text:
won't be blocked by a terror beam. Anyhow
there should be an occasional farmhouse where

10769.text:
we can find some sort of civilized food."
Jill said hungrily, "Scrambled eggs!"

10776.text:
"Probably," he agreed.
They went on and on. Three miles. Four. Five.

10783.text:
Five and a half. They descended a minor slope
and came to a hard-surfaced road with tire

10788.text:
marks on it and a sign sternly urging care
in driving. There were ploughed fields in

10795.text:
which crops were growing. There was a row
of stubby telephone poles with a sagging wire

10800.text:
between them.
"We'll head west," said Lockley. "There ought

10805.text:
to be a farmhouse somewhere near."
"And people," said Jill. "I look terrible!"

10811.text:
He regarded her with approval.
"No. You look all right. You look fine!"

10818.text:
It was pleasing that he seemed to mean it.
But immediately she said, "Maybe we'll be

10823.text:
able to find out about ... about...."
"Vale," agreed Lockley. "But don't be disappointed

10830.text:
if we don't. He could have escaped or been
freed without everybody knowing it."

10836.text:
She said in surprise, "Been freed! That's
something I didn't think of. He'd set to work

10842.text:
to make them understand that we humans are
intelligent and they ought to make friends

10847.text:
with us. That would be the first thing he'd
think of. And they might set him free to arrange

10853.text:
it."
Lockley said, "Yes," in a carefully noncommittal

10859.text:
tone.
Another mile, this time on the hard road.

10864.text:
It seemed strange to walk on so unyielding
a surface after so many miles on quite different

10870.text:
kinds of footing. It was almost sunset now.
There was a farmhouse set well back from the

10876.text:
road and barely discernable beyond nearby
growing corn. The house seemed dead. It was

10883.text:
neat enough and in good repair. There were
clackings of chickens from somewhere behind

10889.text:
it. But it had the feel of emptiness.
Lockley called. He called again. He went to

10896.text:
the door and would have called once more,
but the door opened at a touch.

10901.text:
"Evacuated," he said. "Did you notice that
there was a telephone line leading here from

10906.text:
the road?"
He hunted in the now shadowy rooms. He found

10912.text:
the telephone. He lifted the receiver and
heard the humming of the line. He tried to

10916.text:
call an operator. He heard the muted buzz
that said the call was sounding. But there

10922.text:
was no answer. He found a telephone book and
dialed one number after another. Sheriff.

10928.text:
Preacher. Doctor. Garage. Operator again.
General store.... He could tell that telephones

10935.text:
rang dutifully in remote abandoned places.
But there was no answer at all.

10940.text:
"I'll look in the chicken coops," said Jill
practically.

10945.text:
She came back with eggs. She said briefly,
"The chickens were hungry. I fed them and

10951.text:
left the chicken yard gate open. I wonder
if the beam hurts them too?"

10956.text:
"It does," said Lockley.
He made a light and then a fire and she cooked

10963.text:
eggs which belonged to the unknown people
who owned this house and who had walked out

10968.text:
of it when instructions for immediate evacuation
came. They felt queer, making free with this

10975.text:
house of a stranger. They felt that he might
come in and be indignant with them.

10981.text:
"I ought to wash the dishes," said Jill when
they were finished.

10985.text:
"No," said Lockley. "We go on. We need to
find some soldiers, or a telephone that works...."

10993.text:
"I'm not a good dishwasher anyhow," said Jill
guiltily.

10999.text:
Lockley put a banknote on the kitchen table,
with a weight on it to keep it from blowing

11003.text:
away. They closed the house door. They'd eaten
fully and luxuriously of eggs and partly stale

11010.text:
bread and the sensation was admirable. They
went out to the highway again.

11016.text:
"West is still our best bet," said Lockley.
"They've blocked the highway to eastward with

11022.text:
that terror beam."
The sun had set now, but a fading glory remained

11027.text:
in the sky. They saw the slenderest, barest
crescent of a new moon practically hidden

11033.text:
in the sunset glow. They walked upon a civilized
road, with a fence on one side of it and above

11040.text:
it a single sagging telephone wire that could
be made out against the stars.

11046.text:
"I feel," said Jill, "as if we were almost
safe, now. All this looks so ordinary and

11054.text:
reassuring."
"But we'd better keep our noses alert," Lockley

11058.text:
told her. "We know that one beam comes nearly
this far and probably--no, certainly crosses

11066.text:
this road. There may be more."
"Oh, yes," agreed Jill. Then she said irrelevantly,

11073.text:
"I'll bet they do make him a sort of--ambassador
to our government to arrange for making friends.

11081.text:
He'll be able to convince them!"
Again she referred to Vale. Lockley said nothing.

11090.text:
Night was now fully fallen. There were myriad
stars overhead. They saw the telephone wire

11096.text:
dipping between poles against the sky's brightness.
They passed an open gate where another telephone

11103.text:
wire led away, doubtless to another farmhouse.
But if there was no one at the other end of

11109.text:
a telephone line, there was no point in using
a phone.

11114.text:
There came a rumbling noise behind them. They
stared at one another in the starlight. The

11120.text:
rumbling approached.
"It--can't be!" said Jill, marvelling.

11126.text:
"It's a motor," said Lockley. He could not
feel complete relief. "Sounds like a truck.

11133.text:
I wonder--"
He felt uneasiness. But it was absurd. Only

11138.text:
human beings would use motor trucks.
There was a glow in the distance behind them.

11144.text:
It came nearer as the sound of the motor approached.
The motor's mutter became a grumble. It was

11151.text:
definitely a truck. They could hear those
other sounds that trucks always make in addition

11156.text:
to their motor noises.
It came up to the curve they'd rounded last.

11161.text:
Its headlight beams glared on the cornstalks
growing next to the highway. One headlight

11167.text:
appeared around the turn. Then the other.
An enormous trailer-truck combination came

11172.text:
bumbling toward them. Jill held up her hand
for it to stop. Its headlights shone brightly

11178.text:
upon her.
Airbrakes came on. The giant combination--cab

11184.text:
in front, gigantic box body behind--came to
a halt. A man leaned out. He said amazedly,

11192.text:
"Hey, what are you folks doin' here? Everybody's
supposed to be long gone! Ain't you heard

11199.text:
about all civilians clearing out from twenty
miles outside the Park? There's boogers in

11204.text:
there! Characters from Mars or somewhere.
They eat people!"

11210.text:
Even in the starlight Lockley saw the familiar
Wild Life Control markings on the trailer.

11216.text:
He heard Jill, her voice shaking with relief,
explaining that she'd been at the construction

11222.text:
camp and had been left behind, and that she
and Lockley had made their way out.

11227.text:
"We want to get to a telephone," she added.
"He has some information he wants to give

11233.text:
to the Army. It's very important." Then she
swallowed. "And I'd like to ask if you've

11240.text:
heard anything about a Mr. Vale. He was taken
prisoner by the creatures up there. Have you

11246.text:
heard of his being released?"
The driver hesitated. Then he said, "No, ma'm.

11252.text:
Not a word about him. But we'll take care
of you two! You musta been through plenty!

11258.text:
Jud, you go get in the trailer, back yonder.
Make room for these two folks up on the front

11262.text:
seat." He added explanatorily, "There's cases
and stuff in the back, ma'm. You two folks

11270.text:
climb right up here alongside of me. You sure
musta had a time!"

11275.text:
The door on the near side of the truck cab
opened. A small man got out. Silently, he

11281.text:
went to the rear of the trailer and swung
up out of sight. Jill climbed into the opened

11287.text:
door. Lockley followed her. He still felt
an irrational uneasiness, but he put it down

11293.text:
to habit. The past few days had formed it.
"We've been cartin' stuff for the soldiers,"

11300.text:
explained the driver as Lockley closed the
door behind him. "They keep track of where

11305.text:
that terror beam is workin', and they tell
us by truck radio, and we dodge it. Ain't

11310.text:
had a bit of trouble. Never thought I'd play
games with Martians! Did you see any of 'em?

11316.text:
What sort of critters are they?"
He slipped the truck into gear and gunned

11321.text:
the motor. Truck and trailer, together, began
to roll down the highway. Lockley was irritated

11328.text:
with himself because he couldn't relax and
feel safe, as this development seemed to warrant.

11335.text:
Later, he would wonder why he hadn't used
his head in this as in other matters during

11341.text:
the few days just past.
He plainly hadn't.

11347.text:
CHAPTER 7
The driver was avidly curious about the area

11352.text:
where supposedly no human being could survive.
He asked absorbed questions, especially and

11359.text:
insistently about the aliens. Jill said that
she'd seen a few of them, but only at a distance.

11365.text:
They'd been investigating the evacuated construction
camp. They were about the size of men. She

11372.text:
couldn't describe them, but they weren't human
beings. He seemed to find it unthinkable that

11377.text:
she hadn't examined them in detail.
Lockley came to her rescue. He observed that

11383.text:
he'd been a prisoner of the invaders, and
had escaped. Then the driver's curiosity became

11390.text:
insatiable. He wanted to know every imaginable
detail of that experience. He expressed almost

11398.text:
incredulous disappointment that Lockley couldn't
give even a partial description of the creatures.

11405.text:
When convinced, he launched a detailed recital
of the descriptions offered by the workmen

11410.text:
from the camp. He pictured the aliens as hoofed
like horses, equipped with horns like antelopes,

11417.text:
fitted with multiple arms like octopi and
huge multi-faceted eyes like insects.

11425.text:
He seemed to contemplate this picture with
vast satisfaction as the truck growled and

11431.text:
rumbled through the night.
The headlights glared on ahead of the truck.

11435.text:
There were dark fields and darker mountains
beyond them. From time to time little side

11441.text:
roads branched off. They undoubtedly led to
houses, but no speck of lamp light appeared

11448.text:
anywhere. This part of the world was empty,
with the loneliness of a landscape from which

11454.text:
every hint of human activity had been removed.
Jill asked a question. The driver grew garrulous.

11461.text:
He gave a dramatic picture of terror throughout
the world, the suspension of all ordinary

11466.text:
antagonisms in the face of this menace to
every man and nation on the earth. There was

11473.text:
peace even in the world's trouble spots as
appalled agitators saw how much worse things

11479.text:
could be if the monsters took over the world
to rule. But the driver insisted that the

11485.text:
United States was calm. Us Americans, he assured
Lockley, weren't scared. We were educated

11493.text:
and we knew that them scientists would crack
this nut somehow. Like only yesterday a broadcast

11499.text:
said this Belgian guy had come up with calculations
that said this poison beam had to be something

11505.text:
like a radar beam or a laser beam or something
like that. And the American scientists were

11512.text:
right out there in front, along with guys
from England and France and Italy and Germany

11518.text:
and even Russia. All the big brains of the
world were workin' on it! Those Martians were

11524.text:
gonna wish they'd come visitin' polite instead
of barging in like they owned the world! They'd

11530.text:
be lucky if they wound up ownin' Mars!
Lockley pressed for details about the scientists'

11536.text:
results. He didn't expect to get them, but
the driver cheerfully obliged.

11541.text:
Radio, said the driver largely, worked by
making waves like those on a pond. They spread

11548.text:
out and reached places where there were instruments
to detect them, and that was that. Radar made

11554.text:
the same kind of waves, only smaller, which
bounced back to where there was an instrument

11559.text:
to detect them. These were ripple waves.
Lockley interpreted the term to mean sine

11566.text:
waves, rounded at top and trough. It was a
perfectly good word to express the meaning

11571.text:
intended.
These were natural kindsa waves, pursued the

11576.text:
driver. Lightning made them. Static was them,
and sparks from running motors and blown fuses.

11584.text:
Waves like that were generated whenever an
electric circuit was made or broken besides

11589.text:
their occurrence from purely natural causes.
"We can't feel 'em," said the driver expansively.

11596.text:
"We're used to waves like that. Animals couldn't
do anything about 'em and didn't need to before

11602.text:
there was men. So when we come along, we couldn't
notice 'em any more than we notice air pressure

11608.text:
on our skin. We're used to it! But these scientists
say there's waves that ain't natural. They

11615.text:
ain't like ripples. They're like storm waves
with foam on 'em. And that's the kind of waves

11621.text:
we can notice. Like storm waves with sharp
edges. We can notice them because they do

11627.text:
things to us! These Martians make 'em do things.
But now we know what kinda waves they are,

11634.text:
we're gonna mess them up! And I'm savin' up
a special kick for one o' those Martians when

11639.text:
they're licked just as soon as I can find
out which end of him is which an' suited to

11644.text:
that kinda attention!"
Lockley found himself suspicious and was annoyed.

11650.text:
Jill was safe now. This driver was well-informed,
but probably everybody was well-informed now.

11657.text:
They had reason to become so!
The truck trundled through the night. High

11662.text:
overhead, a squadron of planes arrived to
take its place in the ever-moving patrol around

11667.text:
the Park. Another squadron, relieved, went
away to the southwest. There was a deep-toned,

11674.text:
faraway roaring from the engines aloft. All
the sky behind the trailer seemed to mutter

11680.text:
continuously. But the roof of stars ahead
was silent.

11686.text:
Lockley stayed tense and was weary of his
tenseness, Jill was safe. He tried to reason

11693.text:
his uneasiness away. The cab of the truck
wobbled and swayed. The feel of the vehicle

11699.text:
was entirely unlike the feel of a passenger
car. It felt tail-heavy. The driver had ceased

11707.text:
to talk. He seemed to be musing as he drove.
He'd asked about the invaders but seemed almost

11714.text:
indifferent to any adventures Jill and Lockley
might have had on their way out. He didn't

11719.text:
ask what they'd done for food. He was thinking
of something else.

11725.text:
Lockley found himself questioning the driver's
statements just after they got in. Driving

11730.text:
for the Army. The Army kept track of where
the terror beams existed, and notified this

11736.text:
truck by truck radio, and he dodged all such
road barriers. That was what he said. It seemed

11744.text:
plausible, but--
"One thing strikes me funny," said the driver,

11750.text:
musingly. "Those critters blindfoldin' you
and those other guys. What' you think they

11756.text:
did it for?"
"To keep us from seeing them," said Lockley,

11760.text:
curtly.
"But why'd they want to do that?"

11764.text:
"Because," said Lockley, "they might not have
been Martians. They might not have been critters.

11778.text:
They might have been men."
On the instant he regretted bitterly that

11785.text:
he'd said it. It was a guess, only, with all
the evidence against it. The driver visibly

11792.text:
jumped. Then he turned his head.
"Where'd you get that idea?" he demanded.

11797.text:
"What's the evidence? Why d'you think it?"
"They blindfolded me," said Lockley briefly.

11804.text:
A pause. Then the driver said vexedly, "That's
a funny thing to make you think they was men!

11813.text:
Hell! Excuse me, ma'm!--they coulda had all
kindsa reasons for blindfoldin' you! It coulda

11818.text:
been part of their religion!"
"Maybe," said Lockley. He was angry with himself

11824.text:
for having said something which was needlessly
dramatic.

11828.text:
"Didn't you have any other reason for thinkin'
they were men?" demanded the driver curiously.

11834.text:
"No other reason at all?"
"No other at all," said Lockley.

11839.text:
"It's a crazy reason, if you ask me!"
"Quite likely," conceded Lockley.

11847.text:
He'd been indiscreet, but no more. He'd said
what he thought, perhaps because he was tired

11853.text:
of watching all the country round him for
a menace to Jill, and then watching every

11858.text:
word he spoke to keep her from abandoning
hope for Vale.

11862.text:
Jill said, "Where are we headed for? I hope
I can get to a telephone. I want to ask about

11869.text:
somebody.... He wants to tell the soldiers
something."

11871.text:
"We're headed for a army supply dump," said
the driver comfortably, "to load up with stuff

11878.text:
for the guys that're watching all around the
Park. We'll be goin' through Serena presently.

11884.text:
Funny. Everybody moved out by the Army. A
good thing, too. The folks in Maplewood couldn't

11891.text:
ha' been got out last night before the Martians
got there."

11895.text:
The trailer-truck went on through the night.
The driver lounged in his seat, keeping a

11900.text:
negligent but capable eye on the road ahead.
The headlights showed a place where another

11905.text:
road crossed this one and there was a filling
station, still and dark, and four or five

11911.text:
dwellings nearby with no single sign of life
about them. Then the crossroads settlement

11918.text:
fell behind. A mile beyond it Jill said startledly,
"Lights! There's a town. It's lighted."

11926.text:
"It's Serena," said the driver. "The street
lights are on because the electricity comes

11931.text:
from far away. With the lights on it's a marker
for the planes, too, so they can tell exactly

11937.text:
where they are and the Park too. They can't
see the ground so good at night, from away

11942.text:
up there."
The white street lamps seemed to twinkle as

11947.text:
the trailer-truck rumbled on. A single long
line of them appeared to welcome the big vehicle.

11953.text:
It went on into the town. It reached the business
district. There were side streets, utterly

11959.text:
empty, and then the main street divided. The
truck bore to the right. There were three

11964.text:
and four-story buildings. Every window was
blank and empty, reflecting only the white

11970.text:
street lamps. No living thing anywhere. There
had been no destruction, but the town was

11977.text:
dead. Its lights shone on streets so empty
that it would have seemed better to leave

11982.text:
them to the kindly dark.
Jill exclaimed, "Look! That window!"

11988.text:
And ahead, in the dead and lifeless town,
a single window glowed from electric light

11994.text:
inside it, and it looked lonelier than anything
else in the world.

11998.text:
"I'm gonna look into that!" said the driver.
"Nobody's supposed to be here."

12004.text:
The truck came to a stop. The driver got out.
There was a stirring, behind, and the small

12009.text:
man who'd given his place to Jill and Lockley
popped out of the trailer body. Lockley saw

12015.text:
the name of a local telephone company silhouetted
on the lighted windowpane. He opened the door.

12022.text:
Jill followed him instantly. The four of them--driver,
helper, Lockley and Jill--crowded into the

12028.text:
building hallway to investigate the one lighted
room in a town where twenty thousand people

12034.text:
were supposed to live.
There was a door with a frosted glass top

12038.text:
through which light showed. The driver turned
the door-knob and marched in. The room had

12044.text:
an alcoholic smell. A man with sunken cheeks
slept heavily in a chair, his head forward

12050.text:
on his chest.
The driver shook him.

12054.text:
"Wake up, guy!" he said sternly. "Orders are
for all civilians to clear outa this town.

12060.text:
You wanna soldier to come by an' take you
for a looter an' bump you off?"

12064.text:
He shook again. The cadaverous man blinked
his eyes open. The smell of alcohol was distinct.

12072.text:
He was drunk. He gazed ferociously up at the
driver of the truck.

12076.text:
"Who the hell are you?" he demanded belligerently.
The driver spoke sternly, repeating what he'd

12083.text:
said before. The drunk assumed an air of outraged
dignity.

12088.text:
"If I wanna stay here, that's my business!
Who th' hell are you anyways, disturbin' a

12094.text:
citizen tax-payer on his lawful occasions?
Are you Martians? I wouldn't put it pasht

12101.text:
you!"
He sat down and went back to sleep.

12105.text:
The driver said fretfully, "He oughtn't to
be here! But we ain't got room to carry him.

12111.text:
I'm gonna use the truck radio an' ask what
to do. Maybe they'll send a Army truck to

12116.text:
get him outa here. He could set the whole
town on fire!"

12120.text:
He went out. The small man who was his helper
followed him. He hadn't spoken a word. Lockley

12127.text:
growled. Then Jill said breathlessly, "The
switch-board has some long distance lines.

12133.text:
I know how to connect them. Shall I try?"
Lockley agreed emphatically. Jill slipped

12139.text:
into the operator's chair and donned the headset.
She inserted a plug and pressed a switch.

12145.text:
"I did an article once on how--Hello! Serena
calling. I have a very important message for

12151.text:
the military officer in command of the cordon.
Will you route me through, please?"

12157.text:
Her manner was convincingly professional.
She looked up and smiled shakily at Lockley.

12163.text:
She spoke again into the mouthpiece before
her. Then she said, "One moment, please."

12169.text:
She covered the mouthpiece with her hand.
"I can't get the general," she said. "His

12174.text:
aide will take the message and if it's important
enough--"

12177.text:
"It is," said Lockley. "Give me the phone."
She vacated the chair and handed him the operator's

12184.text:
instrument with its light weight earphones
and a mouthpiece that rested on his chest.

12190.text:
"My name's Lockley," said Lockley evenly.
"I was in the Park on a Survey job the morning

12196.text:
the thing came down from the sky. I relayed
Vale's message describing the landing and

12203.text:
the creatures that came out of the--object.
I was talking to him by microwave when he

12208.text:
was seized by them. I reported that via Sattell
of the Survey. You probably know of these

12215.text:
reports."
A tinny voice said with formal cordiality

12219.text:
that he did, indeed.
"I've just managed to get out of the park,"

12224.text:
said Lockley. "I've had a chance to experiment
with a stationary terror beam. I've information

12230.text:
of some importance about detecting those beams
before they strike."

12234.text:
The tinny voice said hastily that Lockley
should speak to the general himself. There

12240.text:
were clickings and a long wait. Lockley shook
his head impatiently. When a new voice spoke,

12247.text:
he said, "I'm at Serena. I was brought here
by a Wild Life Control trailer-truck which

12253.text:
picked us up just outside the Park. I mention
that because the driver says he's driving

12259.text:
it for the Army, now. The information I have
to pass on is...."

12263.text:
Curtly and succinctly, he began to give exact
information about the terror beam. Its detection

12271.text:
so that one need not enter it. The total lack
of effectiveness of a Faraday cage to check

12276.text:
it. Its use to block highways and its one
use against a low-flying plane. The failure

12283.text:
to search him out with that terror beam was
to be noted. There was other evidence that

12288.text:
the monsters were not monsters at all--
The new voice interrupted sharply. It asked

12294.text:
him to wait. His information would be recorded.
Lockley waited, biting his lips. The voice

12301.text:
returned after an unconscionably long wait.
It told him to go ahead.

12307.text:
The driver of the truck was taking a long
time to make contact with the military. He'd

12313.text:
have done better by telephone instead of short
wave.

12317.text:
The new voice repeated sharply for Lockley
to go on with his story. And very, very carefully

12323.text:
Lockley explained the contradictions in the
behavior of the invaders. The blindfolds.

12330.text:
The fact that it had been absurdly easy for
four human prisoners in a compost pit shell

12336.text:
to escape--almost as if it were intended for
them to get away and report that their captors

12342.text:
regarded men as on a par with game birds and
rabbits and porcupines. True aliens would

12349.text:
not have bothered to give such an impression.
But men cooperating with aliens would contrive

12355.text:
every possible trick to insist that only aliens
operated at Boulder Lake.

12360.text:
"I'm saying," said Lockley carefully, "that
they do not act like aliens making a first

12366.text:
landing on earth. Apparently their ship is
designed to land in deep water. On a first

12372.text:
landing, they should have chosen the sea.
But they knew Boulder Lake was deep enough

12377.text:
to cushion their descent. How did they know
it? They didn't kill us local animals for

12383.text:
study, but they dropped in other local animals
to convince us that they wouldn't mind. Why

12388.text:
try to fill us with horror--and then let us
escape?"

12392.text:
The voice at the other end said sharply, "What
do you infer from all this?"

12397.text:
"They've been briefed," said Lockley. "They
know too much about this planet and us humans.

12404.text:
Somebody has told them about human psychology
and suggested that they conquer us without

12409.text:
destroying our cities or our factories or
our usefulness as slaves. We'll be much more

12416.text:
valuable if captured that way! I'm saying
that they've got humans advising and cooperating

12422.text:
with them! I'm suggesting that those humans
have made a deal to run earth for the aliens,

12428.text:
paying them all the tribute they can demand.
I'm saying that we're not up against an invasion

12434.text:
only by aliens, but by aliens with humans
in active cooperation and acting not only

12441.text:
as advisers but probably as spies. I'm--"
"Mr. Lockley!" said the voice at the other

12449.text:
end of the wire. It was startled and shocked.
It became pompous. "Mr. Lockley, what has

12457.text:
been your training?" The voice did not wait
for an answer. "Where have you become qualified

12463.text:
to offer opinions contradicting all the information
and all the decisions of scientists and military

12470.text:
men alike? Where do you get the authority
to make such statements? They are preposterous!

12476.text:
You have wasted my time! You--"
Lockley reached over and flipped back the

12482.text:
switch he'd seen Jill flip over. He carefully
put down the headset. He stood up.

12489.text:
The driver and the small man came back. They
picked up the sleeping drunk and moved toward

12494.text:
the door. Something fell out of the drunk's
pocket. It was a wallet. They did not notice.

12501.text:
They went out, carrying the drunk. Jill stooped
and recovered it. She looked at Lockley's

12508.text:
"I'm trying," said Lockley in a grating voice,
"to figure out what to do next. That didn't

12516.text:
work."
"I'll be right back," said Jill.

12519.text:
She went out to deliver the wallet to the
driver, who had apparently been ordered to

12523.text:
put the drunk in the trailer body and deliver
him somewhere.

12528.text:
Lockley swore explosively when she was gone.
He clenched and unclenched his hands. He paced

12534.text:
the length of the room.
Jill came back, her face white.

12539.text:
"They opened the door of the trailer to pass
him in," she said in a thin, strained voice.

12546.text:
"And there were other men back there. Several
of them! And machinery! Not cages for animals

12558.text:
"And I," said Lockley, "am a fool. I should
have known it! Look here--"

12565.text:
The frosted-glass door opened. The driver
came back. He had a revolver in his hand.

12571.text:
"Too bad!" he said calmly. "We should've been
more careful. But the lady saw too much. Now--"

12580.text:
The revolver bore on Lockley. Jill flung herself
upon it. Lockley swung, with every ounce of

12587.text:
his strength. He connected with the driver's
jaw. The driver went limp. Lockley had the

12592.text:
revolver almost before he reached the floor.
"Quick!" he snapped. "Where was the machinery?

12599.text:
Front or back part of the trailer?"
"All of it," panted Jill. "Mostly front. What--"

12605.text:
"The hall again," Lockley snapped. "Hunt for
a back door!"

12609.text:
He thrust her out. She fumbled toward the
back of the building while he went to the

12614.text:
street entrance. The trailer-truck loomed
huge. The driver's helper came out of it.

12620.text:
Another man followed him. Still another....
Lockley fired from the doorway. One bullet

12626.text:
through the front part of the truck. One near
the middle. Then a third halfway between the

12631.text:
first two. The three men dived to the ground,
thinking themselves his targets. But Jill

12638.text:
called inarticulately from the back of the
dark hall. Lockley raced back to her. He saw

12645.text:
starlight. She waited, shivering. They went
out and he closed the door softly behind him.

12652.text:
He took her hand and they ran through the
night. Overhead there was a luminous mistiness

12657.text:
because of the street light, but here were
abysmal darknesses between vague areas on

12663.text:
which the starlight fell. Lockley said evenly,
"We've got to be quiet. Maybe I hit some of

12670.text:
the machinery. Maybe. If I didn't, it's all
over!"

12675.text:
The back of a building. An alleyway. They
ran down it. There was a street with trees,

12681.text:
where the street lights cast utterly black
shadows in between intolerable glare. They

12686.text:
ran across the street. On the other side were
residences--the business district was not

12692.text:
large. Lockley found a gate, and opened it
quietly and as quietly closed it behind them.

12699.text:
They ran into a lane between two dead, dark,
dreary structures in which people had lived

12705.text:
but from which all life was now gone.
A back yard. A fence. Lockley helped Jill

12712.text:
get over it. Another lane. Another street.
But this street was not crossed--not here,

12718.text:
anyhow--by another which led back to the street
of the telephone office. A man could not look

12724.text:
from there and see them running under the
lights.

12727.text:
The blessed irregularity of the streets continued.
They ran and ran until Jill's breath came

12733.text:
in pantings. Lockley was drenched in sweat
because he expected at any instant to smell

12740.text:
the most loathesome of all possible combinations
of odors, and then to see flashing lights

12746.text:
originating in his own eyes, and sounds which
would exist only in the nerves of his ears,

12753.text:
and then to feel all his muscles knot in total
and horrible paralysis.

12759.text:
They heard the truck motor rumble into life
when they were many blocks away. They heard

12764.text:
the clumsy vehicle move. It continued to growl,
and they knew that it was moving about the

12770.text:
streets with its occupants trying to sight
fleeing figures under the darknesses which

12775.text:
were trees.
"I hit--I hit the generator," panted Lockley.

12782.text:
"I must have! Else they'd swing a beam on
us!"

12786.text:
He stopped. Here they were in a district where
many large homes pooled their lawns in block-long

12792.text:
stretches of soft green. The street lights
cast arbitrary patches of brightness against

12798.text:
the houses, but their windows were blank and
dark. This street, like most in this small

12804.text:
town, was lined with trees on either side.
There were the fragrances of flowers and grass.

12811.text:
"We aren't safe now," said Lockley, "but I
just found out there may not be any safety

12820.text:
"What will we do? What was that machinery?
I felt--frightened because it wasn't what

12827.text:
he said was back there. So I told you. But
what was it?".

12832.text:
"At a guess," said Lockley, "a terror beam
generator. The invaders must have human friends.

12840.text:
To us they're spies. They're cooperating with
the monsters. Apparently they're even trusted

12847.text:
with terror beam projectors."
He stood still, thinking, while in the distance

12853.text:
the trailer-truck ground and rumbled about
the streets. It was not a very promising method

12859.text:
for finding two fugitives. They could hide
if it turned onto a street they used. It could

12865.text:
not continue the search indefinitely. The
most likely final course would be to leave

12871.text:
some of the unknown number of men in its trailer
to search the town on foot. Even that might

12877.text:
not be successful. But it wouldn't be a good
idea for Lockley and Jill to remain here,

12883.text:
either.
"We look for two-car garages," said Lockley.

12886.text:
"It's not a good chance, but it's all we've
got. If somebody had two cars, they might

12893.text:
have left one behind when they evacuated.
I can jump an ignition switch if necessary.

12899.text:
Meanwhile we'll be moving out of town, which
is a good idea even if we do it on foot!"

12905.text:
They ceased to use the streets with their
dramatic contrast of vivid lights with total

12911.text:
shadows. They moved behind a row of what would
be considered mansions in Serena, Colorado.

12918.text:
Sometimes they stumbled over flower beds,
and once there was a hose over which Jill

12922.text:
tripped, and once Lockley barked his shin
on a garden wheelbarrow. Most of the garages

12928.text:
were empty or contained only tools and garden
equipment.

12934.text:
Then something made Lockley look up. A slender,
truss-braced, mastlike tower rose skyward.

12942.text:
It began on the lawn of a house with wide
porches. There was a two-car garage with one

12947.text:
wide door open.
"A radio ham," said Lockley. "I wonder--"

12954.text:
But he looked first in the garage. There was
a car. It looked all right. He climbed in

12959.text:
and opened the door. The dome light came on.
The key was still in the ignition. He turned

12966.text:
it and the gauge showed that the gas tank
was three-quarters full. This was unbelievable

12971.text:
good fortune.
"They probably intended to use this and then

12976.text:
changed their minds," said Lockley. "I'll
get the door open and attempt a little burglary.

12982.text:
Just one burglary with a prayer that he used
a storage battery for his power!"

12989.text:
Breaking in was simple. He tried the windows
opening on the main wide porch. One window

12994.text:
slid up. He went inside, Jill following.
The ham radio outfit was in the cellar. Like

13001.text:
most radio hams, this one had battery-powered
equipment as a matter of public responsibility.

13007.text:
In case of storm or disaster when power lines
are down, the ham operators of the United

13013.text:
States can function as emergency communication
systems, working without outside power. This

13020.text:
operator was equipped as membership in the
organization required.

13026.text:
Lockley warmed up the tubes. He tuned to a
general call frequency. He began to say, "May

13032.text:
Day! May Day! May Day!" in a level voice.
This emergency call has precedence over all

13041.text:
other calls but S.O.S., which has an identical
meaning. But "May Day" is more distinct and

13048.text:
unmistakable when heard faintly.
There were answers within minutes. Lockley

13054.text:
snapped for them to stay tuned while he called
for others. He had half a dozen hams waiting

13059.text:
curiously when he began to broadcast what
he wanted the world to know.

13063.text:
He told it as briefly and as convincingly
as he could. Then he said, "Over" and threw

13070.text:
the reception switch for questions.
There were no questions. His broadcast had

13076.text:
been jammed. Some other station or stations
were transmitting pure static with deafening

13082.text:
volume, evidently from somewhere nearby. Lockley
could not tell when it had begun. It could

13090.text:
have been from the instant he began to speak.
It was very likely that not one really useful

13096.text:
word had been heard anywhere.
But a direction finder could have betrayed

13108.text:
It was a ticklish job getting the car out
of the garage and into the street. Lockley

13112.text:
was afraid that starting the motor would make
a noise which in the silence of the town's

13117.text:
absolute abandonment could be heard for a
long way. The grinding of the starter, though,

13123.text:
lasted only for seconds. It might make men
listen, but they could hardly locate it before

13128.text:
the motor caught and ran quietly. Also, the
trailer-truck was still in motion and making

13134.text:
its own noise. Of course it was probably posting
watchers and listeners here and there to try

13140.text:
to find Lockley and Jill.
So Lockley backed the car into the street

13145.text:
as silently as was possible. He did not turn
on the lights. He stopped, headed away from

13151.text:
the area in which the truck rumbled. He sent
the car forward at a crawl. Then an idea occurred

13158.text:
to him and cold chills ran down his spine.
It is possible to use a short wave receiver

13165.text:
to pick up the ignition sparks of a car. Normally
such sparkings are grounded so the car's own

13171.text:
radio will work. But sometimes a radio is
out of order. It was characteristic of Lockley's

13178.text:
acquired distrust of luck and chance that
he thought of so unlikely a disaster.

13183.text:
He eased the car into motion, straining his
ears for any sign that the truck reacted.

13190.text:
Then he moved the car slowly away from the
business district. It required enormous self-control

13196.text:
to go slowly. While among the lighted streets
the urge to flee at top speed was strong.

13203.text:
But he clenched his teeth. A car makes much
less noise when barely in motion. He made

13209.text:
it drift as silently as a wraith under the
trees and the street lamps.

13214.text:
They got out of town. The last of the street
lamps was behind them. There was only starlight

13220.text:
ahead, and an unknown road with many turns
and curves. Sometimes there were roadsigns,

13228.text:
dimly visible as uninformative shapes beside
the highway. They warned of curves and other

13234.text:
driving hazards, but they could not be read
because Lockley drove without lights. He left

13240.text:
the car dark because any glare would have
been visible to the men of the trailer-truck

13244.text:
for a very long way.
Starlight is not good for fast driving, and

13250.text:
when a road passes through a wooded space
it is nerve-racking. Lockley drove with foreboding,

13256.text:
every sense alert and every muscle tense.
But just after a painful progress through

13262.text:
a series of curves with high trees on either
side which he managed by looking up at the

13267.text:
sky and staying under the middle of the ribbon
of stars he could see, Lockley touched the

13272.text:
brake and stopped the car.
"What's the matter?" asked Jill, as he rummaged

13278.text:
under the instrument panel.
"I think," said Lockley, "that I must have

13283.text:
damaged something in that truck. Otherwise
they'd have turned their beam on us just to

13287.text:
get even.
"But maybe they'll be able to make a repair.

13291.text:
In any case there are other beams. Those are
probably stationary and the truck knows where

13297.text:
they are and calls by truck radio to have
them shut off when it wants to go by. That

13302.text:
would work. Using the Wild Life truck was
really very clever."

13308.text:
He wrenched at something. It gave. He pulled
out a length of wire and started working on

13314.text:
one end of it.
"If they guess we got a car," he observed,

13318.text:
"they'll expect us to run into a road block
beam that would wreck the car and paralyze

13323.text:
us. I'm taking a small precaution against
that. Here." He put the wire's end into her

13329.text:
hand. "It's the lead-in from this car's radio
antenna. It ought to warn us of beams across

13335.text:
the road as my watch spring did in the hills.
Hold it."

13339.text:
"I will," said Jill.
"One more item," he said. He got out of the

13344.text:
car and closed the door quickly. He went to
the back. There was the sound of breaking

13349.text:
glass. He returned, saying, "No brake lights
will go on now. I'll try to do something about

13355.text:
that dome light." With a sharp blow he shattered
it. "Now we could be as hard to trail as that

13362.text:
Wild Life truck was the other night."
Jill groped as the car got into motion again.

13368.text:
"You mean it was--Oh!"
"Most likely," agreed Lockley, "it was the

13375.text:
thing that went out of the park and occupied
Maplewood, flinging terror beams in all directions.

13381.text:
Some of the truck's crew would have had footgear
to make hoofprints. They committed a token

13387.text:
burglary or two. And there was the illusion
of aliens studying these queer creatures,

13393.text:
men."
They went on at not more than fifteen miles

13396.text:
an hour. The car was almost soundless. They
heard insects singing in the night. There

13402.text:
was a steady, monotonous rumbling high above
where Air Force planes patrolled outside the

13408.text:
Park. After a time Jill said, "You seemed
discouraged when you talked to that general."

13415.text:
"I was," said Lockley. "I am. He played it
safe, refused to admit that anybody in authority

13423.text:
over him could possibly be mistaken. That's
sound policy, and I was contradicting the

13429.text:
official opinion of his superiors. I've got
to find somebody of much lower rank, or much

13436.text:
higher. Maybe--"
Jill said in a strained voice, "Stop!"

13441.text:
He braked. She said unsteadily, "Holding the
wire, I smell that horrible smell."

13449.text:
He put his hand on the wire's end. He shared
the sensation.

13454.text:
"Terror beam across the highway," he said
calmly. "Maybe on our account, maybe not.

13461.text:
But there was a side road a little way back."
He backed the car. He'd smashed the backing

13466.text:
lights, too. He guided himself by starlight.
Presently he swung the wheel and faced the

13472.text:
car about. He drove back the way he had come.
A mile or so, and there was another hard-surface

13478.text:
road branching off. He took it. Half an hour
later Jill said quickly, "Brakes!"

13486.text:
The road was blocked once more by an invisible
terror beam, into which any car moving at

13492.text:
reasonable speed must move before its driver
could receive warning.

13497.text:
"This isn't good," he said coldly. "They may
have picked some good places to block. We

13504.text:
have to go almost at random, just picking
roads that head away from the Park. I don't

13509.text:
know how thoroughly they can cage us in, though."
There was a flicker of light in the sky. Lockley

13515.text:
jerked his head around. It flashed again.
Lightning. The sky was clouding up.

13521.text:
"It's getting worse," he said in a strained
voice. "I've been taking every turn that ought

13527.text:
to lead us away from the Park, but I've had
to use the stars for direction. I didn't think

13532.text:
that soldiers would keep us from getting away
from here. I was almost confident. But what

13538.text:
will I do without the stars?"
He drove on. The clouds piled up, blotting

13543.text:
out the heavens. Once Lockley saw a faint
glow in the sky and clenched his teeth. He

13550.text:
turned away from it at the first opportunity.
The glow could be Serena, and he could have

13556.text:
been forced back toward it by the windings
of the highway he'd followed without lights.

13561.text:
Twice Jill warned him of beams across the
highway. Once, driven by his increasing anxiety,

13568.text:
his brakes almost failed to stop him in time.
When the car did stop, he was aware of faint

13574.text:
tinglings on his skin. There were erratic
flashings in his eyes, too, and a discordant

13580.text:
composite of sounds which by association with
past suffering made him nauseated. Perhaps

13588.text:
this extra leakage from the terror beam was
through the metal of the car.

13592.text:
When he got out of that terror beam the sky
was three-quarters blacked out and before

13597.text:
he was well away from the spot there was only
a tiny patch of stars well down toward the

13603.text:
horizon. There were lightning flickers overhead.
After a time he depended on them to show him

13609.text:
the road.
Then the rain came. The lightning increased.

13614.text:
The road twisted and turned. Twice the car
veered off onto the road's shoulders, but

13619.text:
each time he righted it. As time passed conditions
grew worse. It was urgent that he get as far

13627.text:
as possible from Serena, because of the Wild
Life truck which could seize Jill and himself

13632.text:
if its beam generators were repaired, and
whose occupants could murder them if they

13638.text:
weren't. But it was most urgent that he get
away beyond the military cordon to find men

13643.text:
who would listen to his information and see
that use was made of it. Yet in driving rain

13649.text:
and darkness, without car lights and daring
to drive only at a crawl, he might be completely

13655.text:
turned around.
"I think," he said at last, "I'll turn in

13660.text:
at the next farm gate the lightning shows
us. I'll try to get the car into a barn so

13665.text:
it won't show up at daybreak. We might be
heading straight back into the Park!"

13670.text:
He did turn, the next time a lightning flash
showed him a turn-off beside a rural free

13674.text:
delivery mailbox. There was a house at the
end of a lane. There was a barn. He got out

13680.text:
and was soaked instantly, but he explored
the open space behind the wide, open doors.

13685.text:
He backed the car in.
"So," he explained to Jill, "if we have a

13690.text:
chance to move we won't have to back around
first."

13693.text:
They sat in the car and looked out at the
rain-filled darkness. There was no light anywhere

13700.text:
except when lightning glittered on the rain.
In such illuminations they made out the farmhouse,

13706.text:
dripping floods of water from its eaves. There
was a chicken house. There were fences. They

13712.text:
could not see to the gate or the highway through
the falling water, but there had been solid

13717.text:
woodland where they turned off into the lane.
"We'll wait," said Lockley distastefully,

13724.text:
"to see if we are in a tight spot in the morning.
If we're well away--and I've no real idea

13730.text:
where we are--we'll go on. If not, we'll hide
till dark and hope for stars to steer by when

13736.text:
we go."
Jill said confidently, "We'll make it. But

13741.text:
where to?"
"To any place away from Boulder Lake Park,

13745.text:
and where I'm a human being instead of a crackpot
civilian. To where I can explain some things

13750.text:
to people who'll listen, if it isn't too late."
"It's not," said Jill with as much assurance

13757.text:
as before.
There was a pause. The rain poured down. Lightning

13763.text:
flashed. Thunder roared.
"I didn't know," said Jill tentatively, "that

13770.text:
you believed the invaders--the monsters--had
people helping them."

13774.text:
"The overall picture isn't a human one," he
told her. "But there's a design that shows

13780.text:
somebody knows us. For instance, nobody's
been killed. At least not publicly. That was

13787.text:
arranged by somebody who understood that if
there was a massacre, we'd fight to the end

13792.text:
of our lives and teach our children to fight
after us."

13796.text:
She thought it over. "You'd be that way,"
she said presently. "But not everybody. Some

13803.text:
people will do anything to stay alive. But
you wouldn't."

13807.text:
The rain made drumming sounds on the barn
roof. Lockley said, "But what's happened isn't

13813.text:
altogether what humans would devise. Humans
who planned a conquest would know they couldn't

13819.text:
make us surrender to them. If this was a sort
of Pearl Harbor attack by human enemies--and

13825.text:
you can guess who it might be--they might
as well start killing us on the largest possible

13830.text:
scale at the beginning. If monsters with no
information about us landed, they might perpetrate

13836.text:
some massacres with the entirely foolish idea
of cowing us. But there haven't been any massacres.

13844.text:
So it's neither a cold war trick nor an unadvised
landing of monsters. There's another angle

13851.text:
in it somewhere. Monster-human cooperation
is only a guess. I'm not satisfied, but it's

13858.text:
the best answer so far."
Jill was silent for a long time. Then she

13863.text:
said irrelevantly, "You must have been a good
friend of ... of...."

13869.text:
"Vale?" Lockley said. "No. I knew him, but
that's all. He only joined the Survey a few

13875.text:
months ago. I don't suppose I've talked to
him a dozen times, and four of those times

13881.text:
he was with you. Why'd you think we were close
friends?"

13885.text:
"What you've done for me," she said in the
darkness.

13890.text:
He waited for a lightning flash to show him
her expression. She was looking at him.

13895.text:
"I didn't do it for Vale," said Lockley.
"Then why?"

13900.text:
"I'd have done it for anyone," said Lockley
ungraciously.

13905.text:
In a way it was true, of course. But he wouldn't
have gone up to the construction camp to make

13910.text:
sure that anyone hadn't been left behind.
The idea wouldn't have occurred to him.

13916.text:
"I don't think that's true," said Jill.
He did not answer. If Vale was alive, Jill

13924.text:
was engaged to him; although if matters worked
out, Lockley would not be such a fool as to

13929.text:
play the gentleman and let her marry Vale
by default. On the other hand, if Vale was

13935.text:
dead, he wouldn't be the kind of fool who'd
try to win her for himself before she'd faced

13941.text:
and recovered from Vale's death. A girl could
forgive herself for breaking her engagement

13946.text:
to a living man, but not for disloyalty to
a dead one.

13951.text:
"I think," said Lockley deliberately, "that
we should change the subject. I will talk

13957.text:
about why I went to the Lake after you when
everything has settled down. I had reasons.

13962.text:
I still have them. I will express them, eventually,
whether Vale likes it or not. But not now."

13970.text:
There was a long silence, while rain fell
with heavy drumming noises and the world was

13976.text:
only a deep curtain of lightning-lighted droplets
of falling water.

13980.text:
"Thanks," said Jill very quietly. "I'm glad."
And then they sat in silence while the long

13989.text:
hours went by. Eventually they dozed. Lockley
was awakened by the ending of the rain. It

13996.text:
was then just the beginning of gray dawn.
The sky was still filled with clouds. The

14002.text:
ground was soaked. There were puddles here
and there in the barnyard, and water dripped

14007.text:
from the barn's eaves, and from the now vaguely
visible house, and from the two or three trees

14013.text:
beside it.
Lockley opened the car door and got out quietly.

14018.text:
Jill did not waken. He visited the chicken
house, and horrendous squawkings came out

14023.text:
of it. He found eggs. He went to the house,
stepping gingerly from grass patch to grass

14029.text:
patch, avoiding the puddles between them.
He found bread, jars of preserves and cans

14035.text:
of food. He inspected the lane. The car's
tracks had been washed out. He nodded to himself.

14043.text:
He went back to the barn. There was still
only dusky half-light. He pulled the doors

14048.text:
almost shut behind him, leaving only a four-inch
gap to see through. Now the car was safely

14055.text:
out of sight and there was no sign that any
living being was near.

14059.text:
"You closed the doors," said Jill. "Why?"
He said reluctantly, "I'm afraid we're as

14067.text:
badly off as we were at the beginning. Unless
I'm mistaken, we got turned around in that

14072.text:
rainstorm on those twisty roads, and the Park
begins nearby. This isn't the highway I drove

14079.text:
up on to find you, the one where my car's
wrecked. This is another one. I don't think

14085.text:
we're more than twenty miles from the Lake,
here. And that's something I didn't intend!"

14092.text:
He began to unload his pockets.
"I got something for us to eat. Well just

14097.text:
have to lie low until night and fumble our
way out toward the cordon, with the stars

14101.text:
to guide us."
There was silence, save for the lessened dripping

14107.text:
of water. Lockley was filled with a sort of
baffled impatience with himself. He felt that

14114.text:
he'd acted like an idiot in trying to escape
the evacuated area by car. But there'd been

14119.text:
nothing else to do. Before that he'd stupidly
been unsuspicious when the Wild Life truck

14126.text:
came down a highway that he'd known was blocked
by a terror beam. And perhaps he'd been a

14131.text:
fool to refuse to discuss why he'd gone up
to the construction camp to see to her safety

14137.text:
when by all the rules of reason it was none
of his business.

14142.text:
The gray light paled a little. Through the
gap between the barn doors, he could see past

14147.text:
the house. Then he could see the length of
the lane and the trees on the far side of

14151.text:
the highway.
He was laying out the food when suddenly he

14157.text:
froze, listening. The stillness of just-before-dawn
was broken by the distant rumble of an internal-combustion

14165.text:
engine. It was a familiar kind of rumbling.
It drew nearer. Except for the singularly

14171.text:
distinct impacts of drippings from leaves
and roof to the ground below, it was the only

14176.text:
sound in all the world.
It became louder. Jill clenched her hands

14182.text:
unconsciously.
"I don't think there are any car tracks at

14186.text:
the turn-off where we came in," said Lockley
in a level voice. "The rain should have washed

14191.text:
them out. It's not likely they're looking
for us here anyhow. But I've only got three

14197.text:
bullets left in the pistol. Maybe you'd better
go off and hide in the cornfield. Then if

14202.text:
things go wrong they'll believe I left you
somewhere."

14206.text:
"No," said Jill composedly, "I'd leave tracks
in the ploughed ground. They'd find me."

14213.text:
Lockley ground his teeth. He got out the pistol
he'd taken from the truck driver in the lighted

14218.text:
room in Serena. He looked at it grimly. It
would be useless, but....

14224.text:
Jill came and stood beside him, watching his
face.

14227.text:
The rumbling of the truck was still nearer
and louder. It diminished for a moment where

14232.text:
a curve in the road took the vehicle behind
some trees that deadened its noise. But then

14237.text:
the sound increased suddenly. It was very
loud and frighteningly near.

14243.text:
Lockley watched through the gap between the
barn doors. He stayed well back lest his face

14248.text:
be seen.
The trailer-truck with the Wild Life Control

14253.text:
markings on it rumbled past. It growled and
roared. The noise seemed thunderous. Its wheels

14260.text:
splashed as they went through a puddle close
by the gate.

14264.text:
It went away into the distance. Jill took
a deep breath of relief. Lockley made a warning

14270.text:
gesture.
He listened. The noise went on steadily for

14274.text:
what he guessed to be a mile or more. Then
they heard it stop. Only by straining his

14281.text:
ears could Lockley pick up the sound of an
idling motor. Maybe that was imagination.

14288.text:
Certainly at any other less silent time he
could not possibly have heard it. Jill whispered,

14293.text:
"Do you think--"
He gestured for silence again. The distant

14299.text:
heavy engine continued to idle. One minute.
Two. Three. Then the grinding of gears and

14306.text:
the roar of the engine once more. The truck
went on. Its sound diminished. It faded away

14312.text:
altogether.
"They got to a place where the road's blocked

14317.text:
with a terror beam," said Lockley evenly.
"They stopped and called by short wave and

14322.text:
the beam was cut off, then they went past
the block-point and undoubtedly the beam was

14328.text:
turned on again."
He debated a decision.

14332.text:
"We'll have breakfast," he said shortly. "We'll
have to eat the eggs raw, but we need to eat.

14339.text:
Then we'll figure things out. It may be that
we'd be sensible to forget about cars and

14344.text:
try to get to the cordon on foot, robbing
farmhouses of food on the way. There can't

14349.text:
be too many ... collaborators. And we could
keep out of sight."

14354.text:
He opened a jar of preserves.
"But it would be better for you to be travelling

14359.text:
by car, if tonight's clear and there's starlight
to drive by."

14364.text:
Jill said practically, "There might be some
news...."

14369.text:
Her hands shook as she put the pocket radio
on the hood of the car. Lockley noticed it.

14375.text:
He felt, himself, the strain of their long
march through the wilderness with danger in

14380.text:
every breath they drew. And he was shaken
in a different way by the proof that humans

14386.text:
were cooperating fully with the invading monsters.
It was unthinkable that anybody could be a

14392.text:
traitor not only to his own country but to
all the human race. He felt incredulous. It

14400.text:
couldn't be true! But it obviously was.
The radio made noises. Lockley turned it in

14407.text:
another direction. There was music. Jill's
face worked. She struggled not to show how

14413.text:
she felt.
The radio said, "Special news bulletin! Special

14419.text:
news bulletin! The Pentagon announces that
for the first time there has been practically

14424.text:
complete success in duplicating the terror
beam used by the space invaders at Boulder

14429.text:
Lake! Working around the clock, teams of foreign
and American scientists have built a projector

14435.text:
of what is an entirely new type of electronic
radiation which produces every one of the

14440.text:
physiological effects of the alien terror
beam! It is low-power, so far, and has not

14446.text:
produced complete paralysis in experimental
animals. Volunteers have submitted themselves

14451.text:
to it, however, and report that it produces
the sensations experienced by members of the

14457.text:
military cordon around Boulder Lake. A crash
program for the development of the projector

14462.text:
is already under way. At the same time a crash
program to develop a counter to it is already

14467.text:
showing promising results. The authorities
are entirely confident that a complete defense

14473.text:
against the no longer mysterious weapon will
be found. There is no longer any reason to

14478.text:
fear that earth will be unable to defend itself
against the invaders now present on earth,

14484.text:
or any reinforcements they may receive!"
The newscast stopped and a commercial called

14490.text:
the attention of listeners to the virtues
of an anti-allergy pill. Jill watched Lockley's

14496.text:
face. He did not relax.
The broadcast resumed. With this full and

14503.text:
certain hope of a defense against the invasion
weapon, said the announcer, it remained important

14509.text:
not to destroy the alien ship if it could
be captured for study. The use of atom bombs

14515.text:
was, therefore, again postponed. But they
would be used if necessary. Meanwhile, against

14521.text:
such an emergency, the areas of evacuation
would be enlarged. People would be removed

14527.text:
from additional territory so if bombs were
used there would be no humans near to be harmed.

14534.text:
Another commercial. Lockley turned off the
radio.

14537.text:
"What do you think?" asked Jill.
"I wish they hadn't made that broadcast,"

14543.text:
said Lockley. "If there were only monsters
involved and they didn't understand English,

14548.text:
it would be all right. But with humans helping
them, it sets a deadline. If we're going to

14554.text:
counter their weapon, they have to use it
before we finish the job."

14560.text:
After a moment he said bitterly, "There was
a time, right after the last big war, when

14565.text:
we had the bomb and nobody else did. There
couldn't be a cold war then! There were years

14572.text:
when we could destroy others and they couldn't
have fought back. Now somebody else is in

14576.text:
that position. They can destroy us and we
can't do a thing. It'll be that way for a

14583.text:
week, or maybe two, or even three. It'll be
strange if they don't take advantage of their

14589.text:
opportunity."
Jill tried to eat the food Lockley had laid

14592.text:
out. She couldn't. She began to cry quietly.
Lockley swore at himself for telling her the

14599.text:
worst, which it was always his instinct to
see. He said urgently, "Hold it! That's the

14606.text:
worst that could happen. But it's not the
most likely!"

14611.text:
She tried to control her tears.
"We're in a fix, yes!" he said insistently.

14617.text:
"It does look like there may be a flock of
other space ship landings within days. But

14623.text:
the monsters don't want to kill people. They
want a world with people working for them,

14629.text:
not dead. They've proved it. They'll avoid
massacres. They won't let the humans who're

14635.text:
their allies destroy the people they want
alive and useful."

14640.text:
Jill clenched her fists. "But it would be
better to be dead than like that!"

14645.text:
"But wait!" protested Lockley. "We've duplicated
the terror beam. Do you think they'll leave

14652.text:
it at that? The men who know how to do it
will be scattered to a dozen or a hundred

14657.text:
places, so they can't possibly all be found,
and they'll keep on secretly working until

14662.text:
they've made the beams and a protection against
them and then something more deadly still!

14668.text:
We humans can't be conquered! We'll fight
to the end of time!"

14673.text:
"But you yourself," said Jill desperately,
"you said there couldn't be a defense against

14679.text:
the beam! You said it!"
"I was discouraged," he protested. "I wasn't

14686.text:
thinking straight. Look! With no equipment
at all, I found out how to detect the stuff

14692.text:
before it was strong enough to paralyze us.
You know that. The scientists will have equipment

14697.text:
and instruments, and now that they've got
the beam they'll be able to try things. They'll

14703.text:
do better than I did. They can try heterodyning
the beam. They can try for interference effects.

14709.text:
They may find something to reflect it, or
they can try refraction."

14714.text:
He paused anxiously. She sobbed, once. "But
other weapons--"

14720.text:
"There may not be any. And there's bound to
be some trick of refraction that'll help.

14725.text:
It thins out at the edges now. That's how
