we get warning of it. It's refracted by ions

14731.text:
in the air. That's why it isn't a completely
tight beam. Ions in the air act like drops

14738.text:
of mist; they refract sunshine and make rainbows
after rain. And we got the smell-effect first.

14746.text:
That proves there's refraction."
He watched her face. She swallowed. What he'd

14752.text:
said was largely without meaning. Actually,
it wasn't even right. The evidence so far

14759.text:
was that the nerves of smell were more sensitive
than the optic nerves or the auditory ones,

14765.text:
while nerves to bundles of muscle were less
sensitive still. But Lockley wasn't concerned

14770.text:
with accuracy just now. He wanted to reassure
Jill.

14775.text:
Then his eyes widened suddenly and he stared
past her. He'd been speaking feverishly out

14780.text:
of emotion, while a part of his mind stood
aside and listened. And that detached part

14785.text:
of his mind had heard him say something worth
noting.

14790.text:
He stood stock-still for seconds, staring
blankly. Then he said very quietly, "You made

14797.text:
me think, then. I don't know why I didn't,
before. The terror beam does scatter a little,

14804.text:
like a searchlight beam in thin mist. It's
scattered by ions, like light by mist-droplets.

14812.text:
That's right!"
He stopped, thinking ahead. Jill said challengingly,

14817.text:
"Go on!" Again what he'd said had little meaning
to her, but she could see that he believed

14824.text:
it important.
"Why, a searchlight beam is stopped by a cloud,

14830.text:
which is many mist-droplets in one place.
It's scattered until it simply doesn't penetrate!"

14837.text:
Lockley suddenly seemed indignant at his own
failure to see something that had been so

14840.text:
obvious all along. "If we could make a cloud
of ions, it should stop the terror beam as

14847.text:
clouds stop light! We could--"
Again he stopped short, and Jill's expression

14854.text:
changed. She looked confident again. She even
looked proud as she watched Lockley wrestling

14861.text:
with his problem, unconsciously snapping his
fingers.

14864.text:
"Vale and I," he said jerkily, "had electronic
base-measuring instruments. Some of their

14871.text:
elements had to be buried in plastic because
otherwise they ionized the air and leaked

14876.text:
current like a short. If I had that instrument
now--No. I'd have to take the plastic away

14883.text:
and it couldn't be done without smashing things."
"What would happen," asked Jill, "if you made

14889.text:
what you're thinking about?"
"I might," said Lockley. "I just possibly

14895.text:
might make a gadget that would create a cloud
of ions around the person who carried it.

14901.text:
And it might reflect some of the terror beam
and refract the rest so none got through to

14907.text:
the man!"
Jill said hopefully, "Then tonight we go into

14912.text:
a deserted town and steal the things you need...."
Lockley interrupted in a relieved voice, "No-o-o-o.

14919.text:
What I need, I think, is a cheese grater and
the pocket radio. And there should be a cheese

14926.text:
grater in the house."
He listened at the barn door gap, and then

14930.text:
went out. Presently he was back. He had not
only a cheese grater but also a nutmeg grater.

14937.text:
Both were made of thin sheet metal in which
many tiny holes had been punched, so that

14943.text:
sharp bits of torn metal stood out to make
the grating surface. Lockley knew that sharp

14949.text:
points, when charged electrically, make tiny
jets of ionized air which will deflect a candle

14955.text:
flame. Here there were thousands of such points.
He set to work on the car seat, pushing the

14962.text:
pistol with its three remaining bullets out
of the way. The pistol was reserved for Jill

14967.text:
in case of untoward events, when it would
be of little or no practical value.

14973.text:
He operated on the tiny radio with his pocket-knife
to establish a circuit which should oscillate

14979.text:
when the battery was turned on. There was
induction, to raise the voltage at the peaks

14985.text:
and troughs of the oscillations. A transistor
acted as a valve to make the oscillations

14991.text:
repeated surges of current of one sign in
the innumerable sharp points of the graters.

14997.text:
And there was an effect he did not anticipate.
The ion-forming points were of minutely different

15003.text:
lengths and patterns, so the radiation inevitably
accompanying the ion clouds was of minutely

15010.text:
varying wave lengths. The consequence of using
the two graters was, of course, that rather

15016.text:
astonishing peaks of energy manifested themselves
in ultra-microscopic packages for a considerable

15023.text:
distance from the device. But Lockley did
not plan that. It happened because of the

15028.text:
materials he had to use in lieu of something
better.

15032.text:
When it was finished he told Jill, "I can
only check ion production here. If it works,

15039.text:
it ought to make a lighter-flame flicker when
near the points. If it does that, I'll go

15044.text:
up the road to where the trailer-truck stopped.
I've a pretty good idea that the road's blocked

15049.text:
by a terror beam there."
Absorbed, he threw the switch. And instantly

15055.text:
there was a racking, deafening explosion.
The pistol on the car seat blew itself to

15061.text:
bits, smashing the windshield and ripping
the cushion open. The three cartridges in

15066.text:
its cylinder had exploded simultaneously.
Lockley seized a pitchfork. He stood savagely,

15073.text:
ready for anything. Powder smoke drifted through
the barn. Nothing else happened.

15080.text:
After long, tense moments, Lockley said slowly,
"That could be another weapon the monsters

15086.text:
have turned on. It's been imagined. They could
be using a broadcast or a beam we haven't

15092.text:
suspected to disarm the troops of the cordon.
They could have a detonator beam that sets

15098.text:
off explosives at a distance. It's possible.
And if that's what they're turning on they

15104.text:
only have to sweep the sky and the bombers
aloft will be wiped out."

15110.text:
But there were no sounds other than the slowly
diminishing drip of water from the barn roof,

15116.text:
and the house eaves, and the few trees in
the barnyard.

15119.text:
"Anyhow they've ruined our only weapon," said
Lockley coldly. "It would be a detonation

15126.text:
beam setting off the cartridges. That would
be a perfect protection against atomic bombs,

15132.text:
if the chemical explosive that makes them
go off could be triggered from a distance.

15137.text:
Clever people, these monsters!"
Then he said abruptly, "Come on! It's ten

15142.text:
times more necessary for us to get to where
somebody can make use of our information!"

15147.text:
"Go where?" asked Jill, shaken once more.
"We take to the woods until dark," said Lockley,

15154.text:
"and meanwhile I'll check this supposedly
promising gadget--though it looks pretty feeble

15159.text:
if the monsters have a detonating beam--against
the road blocking beam up yonder. Come on!"

15165.text:
He stuffed his pockets with food. He led the
way.

15169.text:
The morning had now arrived. The sun was visible,
red at the eastern horizon.

15173.text:
"Walk on the grass!" commanded Lockley.
There was no point in leaving footprints,

15179.text:
though there was no reason to believe the
explosion on the car seat had been heard.

15184.text:
Lockley, indeed, considered that if the aliens
had just used a previously undisclosed weapon,

15190.text:
there would be explosions of greater or lesser
violence all over the evacuated territory

15195.text:
and all other areas within its range. There
wouldn't be many farmhouses without a shotgun

15201.text:
put away somewhere. There would be shotgun
shells, too. If the aliens had a detonator

15207.text:
beam as well as one that produced the terror
beam's effects, then all hope of resistance

15213.text:
was probably gone.
They crossed to the house and moved alongside

15217.text:
it. They went with instinctive furtiveness
out of the lane and quickly into the woodland

15223.text:
on the farther side. They were soaked almost
immediately. Fallen leaves clung to their

15229.text:
shoes. Drooping branches smeared them with
wetness. Lockley went barely out of sight

15235.text:
of the highway and then trudged doggedly in
the direction the Wild Life Control trailer-truck

15241.text:
had taken. He handed Jill the ribbon of bronze
that had been the mainspring of his watch.

15247.text:
"We might pick up the beam from the wetness
underfoot," he said, "but we'll play it safe

15252.text:
and use this too."
They went on for a long way. Lockley fumed,

15258.text:
"I don't like this! We ought to be there--"
"I think," said Jill, "I smell it."

15265.text:
"I'll try it," said Lockley.
He detected the jungle smell and its concomitant

15272.text:
revolting odors. He led Jill back.
"Wait here, by this big tree stump. I'll be

15277.text:
able to find you and you're safe enough from
the beam."

15280.text:
He turned away. Jill said pleadingly, "Please
be careful!"

15286.text:
"A little while ago," he told her gloomily,
"I felt that I had too much useful information

15294.text:
to take any chances with my life, let alone
yours. I'm not so sure of my importance now.

15301.text:
But I think you still need somebody else around."
"I do!" said Jill. "And you know it! I'd much

15313.text:
He went away, trailing the watch spring.
He was extra cautious now. The smell recurred

15320.text:
and grew stronger. He began to feel the first
faint flashes of light in his eyes. It was

15327.text:
the symptom which followed the smell when
approaching a terror beam. Then a faint, discordant

15333.text:
murmur, originating in his own ears. He turned
on the device made of two graters and the

15339.text:
elements of a pocket radio. The smell ceased.
The faint flashes of light stopped. There

15346.text:
was no longer a raucous sound.
He turned off the ion producing device. The

15352.text:
symptoms returned. He turned it on and off.
He took a step forward. He tested again. The

15359.text:
cloud of ions from the innumerable jagged
points was invisible, but somehow it refracted

15365.text:
or reflected--in any case, neutralized--the
weapon of the beings at Boulder Lake. He went

15372.text:
on and presently he felt the very faintest
possible tingling of his skin and heard the

15377.text:
barest whisper of a sound, and smelled the
jungle reek as something so diluted that he

15384.text:
was hardly sure he smelled it.
He went on, and those faint sensations ceased.

15391.text:
Presently, impatient of his own timorousness,
he turned the device off again. He had walked

15397.text:
through the terror beam.
He started back with the device turned on

15401.text:
once more and at the point where he'd felt
the beam's manifestations faintly, he stopped

15406.text:
to savor his now seemingly useless triumph.
If the monsters had a detonating beam this

15412.text:
meant nothing. Yet it could have meant everything.
He paid close attention and distinctly but

15419.text:
weakly experienced the effect of the terror
beam.

15423.text:
Then he didn't. Not at all. The sensations
were cut off.

15429.text:
He heard Jill cry out shrilly. He plunged
toward the place where he had left her. He

15434.text:
raced. He leaped. Once he fell, and frantically
swore at the wet stuff that had caused him

15440.text:
to slip. He reached the tree stump and Jill
was not there. He saw the saucer-sized tracks

15447.text:
her feet had made on the saturated fallen
leaves. They led toward the road.

15452.text:
He heard a car door slam and a motor roar.
He plunged onward more desperately than before.

15459.text:
The motor raced away. And Lockley got out
on the highway only in time to see the rear

15464.text:
of a brown-painted, military-marked car some
three hundred yards away. It swept around

15470.text:
a curve of the highway and was gone. It was
going through the space where the road was

15475.text:
blocked by a terror beam, headed obviously
for Boulder Lake.

15480.text:
What had happened was self-evident. From her
place beside the huge stump she'd seen a military

15485.text:
car approaching. And she and Lockley had been
trying to reach the cordon of troops around

15491.text:
Boulder Lake. There was no reason to distrust
men in uniform or in a military car. She'd

15498.text:
run to flag it down. She had. By a coincidence,
it was undoubtedly where a carload of collaborating

15505.text:
humans would have stopped to have the road-blocking
beam cut off by their monster allies. She'd

15511.text:
approached the stopped car. And something
frightened her. She screamed.

15515.text:
But she'd been pulled into the car, which
went on before the beam could come on again

15526.text:
It was very likely that at that moment Lockley
despised himself more bitterly than any other

15531.text:
man alive. He blamed himself absolutely for
Jill's capture. If there were humans acting

15539.text:
with the alien invaders, her fate would unquestionably
be more horrible than at the hands of the

15545.text:
monsters alone. After all, there was one nation
most likely to deal with extra-terrestrial

15551.text:
creatures to help them in the conquest of
earth, and its troops were not notorious for

15558.text:
their kindly behavior to civilians.
And Jill was their captive. He'd been carried

15565.text:
past the place where a terror beam blocked
the road. The military markings might mean

15569.text:
the car was stolen, or that its markings and
paint were counterfeit. It seemed certain

15575.text:
that Jill had gone up to it in confidence
that there could only be American soldiers

15580.text:
in such a car, and when near it found out
her mistake too late.

15586.text:
These were not things that Lockley thought
out in detail at the beginning. He ran after

15591.text:
the car like a mad man, unable to feel anything
but horror and so terrible a fury that it

15597.text:
should have killed its objects by sheer intensity.
Presently he heard hoarse, gasping sounds.

15605.text:
He realized that the sounds were the breath
going in and out of his own throat, while

15609.text:
Jill was carried farther and farther away
from him in a car which traveled ten yards

15616.text:
to his one. He sobbed then, and suddenly he
was strangely and unnaturally calm. He was

15623.text:
able to think quite coolly. The only difference
between this and normal thinking was that

15629.text:
now he could only think about one thing--full
and complete and terrible revenge for the

15636.text:
crimes committed and to be committed against
Jill. She would be taken to Boulder Lake.

15642.text:
So he would go to Boulder Lake, and somehow,
in some manner, he would destroy utterly all

15649.text:
living beings there and every trace of their
coming.

15652.text:
Which, of course, was both natural and unreasonable.
But reason would have been unnatural at such

15659.text:
a time as this.
He moved along the highway in a passion of

15663.text:
ultimate resolve. In the rest of the world,
time passed without knowledge of his emotional

15669.text:
state. The rest of the world was suffering
emotional agonies of its own.

15674.text:
The United States had become popular among
peoples who disliked all things American except

15680.text:
those they were given free, and who continued
to dislike the givers. Now though, the United

15688.text:
States had been invaded from space by creatures
using weapons of unprecedented type and effect.

15695.text:
If the United States were conquered, there
was no other nation likely to remain free.

15701.text:
So a great deal of anti-Americanism faded
under pressure of an ardent desire for America

15707.text:
to be successful in its self-defense.
Moreover, anticipating other alien landings

15713.text:
which could take place anywhere, the United
States offered to share its stock of atom

15719.text:
bombs with any nation so invaded. American
popularity increased. The fact that the USSR

15725.text:
made no such proposal also had its effect.
The United States invited scientists of every

15732.text:
country to help in solving the menace of the
terror beam, and committed itself to share

15737.text:
any discoveries for defense against it with
all the world. Again there was an improvement

15743.text:
in the public image of the United States abroad.
But Lockley knew nothing of this. His pocket

15751.text:
radio no longer existed to give him news.
It had been rebuilt into something else, whose

15757.text:
most conspicuous parts were cheese and nutmeg
graters, slung over his shoulder as he marched.

15764.text:
But if he had known of changes in the popularity
of his country, he wouldn't have been interested.

15771.text:
He could fix his mind only on one subject
and matters related to it.

15775.text:
He tramped along the highway, possessed by
a cold demon of hatred. He was on foot for

15781.text:
lack of a car. He was unarmed. At the moment
he believed that all the rest of humanity

15787.text:
was disarmed, in effect if not in fact. So
he had no plans, only an infinite hatred.

15796.text:
But because he would have to pass through
terror beams to get at those he meant to destroy,

15801.text:
he realized that it was necessary to make
sure that he would be able to pass through

15805.text:
them, that his equipment for reaching Boulder
Lake was in good order. It was still turned

15811.text:
on. He turned it off to be economical of its
batteries. He went on, thinking of only one

15817.text:
subject, examining every possibility for revenge
with a passionate patience, undiscouraged

15824.text:
because one idea after another was plainly
impossible, but continuing obsessively to

15831.text:
think of others.
He smelled the foetid odor, which cut through

15835.text:
his absorption because of its connotations.
He turned on his device and went doggedly

15841.text:
ahead. He knew he had entered a terror beam
by the faint perceptions which came through

15846.text:
the cloud of ions his instrument produced.
Then they ceased. He knew that the beam had

15853.text:
been cut off. He heard a motor rev up. A car
or truck had stopped beyond the road-blocking

15859.text:
beam and waited for it to be cut off, as it
had been.

15864.text:
Lockley stepped into the woods hating the
vehicle bitterly as it approached, but wanting

15869.text:
to save destruction for those where Jill had
been taken.

15873.text:
He was hidden when the car appeared. It was
a perfectly commonplace car with a whip aerial

15879.text:
at its rear. It came confidently along the
highway. A hundred yards from him, there were

15885.text:
explosions. Smoke came out of the open windows.
The engine stopped and the car bucked crazily

15892.text:
and went into the ditch beside the highway.
A man plunged out, slapping at his leg. A

15898.text:
revolver in its holster had exploded all its
shells. The leather holster had saved him

15904.text:
from serious injury, but his clothing was
on fire. Other men, two of them, got out hastily.

15910.text:
Things had exploded in the back of the car,
too. The three men swore agitatedly.

15917.text:
Then one of them said something which stimulated
the others to frantic flight down the highway

15921.text:
away from the ditched car. The third man limped
anxiously after the faster-moving two.

15928.text:
Lockley, watching and hating with undivided
attention, knew when the terror beam came

15933.text:
on again. He felt it, very faint because of
his protection, but quite distinct. The explosions

15940.text:
had taken place when the car was in the area
now covered again by the terror beam. The

15946.text:
men in the car, astonished and scorched, had
fled because the beam was due to come back

15951.text:
on and they didn't want to be caught in it.
Lockley noted that the human confederates

15957.text:
of the monsters had no protection against
the beam to match his own. Perhaps the monsters

15963.text:
themselves were protected only near the projectors.
This was an item affecting his plans of revenge

15970.text:
for Jill. He stored it away in his mind. Then
he realized that the weapons in the car had

15976.text:
exploded just like the pistol on his own seat
cushion. The explosion was not associated

15982.text:
with the terror beam. There'd been no beam
in action when his own pistol blew up. It

15988.text:
did not seem reasonable that if the monsters
possessed a detonation beam that they'd turn

15993.text:
it on their own confederates.
No. Rational beings would do nothing so self-contradictory.

16001.text:
Then Lockley looked down at the cheese grater-pocket
radio device of his own manufacture. He considered

16007.text:
the fact that his own pistol had exploded
the instant he'd turned the gadget on. The

16012.text:
weapons in the other car detonated when that
car was near him.

16016.text:
He plodded onward thinking very clearly and
precisely about the matter. He even remembered

16022.text:
to turn off his gadget because he would need
it to avenge Jill. But when he tried to think

16027.text:
of any subject unconnected with revenge, his
mind became confused and agitated.

16033.text:
Two miles along the highway, which had not
yet turned to head in toward Boulder Lake,

16038.text:
there was a farmhouse. Lockley walked heavily
to the abandoned building. He found the door

16044.text:
locked. Without conscious thought, he forced
it. He searched the closets. He found a shotgun

16051.text:
and half a box of shells. He considered them,
then left the gun and all the shells but three.

16057.text:
He went out. Presently he laid a shotgun shell
down on the road. He paced off twenty-five

16063.text:
yards and dropped another. He dropped a third
twenty-five yards farther on, and then carefully

16070.text:
counted off three hundred feet. The car had
been just about that far away when the explosions

16076.text:
came.
He turned on his device. Two of the three

16080.text:
shells exploded smokily. The farthest away
did not explode.

16086.text:
He did not rejoice. He went on without elation,
but it became a part of his painstaking search

16092.text:
for vengeance that he knew he could set off
explosives within a hundred and twenty-five

16096.text:
yards of himself. There was something about
the device he'd constructed which made explosives

16103.text:
detonate, up to a distance of a little over
one hundred yards. He felt no curiosity about

16109.text:
it, though it was simple enough. The heterodyning
of extremely saw-toothed waves produced peaks

16117.text:
of energy until the saw-teeth began to smooth
out. There were infinitesimal spots in which,

16123.text:
for infinitesimal lengths of time, energy
conditions comparable to sparks existed. This

16130.text:
had not been worked out in advance, but the
reason was clear.

16134.text:
He came to the place where the main highway
to Boulder Lake branched off from the road

16138.text:
he was following. He turned into it, walking
doggedly.

16142.text:
Three miles toward the lake, an engine sounded
from behind him. He got off the highway and

16147.text:
turned the switch. A half-ton truck came trundling
openly along the road. It came closer and

16154.text:
closer.
Small-arm ammunition exploded. The engine

16158.text:
stopped and the light truck toppled over onto
its side. Lockley did not approach it. Its

16165.text:
driver might not be dead, and he would not
find it possible to leave any man alive who

16171.text:
was associated with Jill's captors. He passed
the truck and went on up the highway.

16177.text:
Seven miles up the road a truck came down
from Boulder Lake. Lockley placed himself

16183.text:
discreetly out of sight. He turned on his
instrument. A gun flew to pieces with a thunderous

16189.text:
detonation. The truck crashed. It was interesting
to Lockley that automobile engines invariably

16195.text:
went dead at about the time that explosives
went off. The fact was, of course, that ionized

16202.text:
air is more or less conductive. In an ion
cloud the spark plugs shorted and did not

16208.text:
fire in the cylinders.
There were two other vehicles which essayed

16213.text:
to pass Lockley as he went on up the long
way to the lake. Both came from the interior

16218.text:
of the Park. He left them wrecked beside the
highway. Between times, he walked with a dogged

16224.text:
grimness toward the place where Vale had been
the first to report a thing come down from

16229.text:
the sky. That had been how many days ago?
Three? Four?

16236.text:
Then Lockley had been a quiet and well-conducted
citizen inclined to pessimism about future

16243.text:
events, but duly considerate of the rights
of others. Now he'd changed. He felt only

16249.text:
one emotion, which was hatred such as he'd
never imagined before. He had only one motive,

16256.text:
which was to take total and annihilating vengeance
for what had been done to Jill.

16262.text:
He plodded on and on. He had to make a march
of not less than twenty miles from the Park's

16268.text:
beginning. He journeyed on foot because there
were terror beams to pass and automobile engines

16274.text:
did not run when his protective device operated.
He could not arm himself from the cars that

16280.text:
ditched, because all chemical explosive weapons
and their ammunition blew at the same time.

16286.text:
He was a minute figure among the mountains,
marching alone upon a winding highway, moving

16293.text:
resolutely to destroy--alone--the invaders
from outer space and the men who worked with

16300.text:
them for the conquest of earth. For his purpose
he carried the strangest of equipment, a device

16307.text:
made of a pocket radio and a cheese grater.
He had food in his pockets, but he could not

16313.text:
eat. During the afternoon he became impatient
of its weight and threw it away. But he thirsted

16320.text:
often. More than once he drank from small
streams over which the highway builders had

16325.text:
made small concrete bridges.
At three in the afternoon a truck came up

16330.text:
from behind. Here he trudged between steep
cliffs which made him seem almost a midget.

16336.text:
The highway went through a crevice between
adjoining mountainsides. There was no place

16341.text:
for him to conceal himself. When he heard
the engine, he stopped and faced it. The truck

16347.text:
had picked up many men from wrecked cars along
its route. There were scorched and scratched

16352.text:
and wounded men, hurt by the explosion of
their firearms. The truck brought them along

16358.text:
and overtook Lockley.
He waited very calmly since it did not seem

16363.text:
likely that they would realize that one man
had caused the crashes. The driver of the

16369.text:
truck with the picked-up men did not even
think of such a thing. Lockley seemed much

16374.text:
more likely the victim of still another wreck.
The overtaking truck slowed down. There would

16381.text:
be no strangers in Boulder Lake Park. There
would only be the task force aiding the monsters,

16386.text:
as Lockley reasoned it out. So the truck slowed,
preparatory to taking Lockley aboard.

16394.text:
At a hundred and twenty-five yards from Lockley,
weapons in the truck cab blew themselves violently

16399.text:
apart. The engine, stopped in gear, acted
as a violently applied brake. The truck swerved

16406.text:
off the highway. It turned over and was still.
Lockley turned and walked on. He considered

16413.text:
coldly that it was perfectly safe for him
to go on. There were no weapons left behind

16419.text:
him. The men themselves were shaken up. They
would attempt to make no trouble beyond a

16424.text:
report of their situation and a plea for help.
The report could be made by the radio, which

16430.text:
was not smashed.
Half an hour later, Lockley felt the tingling

16436.text:
which meant that his instrument was protecting
him from a terror beam. The tingling lasted

16441.text:
only a short time, but fifteen minutes later
it came back. Then it returned at odd intervals.

16448.text:
Five minutes--eight--ten--three--six--one.
Each time the terror beam should have paralyzed

16455.text:
him and caused intense suffering. A man with
no protective device would have had his nerves

16460.text:
shattered by torment coming so violently at
unpredictable intervals.

16467.text:
Lockley tried to reason out why this nerve-wracking
application of the terror beam hadn't been

16472.text:
used before. To an unprotected man it would
be worse than continuous pain. No living man

16480.text:
could remain able to resist any demand if
exposed to such torture.

16485.text:
The beam was evidently swung at random intervals,
and the phenomenon lasted for an hour and

16491.text:
a half. Anyone but Lockley behind a cloud
of ions would have been reduced to shivering

16497.text:
hysteria. Then, suddenly, the beamings stopped.
But Lockley left his device in operation.

16506.text:
Half an hour later still--close to five o'clock--it
appeared that the invaders assumed that any

16511.text:
enemy should have been softened up for capture.
They sent an expedition to find out what had

16516.text:
happened to their trucks and cars.
Lockley saw four cars and a light truck in

16522.text:
close formation moving toward him from the
Lake. They were close, as if for mutual protection.

16529.text:
They moved steadily, as if inviting the fate
that had overtaken others. The short wave

16536.text:
reports from smashed trucks seemed improbable
to them, but the expedition was equipped to

16541.text:
investigate even such unlikely happenings.
The four cars in the lead contained five men

16548.text:
each. Each man was armed with a rifle containing
a single cartridge in its chamber and none

16554.text:
in its magazine. The rifles pointed straight
up. There was more ammunition in the light

16560.text:
truck behind, and it was in clips ready for
use, but the truck body was of iron. If that

16567.text:
ammunition detonated, it could do no harm.
If it did not, it would be available for use

16573.text:
against the single man mentioned by the driver
of the last truck to be wrecked.

16579.text:
But Lockley saw them coming. They came sedately
down a long straight stretch of road. He climbed

16585.text:
a rocky wall beside the highway to a little
ravine that led away from the road. He posted

16590.text:
himself where he was extremely unlikely to
be seen. Then he waited.

16596.text:
The cavalcade of cars appeared. It drove briskly
toward Lockley at something like thirty miles

16602.text:
an hour. Perhaps ten yards separated the lead
car from the second. The truck was a trifle

16609.text:
closer to the four man-carrying vehicles.
They swept along, every man alert. They would

16616.text:
pass forty feet below Lockley.
He did nothing. His device was already turned

16622.text:
on. He watched in detached calm.
The lead car stopped as if it had run into

16629.text:
a brick wall, while rifles inside it blew
holes in its top. The second car crashed into

16635.text:
it, rifles detonating. The third car. The
fourth. The truck piled into the others with

16641.text:
a gigantic flare and furious report, each
separate brass cartridge case exploding in

16647.text:
the same instant. The truck became scrap iron.
Lockley went away along the small ravine.

16655.text:
From now on he would avoid the highway. He
estimated that he would arrive at Boulder

16660.text:
Lake itself about half an hour after dark.
It occurred to him that then Jill would have

16666.text:
been a prisoner of the invaders for something
more than twelve hours, at least ten of them

16672.text:
at their headquarters.
Before he began the climb that would take

16676.text:
him to the invaders, Lockley stopped at a
small stream.

16686.text:
There was a three-day-old moon in the sky
when the last colors faded in the west. When

16691.text:
darkness fell it was already low. It gave
little light; not much more than the stars

16698.text:
alone. It did help Lockley while it lasted
however. He knew the terrain about Boulder

16704.text:
Lake but not in detail. And it would not be
wise for him to move openly to wreak destruction

16710.text:
on the enemies of his nation.
He used the moonlight for his approach by

16716.text:
the least practical route to the lake. When
it dimmed and went behind the mountains, he

16721.text:
continued to climb, sliding dangerously, then
descend and climb again as the rough going

16728.text:
demanded. His mind was absorbed with reflections
upon what he meant to do. The wrecks on the

16734.text:
highway would have given notice to the invaders
that he could do damage. They would take every

16739.text:
possible precaution against him.
It was typical of Lockley that he painstakingly

16745.text:
imagined every obstacle that might be put
in his way. During the last half hour of his

16751.text:
scrambling travel, for example, he was tormented
by a measure his enemies might have used to

16756.text:
make him advertise his presence. If they simply
laid rifle cartridges on the ground at intervals

16763.text:
of twenty-five or fifty yards, he could not
cross that line with his device in operation

16769.text:
without blowing up those shells. It was a
possible countermeasure that caused him to

16775.text:
sweat with worry.
But it wasn't thought of by anyone else. To

16780.text:
contrive it, a man would have to know how
the detonation field worked and how far it

16786.text:
extended. Nobody but Lockley knew. Therefore
no one could contrive this defense against

16793.text:
him.
He worked his way to Boulder Lake's back door

16796.text:
through brushwood and over boulders. Presently
he looked down upon his destination. To his

16803.text:
right and left rocky masses were silhouetted
against the starry sky. He gazed down on the

16809.text:
lake and the shoreline where the hotel would
be built, and the places where roads came

16813.text:
out of the wilderness.
There were changes since the time he'd looked

16817.text:
down from Vale's survey post and before the
terror beam captured him. He catalogued them

16824.text:
mentally, but the sight before him was intolerable.
Everything he saw, here where space monsters

16831.text:
were believed to hold sway, was in reality
the work of men. Rage filled him at the sight.

16839.text:
Hatred. Fury....
In the rest of the world an entirely different

16844.text:
sort of emotion was felt about the subject
of the invaders. The United States had announced

16849.text:
to all the world that American and other scientists,
working together, had solved the mystery of

16855.text:
the alien weapon. They had produced a duplicate
of the terror beam. It was no less effective

16861.text:
and no less an absolute weapon than the invaders'.
And a defense had been found which was complete.

16869.text:
It was being rushed into production. The experimental
counter beam generators would be moved into

16874.text:
position to frustrate and defeat the monsters
who had landed upon earth. Military detachments,

16882.text:
protected by the counter generators, would
move upon Boulder Lake at dawn. By sunset

16888.text:
tomorrow the aliens would be dead or captive,
and their ship would undoubtedly be in the

16894.text:
hands of scientists for study.
Moreover, the United States would provide

16899.text:
counter weapons for other nations. In no more
than months every continent and nation on

16905.text:
earth would be equipped to defy any alien
landing that might take place. The world would

16911.text:
be able to defend itself. It would be equipped
to do so. And this was the resolve of the

16918.text:
United States because the world could not
exist half free and half enslaved by creatures

16924.text:
from a distant planet. The news poured out
from all sources. The alien weapon was understood

16931.text:
and now could be defied. Soon all the world
would be provided with counter weapons. It

16938.text:
was necessary for all the world to be prepared
and prepared it would be.

16944.text:
This was the information which made all the
world rejoice, though not yet at ease because

16950.text:
aliens still occupied a tiny part of the earth.
But all the world was eager for confirmation

16956.text:
of the news it had just received.
Lockley had no such soothing anticipations.

16963.text:
He shook with fury because what he saw before
him was so appalling as to be almost unbelievable.

16970.text:
It was not dark in the space he looked down
upon. There were bright floodlights placed

16976.text:
here and there to drench a large area with
light. There were few figures in sight. But

16982.text:
what the floodlights showed made Lockley quiver
with hatred.

16986.text:
The floodlights were of typically human type.
There were vehicles parked on a level grassy

16993.text:
space. They were of human manufacture. There
was no space ship in the lake, but there was

16999.text:
a three-stage rocket set up, ready for firing.
It was of the kind used by humans to put artificial

17006.text:
satellites into orbit. Lockley even knew its
designation, and that it used the new solid

17013.text:
fuels for propulsion.
In the lair of the creatures from outer space

17019.text:
there was nothing from outer space. There
was nothing in view which was alien or unearthly

17026.text:
or extra-terrestrial. And Lockley made inarticulate
growling sounds because he saw with absolute

17033.text:
clarity and certainty that there never had
been anything from outer space at this spot.

17040.text:
There were no monsters. There never had been.
And the truth was more horribly enraging than

17047.text:
the deception had been.
Because this could mean the death of the world.

17052.text:
This was an attempt to fight the last war
on earth in disguise. Humans had posed as

17058.text:
non-human beings so that America would fight
against phantoms while its great military

17063.text:
rival pretended to help and actually stabbed
from behind.

17068.text:
It was completely logical, of course. An admitted
attack by terror beams in the form of death

17073.text:
rays would involve retaliation by America.
Against a human enemy great, roaring missiles

17081.text:
could circle earth to plunge down upon that
enemy's cities to turn them and their inhabitants

17087.text:
into incandescent gas. An attack known to
be by humans and upon humans must touch off

17095.text:
the world's last war in which every living
thing might die. No conceivable success at

17101.text:
the beginning could prevent full retaliation.
But if the attack were believed to be from

17107.text:
space, then American weapons and valor would
be spent against creatures which were no more

17113.text:
than ghosts.
Lockley moved forward. Only he could know

17118.text:
the situation as it presented itself here.
Even vengeance for Jill should be put aside,

17125.text:
if it called for action irrelevant to this
state of things. But it did not. A full and

17133.text:
terrible revenge for her required exactly
the action the coolest of cold-blooded resolutions

17139.text:
would suggest be taken now. And Lockley moved
on and downward to take it.

17147.text:
He began to crawl downhill toward the lights,
unaware that there were some gaps in his picture

17153.text:
of the total scene. For example, these lights
could be detected by aircraft overhead. The

17159.text:
fact did not occur to Lockley. He was not
given pause by the relaxation of the enemy's

17165.text:
disguise so far as air observation was concerned.
He didn't think of it. He moved on.

17173.text:
He drew near the lighted area. He did not
walk, he crawled. He began to listen with

17179.text:
fury-sharpened ears. If he could get close
to that huge rocket, close enough to detonate

17187.text:
its solid fuel stores....
That would be at once revenge and expedience.

17194.text:
If the rocket's fuel blew up instead of burning
as intended, it would annihilate the camp.

17199.text:
It would wipe out every living creature present.
But there would be fragments left by the explosion.

17206.text:
There would be corpses. There would be wreckage.
And that wreckage and those corpses would

17212.text:
be unmistakably human. The last war on earth
might not be avoided, but at the worst it

17220.text:
would be fought against America's actual enemy
and not against imaginary monsters.

17226.text:
It was worth dying to accomplish even that.
But Jill....

17232.text:
Lockley's progress was infinitely slow, but
he needed to take the greatest pains. He listened

17238.text:
carefully.
He heard the faint high roaring of the planes

17243.text:
overhead. They were far away. There were sounds
of insects, and the cries of night birds,

17249.text:
and the rustling of leaves and foliage.
There was another sound. A new sound. It was

17257.text:
inexplicable. It was a strange and intermittent
muttering. There was a certain irregular rhythm

17264.text:
to it, a familiar rhythm.
He crawled on.

17268.text:
There was movement suddenly, off to his left.
Then it stopped. It could be a man on watch

17274.text:
against him simply shifting his position.
Lockley froze, and then went on with even

17280.text:
greater caution. He felt the ground before
him for small twigs that might crack under

17286.text:
his weight.
The muttering continued. Presently Lockley

17292.text:
realized that it was a human voice. It was
resonant and with many overtones, but still

17299.text:
too faint for him to distinguish words.
He crossed a slight rise that had much brushwood.

17307.text:
The brushwood grew in clumps and he circled
them with a patient caution foreign to his

17312.text:
feelings.
The muttering changed and went on. Lockley

17316.text:
pressed himself to the ground. Men went past
him a hundred feet away. He saw them in outline

17324.text:
against the illuminated parked cars and trucks
and in the space around the huge rocket. They

17330.text:
carried no rifles, probably no firearms at
all. Lockley's march up the highway had warned

17337.text:
them of the uselessness of guns, at least
at short range. They were watching for him

17344.text:
now. Perhaps these men were relieving other
watchers on the hillside.

17349.text:
He saw other men. They seemed to move restlessly
around the lighted area.

17354.text:
The muttering was louder now. He could almost
catch the words. He made another hundred yards

17360.text:
toward the rocket and the voice changed again.
Then he was dazed. The voice was speaking

17367.text:
to him! Calling him by name!
"Lockley! Lockley! Don't do anything crazy!

17375.text:
Everything can be explained! You'll recognize
my voice. You talked to me on the telephone

17380.text:
from Serena!"
Lockley did recognize the voice. It was that

17386.text:
of the general who'd sounded pompous and indignant
as he refused to listen to Lockley's statements.

17393.text:
Now, coming out of many loudspeakers and echoing
hollowly from cliffs, it was the same voice

17400.text:
but with an intonation that was persuasive
and forthright.

17404.text:
"You startled me," said the voice crisply.
"You'd found out there were humans involved

17410.text:
in this business. It was important that the
fact be suppressed. I tried to browbeat you,

17416.text:
which was a mistake. While I was talking to
you your suspicion was reported on short wave

17421.text:
by the Wild Life driver. I tried to overawe
you. You're the wrong kind of man for that.

17428.text:
But everything can be explained. Everything!
Here's Vale to prove it!"

17433.text:
There was only an instant's pause. Then Vale's
voice came out of the loudspeakers spread

17439.text:
all about.
"Lockley, this is Vale. The whole thing's

17444.text:
faked. There's a good reason for it, but you
stumbled on the facts. They had to be kept

17450.text:
secret. I didn't even tell Jill. This isn't
treason, Lockley. We aren't traitors! Come

17458.text:
out and I'll explain everything. Here's Sattell."
And Sattell's voice boomed against the hills.

17465.text:
"Vale's right, Lockley! I didn't know what
was up. I was fooled as much as anybody. But

17471.text:
it's all right! It's perfectly all right!
When you understand you'll realize that you

17477.text:
had to be deceived just as I was. Come on
out and everything will be explained to your

17483.text:
satisfaction. I promise!"
Lockley grimaced. How did Sattell get up here?

17492.text:
And the general in command of the cordon?
More than that, why did they call his name

17498.text:
instead of simply trying to kill him? Why
post watchers on the hillsides if they were

17504.text:
anxious to explain and not to murder? How
could they hope to deceive him after Jill....

17512.text:
There was a pause, and then what was evidently
considered a decisive message came. It was

17518.text:
Jill's voice, weary and desperate. It said,
"Please come out and listen! Please come and

17526.text:
let them explain everything. They can do it.
I understand and I believe them. It's true.

17534.text:
It's not treason. I--I beg you to come out
and let them tell you why all this has happened...."

17541.text:
Her voice trailed off. It had trembled. It
was tense. It was strained. And Lockley cursed

17548.text:
softly, shaking with rage. Then the first
voice returned, "Lockley! Lockley! Don't do

17556.text:
anything crazy! Everything can be explained.
You'll recognize my voice. You talked to me

17563.text:
on the telephone from Serena."
This voice repeated, word for word and intonation

17570.text:
for intonation, exactly what it had said before.
The other voices followed in the same order.

17577.text:
They were taped.
In Lockley's state of mind, the taping took

17583.text:
away all authority from the voices. Jill,
in particular, sounded as she might have if

17589.text:
torture had been used to break her will and
force her to say what her captors wished.

17595.text:
She could not put any warning into it, because
she could have been forced to repeat and repeat

17600.text:
the message until her captors were satisfied.
That would all be avenged now. All of it.

17608.text:
And Jill would be grateful to Lockley even
if they never saw each other again; grateful

17614.text:
for the monstrous blast that would wipe this
place clean of living creatures.

17620.text:
Lockley suddenly saw a way by which his vengeance
could be increased by just a little. It could

17627.text:
be made even more satisfying and just. Hiding
under brushwood while the voices tirelessly

17634.text:
repeated their recorded persuasion, he made
a very simple device. It switched onto the

17640.text:
instrument he carried. If his hand clenched,
it would go on. If his hand relaxed, it would

17648.text:
go on. So if he could get within a hundred
and twenty-five yards of the rocket he could

17654.text:
show himself and let them know what waited
for them, and why.

17659.text:
With infinite patience he got to a place almost
near the circle of unarmed guards about the

17664.text:
rocket. He waited. The guards were tense.
They did not like trying to protect something

17670.text:
with no weapons. They were jumpy. The endlessly
repeated messages booming into the night frayed

17678.text:
their nerves. They were plainly on edge.
Their tenseness made the oldest trick in the

17685.text:
world serve Lockley's purpose. He threw a
stone from an especially dark shadow. It struck

17692.text:
and bounced upon another stone, and it created
a rustling of brushwood at a place distant

17697.text:
from Lockley. And the unarmed guards plunged
for that place to seize whatever or whoever

17703.text:
had made the disturbance.
They were too eager. They stumbled upon each

17708.text:
other.
And Lockley ran, and a voice cried out in

17712.text:
terror. And then Lockley stood with his back
to the rocket's lower parts, and he waved

17717.text:
the cheese grater derisively and shouted.
Then there was stillness. Only the booming

17724.text:
voice from the speakers went on. It happened
to be Sattell's voice.

17731.text:
" ... all right. It's perfectly all right.
When you understand you'll realize that you

17736.text:
had to be deceived as I was. It was necessary.
Come out and everything--"

17744.text:
Somebody cut off the recorder. There was a
moment of blank indecision, and then a man

17749.text:
in uniform with two general's stars on his
shoulders came out of somewhere and walked

17754.text:
to face Lockley.
"Ah, Lockley!" he said briskly. "That's the

17760.text:
thing you smash cars and explode ammunition
with, eh? Do you think it will blow the rocket?"

17766.text:
"I'm going to try it!" said Lockley. "Listen."
He showed how anything that could be done

17772.text:
to him would close the switch one way or the
other. "I wanted you to know before I blow

17778.text:
it!" he said fiercely. "Where's Jill? Jill
Holmes? One of your cars picked her up and

17784.text:
brought her here. Where is she?"
"We sent her," said the general, "over to

17790.text:
the construction camp, in case you managed
to get in the exact situation you're in. In

17795.text:
other words, she's safe. She'll be coming
shortly, though. She was to be notified the

17801.text:
instant you appeared--if the rocket didn't
blast as your greeting."

17807.text:
Lockley ground his teeth.
"We'll have this settled before she gets here!"

17812.text:
Vale appeared. He walked forward and stood
beside the general.

17817.text:
"We did a job that was several times too good,
Lockley," he said ruefully. "I'd rehearsed

17824.text:
my song-and-dance until we thought it was
perfect. What made you suspicious, Lockley?

17830.text:
Did you notice we kept the communicator aimed
right so you'd hear through to the end? A

17835.text:
fine point, that. We worried about it."
The headlights of a car moved against a mountainside.

17841.text:
"You see," said Vale, "the thing had to be
done this way! Sattell swore a blue streak

17849.text:
when it was explained to him. He felt he'd
been made a fool of. But there are some things

17855.text:
that can't be handled forthrightly!"
Lockley felt physically ill. Jill had been--still

17862.text:
was--engaged to Vale. She'd been anxious about
him. She'd been loyal to him. And he was helping

17870.text:
the invaders! He opened his mouth to speak
bitterly, when Sattell appeared. He lined

17877.text:
up beside the general and Vale.
"They fooled me too, Lockley," he said wryly.

17884.text:
"But it's all right. They had to. They thought
you were fooled. Those three men in the box

17891.text:
with you the other day, they said you were
fooled, too. And they're sharp secret service

17896.text:
men!"
"You're very convincing, aren't you?" he raged.

17906.text:
up with spies and traitors. You believe...."
He outlined, with precision, exactly what

17914.text:
Lockley did believe; that phantom monsters
were to be credited with waging war against

17919.text:
America while another nation actually murdered
Americans. It was a remarkably accurate picture

17926.text:
of Lockley's state of mind.
"But that's all wrong!" insisted Sattell.

17933.text:
"This is a quick trick by our own people for
our own safety. For the benefit of all the

17939.text:
world. It's a trick to forestall just what
I described!"

17945.text:
The far away headlights drew nearer. But no
car could have come from the construction

17951.text:
camp as quickly as this.
"The fact is," said the general, "that our

17956.text:
spies tell us that another very great nation
has developed this beam we've been demonstrating

17962.text:
to all the world. So did we. And we couldn't
use it, but they would! If they didn't use

17971.text:
it against us, they'd use it for any sort
of emergency dirty trick. So we made up this

17978.text:
invasion to persuade every country on earth
to arm itself against this particular weapon.

17985.text:
Nothing less than monsters in space would
justify arming, in the eyes of some politicians!

17990.text:
Of course, they'll arm against us as well
as--anybody else."

17996.text:
He spoke matter-of-factly. A glance at Lockley's
face would have told him that persuasiveness

18003.text:
would not work.
"This trick, with the defense we intended

18008.text:
to reveal," the general added, "should mean
that a very nasty weapon won't ever be used,

18014.text:
either to start or end a war. Maybe the war
won't occur because we've said there are monsters

18021.text:
who fly around in space ships."
Lockley had a confused impression that he

18028.text:
was dreaming this. It was not the way things
should happen! This was not true! When he

18035.text:
squeezed or released the improvised switch
in his hand, the rocket behind him would disappear

18040.text:
in a monstrous flame, and he and the three
men who faced him would, vanish, and there

18046.text:
would be an explosion crater here and a shattered
mass of wrecked cars--

18051.text:
"It was an interesting job," said Vale. "The
Army dumped a hundred tons of high explosive

18058.text:
into the lake. The two radars that reported
a ship in space were arranged to be operated

18063.text:
by two special men, who got their orders directly
from the President. We picked a day with full

18069.text:
cloud cover; the radar operators inserted
their faked tapes and made their reports;

18075.text:
and the Army set off the hundred-ton explosion
in the lake. From there on, it was just a

18081.text:
matter of using the terror beam."
"I mention," said the general mildly, "that

18089.text:
not one human being has been killed by anything
we've done. Would you expect traitors to be

18095.text:
so careful? Or spies?"
Lockley said thickly, "You stand there arguing.

18102.text:
You're trying to make me believe you. But
there's Jill! What's happened to her? How

18108.text:
did you make her record that tape? Where's
Jill? She won't tell me it's all right!"

18115.text:
Headlights swept up to the floodlit space.
The car stopped.

18120.text:
Jill came into view. She saw Lockley, standing
against the rocket's base. She ran.

18126.text:
She stood beside the general and Vale and
Sattell. She looked worn and desperately anxious.

18133.text:
"What have they done to you?" demanded Lockley
fiercely.

18138.text:
She shook her head.
"N-nothing. I couldn't stay at the camp when

18142.text:
I was so sure you'd come to try to help me.
So I came here. I don't know what they've

18148.text:
told you yet, but it's all right. We were
fooled as the world has to be. Believe it!

18156.text:
Please believe it!"
"What have they done to you?" he repeated

18162.text:
terribly.
"What have they done to the world?" demanded

18166.text:
Jill. "They've made every nation look to us
as the defender of their freedom. And we are!

18173.text:
They've made everybody ready to fight against
more monsters if they come, and to fight against

18179.text:
men if they try to enslave them with the terror
beam or anything else! Would traitors have

18184.text:
done that?"
Lockley knew that he had to decide. It was

18190.text:
an unbearable responsibility. He was not convinced,
even by Jill. But he was no longer certain

18197.text:
that he'd been right.
"Why didn't you kill me?" he demanded. "I

18202.text:
could have been shot down from a distance.
You didn't have to come close to talk to me.

18208.text:
If the rocket blew, what would it matter?"
"You've got a protection against the terror

18215.text:
beam," said the general matter-of-factly.
"So have we. But ours weighs two tons. Yours

18222.text:
can be carried without being a burden. And--"
his eyes went to the unlikely cheese grater

18228.text:
over Lockley's shoulder--"and yours detonates
explosives. If we can equip the world with

18235.text:
those, Lockley, we'll have peace!"
Lockley thought of a decisive test. He grimaced.

18243.text:
"You want me to risk being a traitor! All
right, what's in it for me? What am I offered?"

18251.text:
The general shrugged, his eyes hardening.
Vale spread out his hands. Sattell snorted.

18258.text:
Jill moistened her lips. Lockley turned upon
her.

18263.text:
"You want me to believe," he said harshly.
"What do you offer if I turn over the thing

18269.text:
to these men you say are honest men and neither
spies or traitors. What do you offer?"

18276.text:
She stared at him. Then she said quietly,
"Nothing."

18282.text:
Lockley hesitated once more, for a long instant.
But that was the right answer. Nobody who'd

18289.text:
been bought or bribed or frightened into being
a traitor would have thought of it.

18294.text:
"That," said Lockley, "by a strange coincidence
happens to be my price."

18301.text:
He ripped away a wire. He flung the queer
combination of pocket radio and cheese and

18306.text:
nutmeg graters to the general.
"I'll explain later how it works," he said

18311.text:
wearily, "--if I haven't made a mistake."
* * * * *

18317.text:
After a suitable time the general came to
him. Lockley was convinced, now. The reaction

18323.text:
of the men who'd been guards and truck drivers
and the like was conclusive. They regarded

18328.text:
him with a certain cordial respect which was
not the reaction of either traitors or invaders.

18335.text:
"We've been checking that little device, Lockley,"
said the general happily. "It's perfect for

18342.text:
our purposes! So much better than a two-ton
generator to interfere with and cancel the

18348.text:
terror beams! Marvelous! And do you know what
it means? With all the world believing we've

18354.text:
been attacked from space, and with our great
show of taking back Boulder Lake--"

18359.text:
"How will you manage that?" asked Lockley,
without too much interest.

18365.text:
"The rocket," said the general, beaming. "When
troops start into the Park, the rocket takes

18371.text:
off. It heads for empty space. And we explain
that the aliens went away when they found

18378.text:
their weapon useless and we started to get
rough with them!"

18382.text:
"Oh," said Lockley listlessly.
"But the really beautiful thing," the general

18388.text:
told him, "is your gadget! They can be made
by millions. Ridiculously cheap, they tell

18394.text:
me. Everybody in the world will want one,
and we'll pass them out. No government could

18401.text:
stop that! Not even Russia! But--d'you see,
Lockley?"

18406.text:
Lockley shook his head. He always had a tendency
to look on the dark side of future events.

18413.text:
The future did not look bright to him.
"Don't you see?" demanded the general, chuckling.

18421.text:
"They detonate explosives, those little gadgets!
There's no harm in that! Where explosives

18427.text:
are used in industry you've only to make sure
that nobody turns one on too close. In nine-tenths

18434.text:
of the world, anyhow, civilians aren't allowed
to have guns. But think of the consequences

18440.text:
there!"
Lockley was weary. He was dejected. The general

18445.text:
grinned from ear to ear.
"Why, when these are distributed, even the

18450.text:
secret police can't go armed! What price dictators
then? For that matter, what price soldiers?

18458.text:
The cold war ends, Lockley, because there
couldn't be a conquering army in the modern

18463.text:
sense. The tanks wouldn't run. The cars would
stall. And the guns--An invasion would have

18471.text:
to be made with horse-drawn transport and
the troops armed with bows and spears. That

18477.text:
amounts to disarmament, Lockley! A consummation
devoutly to be wished! I'm going to look forward

18484.text:
to a ripe old age now. I never could before!"
* * * * *

18490.text:
Presently Lockley talked to Jill. She was
constrained. She seemed uneasy. Lockley felt

18498.text:
that there wasn't much to say, now that Vale
was alive and well and there was no more danger

18503.text:
for her. He offered his hand to say good-bye.
"I think," she said with a little difficulty,

18513.text:
"I think I should tell you I'm not--engaged
any longer. I--told him I--wouldn't want to

18521.text:
be married to someone whose work made him
keep secrets from me."

18526.text:
Lockley tensed. He said incredulously, "You're
not going to marry Vale?"

18532.text:
She said nervously.
"No-o-o. I've told him."

18542.text:
"He--didn't like it," said Jill. "But he understood.
I explained things. He said--he said to congratulate

18552.text:
you."
Lockley made an appropriate movement. She

18557.text:
wept quietly, held close in his arms.
"I was so afraid you didn't--you wouldn't--"

18565.text:
Lockley took appropriate measures to comfort
her and to assure her that he did and he would,

18571.text:
forever and ever. A very long time later he
asked interestedly, "What did you say to Vale

18579.text:
when he asked you to congratulate me?"
"I said," said Jill comfortably, "that I would

18586.text:
if things worked out all right. And they have.
I congratulate you, darling. Now how about

18596.text:
The rocket took off and went away into emptiness.
This was near dawn, when military announcements

18603.text:
of the reoccupation of Boulder Lake were being
passed out to the news media. As much of the

18609.text:
public as was awake was informed that the
monstrous aliens had fled from earth, their

18614.text:
intentions frustrated by the work of scientists.
It wasn't necessary for a large force to march

18621.text:
in. A special detail took over at the lake
itself. Curiously enough, it seemed to be

18627.text:
already there when the question arose. It
would report a regrettable absence of alien

18633.text:
artifacts by which the monsters might be kept
in mind.

18638.text:
But there would be reminders. Later bulletins
would report that the United States was putting

18644.text:
into quantity production the small, individual
protective devices which defied the terror

18650.text:
beam and would supply them to all the world.
There could not be greater friendship than

18656.text:
that! The United States also proposed a world
wide alliance for defense against future attacks

18663.text:
by space monsters, with pooled armament and
completely cooperative governments.

18670.text:
The world, obviously, would unite against
monsters. And people in a posture of defense

18677.text:
against enemies from the stars obviously wouldn't
fight each other.

18682.text:
And there were some people who were pleased.
They knew about the possibilities of the small

18688.text:
gadgets, brought down in production to the
size of a pack of cigarettes. Knowing what

18694.text:
they could do, they waited very interestedly
to see what would happen in certain nations

18700.text:
when secret police couldn't carry firearms
and soldiers could only be armed with spears.

18708.text: They expected it to be very interesting indeed.
